author: Amazon Customer

author: Bruce M.
title: This item is very bad, doesn't feel right when playing forza
content: This item is very bad, doesn't feel right when playing forza.  When you go fast, the car just slides out of control and spins out, whatever went into it is very cheap and it doesn't feel real.

author: CoopaPple
title: Buy it
content: It's great and works well.

author: Chuck K. Hamilton
title: The brake is far too stiff and it doesn't work ...
content: The brake is far too stiff and it doesn't work at all with my PC. Causes an immediate BSOD as soon as it's plugged into any USB port.

author: reviewer
title: Works Very Well with Xbox one X
content: so far this is great steering wheel. Not sure about negative reviews, one major thing i noticed is that no other controllers can be connected to the xbox. Initially it wasn't working looked on line looked @ logitech website no one mentions the very important single thing is to disconnect all controllers. No need to update firmware. Here is how to make it work with everything. 1) disconnect all xbox controllers 2) plug G920 adapter in wall 3) plug in G920 usb to xbox 4) wait for calibration to finish 5)press xbox button on G920 6) navigate with pad on G920 to sign in to your profile with steering wheel 7) presto it works with all my games. Very awesome force feedback, Using Forza 7 and Need for speed payback - all functions work, shifter clutch everything... hope this helps

author: Philip Tramontana
title: Better than I hoped
content: Its made out of really good materials and is really firm. Everything works how its supposed to and is better than imagined.

author: DnaAngel
title: Works well, just don't like it
content:
I've always wanted to try a decent wheel in a racing game, but didnt want to cheap out completely. Decided to give this one a go. It takes some getting used to, but no matter the FFB settings I just dont like racing with a wheel. Though I did really enjoy it in American/Euro Truck Simulator, esp with the shifter. Outside of those including Project Cars 2, Forza 7/Horizon 4, And Assetto Corsa I just couldn't really get into it. Maybe it's decades of using an analog gamepad on PC for racing games idk. I love racing games and driving in real life. Can't believe this was a buyers remorse for me.

I also didn't like the feel of the 'gears' in the wheel when turning, just felt awkward and unrealistic. Maybe a belt driven FFB wheel would have been a more realistic and better experience?

author: Frenchy
title: Great beginner set up.
content: It works good, would be great for a beginner wheel for any one starting out. but theres a few things that sorta bug me. Theres Grindy noise when steering and FFB is engaged on high setting, if your learn to race sim and you do lots of grass and wall things youl get a chatery sound and the wheel jerking left and right. The wheel is sort of small for my liking

author: Dave Baxter
title: Three Stars
content: Opted for higher end controllers

author: Jeannaldo
title: Five Stars
content: I love it. Feels perfect with the force feedback. The only thing is the wheel has loose strings.

author: KT
title: Sub par
content:
I have been using this wheel for a couple months now on iracing. The wheel works great and the force feedback is amazing. It is a bit noisy but I never hear it because I use a headset while racing. The pedals are very sturdy. I love having the buttons on the wheel due to the fact I can assign them for in car functions. Helps a lot not having to reach over to hit a button. Would highly recommend the G29!
**UPDATE**
Wheel has started losing calibration in game. I have tried it on different games to see if it was just a certain game but the problem continues. This should not happen to a product this expensive and only 2 months of light use. After a little research it seems I am not the only one to have this issue. I DO NOT recommend the G29. There are way better wheels on the market for this price.
**UPDATE**
After receiving a new wheel and pedals from Logitech on a warranty claim the pedals are now having an issue. The throttle pedal will not fully engage in game. I have checked for updates and even re installed software. This will be the second warranty claim in less than a year. This is a cheap made overpriced product and I DO NOT recommend buying it.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Four Stars

author: Amazon Customer
title: ... a little stiff but over all it is a great product

author: RU
title: WASTE OF MONEY - DO NOT BUY!
content:
This wheel has terrible force feedback. It skips, shakes, and vibrates when it should not.
I received this wheel and as soon as it was plugged, it was already broken. After waiting 3 weeks for a replacement, I opened it up and plugged it in. Once again, the replacement was broken before I even used it. I sent it back in for another replacement, and nearly ONE MONTH LATER, I have not received it yet.
I bought my first wheel November 24th of 2015, and have not had a working wheel to use since then.

I would give this negative stars if I could.

author: Sebastian Filutowski
title: Five Stars
content: Exactly what I was hoping for.

author: Cramlin
title: Really happy with this wheel
content: Really happy with this wheel. Based on all the people suggesting Thrustmaster wheels over this one I was a little concerned as to how much I was going to like it. After having this wheel a week now I can say that those concerns were completely unwarranted. This thing is an absolute blast on my PS4 with Project Cars, you really feel every little detail through the wheel, even when you go over curbing you can tell which side of the car went over it through the wheel. It's really transformed my racing experience, I don't even feel like I'm playing the same game anymore. I highly recommend this wheel.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Logitech g 920 is a pain in the *.*.
content: My g 920 worked i had a power surge and bought a replacement. I can not make this one work.

author: Mk inc.
title: Cheap feel
content: Does feel realistic at all, wheel is so small feels like I'm driving those little red toy cars with your feet to push. Wheel vibrates so much it always loosens up from my desk that it's attached to. Too much feedback from the wheel doesn't feel real at all. Shifter was cool tho

author: Brenda Murphy
title: Love it !!!!
content: Love it !!! Much easier than racing with controller !!

author: Drizztace25
title: Five Stars
content: Good feedback and feel. Brake pedal is stiff but not unreasonable. Solid shifts with paddles..great force feedback

author: Patricia Ferdig
title: Bring your race game to a new level
content:
There is a good amount of gaming that takes place in my household and I was very excited to try this racing wheel. I wish that I could give a 3.5 star review; the set is exceptional, but super expensive and a slight pain to get working on Windows 7 x64.

Fresh out of the box my first thoughts were that this product feels well made, it is hefty and the hand stitched leather on the steering wheel feels excellent. The pedal base has a pop out pad of spikes to keep it from moving on carpet, which I found to work quite well without it tearing up the carpet at all. It mounts easily and securely to my desk with two clamps that screw into place.

Some of the only issues I had installing the device was when I installed the Logitech Gaming Software package from the official website, and after successful installation, Windows 7 informed me it was an unsigned driver then disabled the device.  Heading back to the Logitech website I noticed under the details tab that Windows 7 users need to install a certain Windows Update, which fixed my unsigned driver issue.

The force feedback on the wheel is quite strong, and I have it turned down a bit from the default levels. The Logitech software allows full configuration of buttons as well as sensitivity levels for the wheel and pedals.

This really takes games to the next level and I highly recommend it for the serious game lover.

author: AJ Smith
title: Great quality, realistic, works great with PC and Xbox
content: I love this thing to bits and it’s only been a month. I use this wheel on American truck simulator, Euro Truck Simulator 2, Forza horizon 4, and other assortments of racing and driving games. The response in the wheel makes it feel like you’re sitting high in the cab of a Kenworth W900, or whizzing by in a formula 1 race car. It has very good, high quality leather wrapped around it which adds to realism and gives it a nice grip to hold onto. It works well with both PC and Xbox, and I advise buying the shifter with it because it works great with the shifter.

author: kole hosch
title: East-bound and down
content: I've had this wheel for about a month now, and for ATS mainly, but I also play nascar 15 and wreckfest with it and I am in love. For ATS, the wheel rotates almost picture perfect with the wheel in game, so you may want to get your steering wheel knob now 😂. I have seen some people talk about no calibration disk and stuff, and I'm not a computer genius or anything, but after looking at some forums and stuff, I've found that you download some logitech stuff to your PC, have it recognize the device and all of that (does not take long) and it's been picture perfect! Now I cannot stop playing ATS, and I highly recommend this wheel!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Really annoying squeak when turning left
content: Wheel is decent but has a terrible squeak when turning left.

author: Jeffryb24
title: come fast
content: Best product

author: Joshua Morris
title: I've had this bad boy for a while now
content: I've had this bad boy for a while now, and I must say that when it works, it works very well. I'm using it mainly for simulation games like Euro Truck Sim 2 and Fernbus Simulator. For me, these games occasionally have trouble recognizing the wheel, but once things are set up it runs like a dream. Make sure the desk or table top you intent to mount this thing to isn't too wide - about a half- or one-inch thick table top is ideal. The construction is decent, with thick plastic, solid metals, and even a nice leather binding on the wheel. You get what you pay for when it comes to these racing wheels, and this one is worth its price. Be prepared to troubleshoot and restart a few games to get it working.

author: Kindle Customer

Only problem is that the little knob on the shifter where u tighten to where you place it seemed to brake easily so placing it somewhere else would be a pain. But overall amazing product for $300

author: La Toya Wynn
content: Great buy! Can't go wrong!

author: Rosangel Polo
title: Five Stars
content: Amazing

author: Tony Sexton
title: VERY realistic steering feel!
content: This wheel/pedal set is wonderful!  This is my first set ever,  but I'm happy to say that the steering wheel itself has far exceeded what I was expecting.  I am playing Forza Motorsport 7 on Xbox One X and every car has its own response and feel in steering.  It's so close to reality that I have just ordered a genuine racing seat  so I can build my own gamer seat stand. I have already suggested this set to 2 of my friends.  If something happens to this one,  I will buy another of the same.

author: Brent A Justus

Put in project cars 2 and went into settings menu where the wheel turns freely and turned it lock to lock like 30 times starting slow till very fast. Noise went away. Just not sure if it's gone for good, but it's been fine for a couple hours.

author: Tony

content:
If you look at the Logitech (G920), Microsoft XBox One and Forza 6 forums, you'll know there are lots of issues. For me, the wheel wasn't working out of the box. I had to reset it constantly for it work. Even after it calibrated itself, I couldn't adjust the settings. The G920 couldn't be recognized in the XBox one devices and accessories.  Going to return this back to Amazon.

It's built very solidly and could last a while.

author: Rich Choi
title: Everything is great but the brake pedal
content: Everything is great but the brake pedal. It does not engage till it is about half way down and you have to press real hard to make it register.

author: Lisa Salas
title: Good product
content: I loved it, spend hours of fun playing on it.  Brings my games to life

author: Kate Wagner
title: Okay wheel, horrible pedals.
content: The wheel is fine, but the pedals are awful, mostly because of the brake which is complete garbage. I don't know what they were thinking. The ff feels a little jerky to me, but its mostly the bad pedals that ruin this. I wish I had gotten the Thrustmaster t300rs to begin with as people on reddit recommended. Glad I was able to return this and purchase that, with the t3pa pedals, because unlike Logitech, thrustmaster built in adjustments so you don't have to break your warranty to change the feel of the brake.

author: Casey Wood
title: The steering wheel feedback makes racing games more fun but also a bit difficult until you get used ...
content: Got this for my husband and he loves it! The steering wheel feedback makes racing games more fun but also a bit difficult until you get used to it. We also got the shifter but until he’s more used to the wheel it’s more decoration, there’s also shifters on the steering wheel so the shift knob isn’t necessary if you want to race manual.

author: Thomas P.

author: JD Shields

For those of you brushing off the reviews other people have left regarding the brake pedal:
Do not ignore this. It certainly doesn't feel like it is something that will ever "wear in." It doesn't bother me much because I mostly use it for GT Sport, in which I use ABS. But I can certainly see how this could be a deal breaker for some.

The wheel itself feels amazing compared to my old Drive Force GT.

author: Amazon Customer

author: Amazon Customer
title: Good quality so far 2 weeks in.
content: Great wheel, came a day late but that's alright...quality good...only Con is the brake is so hard to push but with some settings you get used to it.

author: Phil S.
title: G920 Driving Force Racing Wheel Review
content:
I am still trying in vain to figure the Logitech G920 Wheel out. I got it working, but the only way to get it to work is to hook it up into Xbox One & reset the Xbox One. The Xbox One works using the controllers off of the G920, but I constantly get a message on the screen telling me that the controller  has been disconnected. Also I have no way of calibrating the G920 using the Xbox as the Xbox One does not identify the G920. I can set the parameters to the G920 on the computer & did get the G920 updated, but I still can not calibrate the G920. This was suppose to be a plug & play setup. Xbox is suppose to work hand in hand & at the very least, recognize this wheel. Also when racing down the straightaway for no reason the wheel starts vibrating moving car from left to right, causing loss of control, this is frustrating as it just happens out of the blue. I let off the throttle but to no avail, an uncontrollable  crash is evidently in store. Never had this problem before using the Xbox controller. The pedals are cumbersome but work. they move across the carpet & cause issues from a stability stand point. Still waiting for the seat & wheel holder to arrive. I was able to block the pedals from moving by placing a 2 by 6 in between the legs of the table I have the Wheel & Shifter attached to. I'm sure some of the stability issues will go away once I get the seat & stand. Also ran into issues with the Amazon order & a delivery of 3 of these shifters & 2 sets of wheels & pedals. All I wanted was a bundle package with a Logictech G920 Wheel, Pedals, & a Shifter, that I had seen on Amazon .com, but when I place the original order a box was checked on the page to order only the wheel. I tried to cancel order like 3 minutes after I submit it, but was messaged that I couldn't cancel order because it was all ready processed & shipped.  ????? 3 Minute shipping is unheard of. Come on Amazon. Any way I reorder the Logitech G920 Wheel with the Pedal Box checked & wala. I get a confirmation on the second order & they tell me everything will be shipped together. O. K. I thought you just emailed me told me the original order was already shipped. Go figure. At least I had 1 extra wheel & set of pedals & 2 extra shifters incase something didn't work right. Oh well, I will be sending the extras back as they charged my card for them. :(
This was my fist eventful experience with Amazon as usually they are pretty straight forward & things go pretty smoothly. I am a first time wheel & pedal user. I have not bought this kind of stuff before, but wanted to give it a shot. Only directions or information in the box for the whole setup is a small diagram showing how to hook it up & a FCC Licensing information. Wow I can see a whole bunch of frustrated kids out there, feeling pretty fed up, & giving up on what might be something good. I did go to the Logitech Website. After spending almost an hour trolling through the web page I was able to find the Game Control Section & was able to upgrade the drivers in the G920. Now to tech support. None they run you through a bunch of hit & miss trouble shooting theory's & in the end tell you that if your G920 is not working correctly with the Xbox One to disconnect the USB Cable & simultaneously pressing the LSB button, View button, & Xbox button, plug the  USB cord back into the Xbox One. I can see that many people have accomplished this task by themselves. It may some sort of hay wired G920 reset code,  but come on guys. The tech support sucks. No phone #'s to call, no chat, no email service,  just other customers claiming to have the same problems & what they did to fix the problem. What a blogout.  I will edit the review when I see how things pan out with the returning of the unopened items. Lack of support from Logitech as they seem to figure that everybody should already know what to do when their product doesn't seem to work right. That seems to be a no-brainer.

author: asdf
title: This is a great mid-range wheel
content:
This is a great mid-range wheel. The pedals are a strong point, they have a smooth progressive throw and unique to the Logitech system, they're mounted on a wide, solid base with a carpet grabber, rendering them usable without a simpit.

Alongside belt-based systems, the geared force feedback system used here feels rough and grindy. If I hadn't tested it alongside the Thrustmaster I think it would have felt fine

I was able to bind the pedals to roll and boost in Star Citizen

author: Z
title: Been solid through grueling iRacing events (Windows 10)
content:
According to other reviews, I must have gotten one of the good ones. So far this thing has been great. The build feels really well and the FFB is enough to keep me satisfied. I have put this thing through hell racing dirt with sprint cars and modified on iRacing and it is holding its own. Plenty of buttons to map for ease of use in VR. The only thing I would like better is if the wheel was just a tad bigger in diameter. It does have the grindy feel due to the gear system it uses, but once you get your preferred settings in order, you can hardly tell. For the money, this wheel is by far the best you can get. Word of advice, if you are having trouble installing the Logitech software on your Windows 10 machine, unplug your optical drive prior to installing. As crazy as this sounds, it works when you run into the installation hanging up.

*Update*
After hours upon hours of use, the unit has started to make the squeaking noises that other users have mentioned. IT only seems to do it after sitting over night. Once the unit gets used and the gears get re-greased the sound seems to go away. I will eventually take the wheel apart and put some high quality airplane grease on the gears but everything seems to be in working order. I use VR with this wheel so I don't seem to notice any concerning noises coming from the unit.

author: liz
title: So far so good. Only used twice so far but everything works ...
content: So far so good. Only used twice so far but everything works and set up is easy. Table happened to be a great height for the steering wheel to be comfortable. Only real complaint is I wish the pedal were heavier because it'll slide back if not against something but I just put a big book behind it and that solved that.

author: B.J. Carroll
title: Great wheel for us casual sim racers.
content:
Pros:
 Looks good
 All the buttons you will need are on the wheel
 Wheel is high quality in its build
 Pedals do not slide around
 Clutch and gas pedals feel great

Cons:
 Brake is very stiff. There are a lot of YouTube videos on modding the pedal
 The right knob on the shifter does not pop up as it should thus making it harder to tighten down to desk
 Shifter not included with the wheel (making the cost higher than it should be)
 Shifter can not be put in sequential mode (G25 shifter had this option)

author: Gearz
title: wheel and pedals are fantastic! game support isn't that great
content:
wheel and pedals are fantastic! game support isn't that great, yet. I'm hoping that game devs will be sure to include profiles for this setup.

Build quality is very good, the feel is fantastic and the gameplay is greatly enhanced. Thanks for making the brake pedal feel more brakey!

author: Matthew Snyder
title: Great wheel
content: This is a great wheel. The feedback is super realistic and the motors in the wheel are fierce. You will def need a sturdy mount for it.

author: teletub
title: GreatWheel
content: If it wasn't for this wheel, I'd toss my new xBox One.

author: Y. Lo
title: Five Stars

author: Dean Buck
title: G920 is not PC compatible.
content: The G920 is advertised as being PC compatible. It is not. Internet searches for this product will clearly show many issues with connecting it to a PC running WIN 10. I have returned the item and requested a refund. I will not buy Logitech products in the future.

author: charlie
title: Good product
content: works great with Grand Prix

author: KDad
title: Other than the brake pedal being a little stiff (for which their is an easy mod to fix)
content:
This would be a 5 Star review if the unit didn’t nose dive off a cliff as soon as the base warranty expired.

Bought this unit for iRacing. Other than the brake pedal being a little stiff (for which their is an easy mod to fix), it works great for Sim racing.

However, the base warranty ran out about a week ago, and the unit died almost immediately afterwards. Won’t read on a PS4, won’t read on a computer, went through the whole routine of trying to fix it through software, all to no avail.

In the end, without the ability to fix it myself, and paying for repairs being as expensive as buying a new unit, I guess it’s what I have to do.

So, great unit in terms of how it works, but buy the extended warranty.

author: Donald
title: The quality of the wheel is very good. I love the feel of the leather
content: I've wanted a driving wheel for a very long time and I finally bought this when it was $240. I was quite surprised with just how much the wheel fought back with force feedback. I want expecting it to work that well. The quality of the wheel is very good. I love the feel of the leather. The only two things I don't like it's that the brake isn't a progressive spring and that I can feel the gears when I turn the wheel. It isn't completely smooth as most cars are. Improve this two things and I'd rate it five stars.

author: Chris
title: USB cable is too short
content: I would give this 5 stars if the connecting USB cable to the Xbox was longer.  It is too short.  Needs about 6 more feet. Everything else works great.

author: WENDY BLEVINS
title: Great product
content: Real feel like you are in a car. My son loves it specially for iRacing

author: Steve
title: Not great. Ok for occassional use
content: Fun for kids. Too small and crappy for adults to use regularly. The pedal suck especially the brake. It has that stupid rubber thing and it ruins this unit.  Have to adjust Forza to have max braking at 15% travel or you will wreck cuz you can't stop. Wheel is tiny and the feedback is jerky. It only gets used when I have guests (and mostly young kids).  That is the only reason I keep it.

author: shakawa
title: Great deal
content: Works perfect

author: BananaCoffee402
title: Remove the stupid rubber piece they shove in the brake pedal to ...
content:
Brake pedal has been modded, if I didn't have to mod the brake pedal, I'd give it a 5 star. But in no circumstance have I ever had to put over 200lbs of pressure on a brake pedal in a vehicle in order to apply even 10% brakes.

Remove the stupid rubber piece they shove in the brake pedal to 'increase' realism, and it is a great buy.

author: Joshua caleb sannes
title: Five Stars
content: Works great and creates a good challenge for serious forza players

author: wayne snyder
title: Five Stars
content: looks good in the box ! have not had a chance to open yet !!!!!

author: Tina Buerke
title: Five Stars
content: PS3 and PS4 compatible. This is a G27 plus.

author: Amazon Customer
title: So realistic and a ton of fun with family and friends
content: Probably the coolest thing I've ever bought. So realistic and a ton of fun with family and friends.  Even the GF likes it!

author: Kindle Customer
title: Na
content: It is damage afer one month of use

author: Issam Ahmed
title: Great kit for first timers
content: Great kit for a first time steering wheel user like myself. I was plateauing on racing sims like GT5 and Dirt Rally on the PS4 controller. There's just no comparison really. And very glad I got force feedback not a simple wheel with bungee rope. That said, I wish they'd built in a port for a handbrake. Using the circle button doesn't have the same realistic feel as the rest of the kit. I see plenty of suggested mods involving soldering and more online but they require a level of time and DIY expertise I do not have.

author: David
title: Gas pedal did not work on arrival
content:
So it arrived today and straight out of the box the gas pedal did not work, would not register when brake and clutch did.

Thought about playing with the clutch as the gas pedal then thought I would crash my real car next time I got in it.

Getting a replacement, hopefully that works well.

author: Mubarak Alkhayarin
content: very good

author: Jeremy Haggard
title: Very expensive, but really a solid, high quality wheel.
content: I had the chance to use this steering wheel and a quick overview, it is made really well and feels like an actual steering wheel, not a toy which for the price is required. It has a built on controller functionality as well. The wheel and contrs are very responsive and it really is a lot of fun using this. The wheel itself is very expensive and for that I am knocking a star off, bit it works well.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Very disappointed with the wheel I have recieved.
content:
Purchased this wheel just 7 days ago (April 8th, 2016) and it is already broken (after just 6 days). I am extremely disappointed with the product I have recieved. I ran the wheel for about 3-4 days and it broke. The game I used this wheel with was Euro Truck Simulator 2.

The problem with my wheel is that when I turn the wheel al the way to the left and sometimes just a little bit, every single button activates at once. I did some reading and discovered this could be caused by the wires attached to the motherboard being broken around the connector causing a short/bad connection (though this is not the issue with mine). After reading that I reinstalled the drivers and did everything that might have fixed it. After a little more wheel movement the wheel is no longer memorized by my PC. Also, another very common issue is the brake pedal being extremely and unrealistically stiff. Either the brakes are barely pressed, or they're entirely applied.

Either way this wheel was poorly designed because of the wires breaking off due to not having enough slack for the wires run up to the motherboard. Also the brake pedal as mentioned. One last thing is compatibility and software. There is no way to use a "profiler" like previously with the G27. The G920 and G27 are only good for a few games which makes this wheel nearly pointless.

I can not recommend this wheel due to the poor design and drivers/software that is provided. I would recommend finding a different brand like Thrustmaster or similar wheels. This wheel is supposed to be PC compatible but it is far from it. Only a few games work with it and it's very difficult to keep it working properly. It is not an out of the box wheel and it does not support PC entirely as it is recognized as a controller.

author: Khiasa Frederick Jeter
title: Most suitable for beginners
content: This product would be much better if there were adjustable pedals. The pedals are just too close, and make for a difficult time driving with proper technique. This product is acceptable for a novice. Anyone with advanced skill will be disenchanted if they were to purchase this set.

author: TJ Aldridge
title: Best racing wheel I have ever used.
content: This wheel is amazing to use. I am currently using it to play American Trucking Simulator and it has made the gaming experience much better. I have tried racing wheels in the past but they always made driving much more difficult. This one has changed how I feel about racing wheels for the better. The force feedback really makes you think about how deep you should be turning the wheel when going fast. The more violent it vibrates indicates that you are risking your truck and trailer rolling over in the turn. I love the rev indicator leds as they really help get the shifting right. I also own the H-shifter which is a great addition.The number of buttons helps limit how much I need to rely on the keyboard for in game functions. You can even assign G key macro commands to any of the buttons which I use to trigger my 3 button push-to-talk for teamspeak. The volume buttons are in a great spot so I never have to reach for my keyboard volume buttons during the game. The red dial is handy as I have the transmission retarder mapped to. The bottom PS4 buttons can be used with the pc and can be programmed to do anything you need them to be. For anyone that knows LUA scripting, any button on here can but scripted just like other G key devices.

author: queenc
title: Not impressed
content:
I do not normally complain about things I purchase, but I want to post this message to see if something can be done about my product. I recently purchased a Logitech G920 Driving Force Racing Wheel. I believe I have had it for about two months now. Normal usage is about 5-6 times a week( 1-2 hours at a time-if that). I have to say, this product is absolutely awful. The pedals are very sticky(brake pedal has a soft feel , then gets hard, then soft again- Almost like it has a rub somewhere in the pedal mechanism)  The accelerator pedal is way too soft and does not have much throw, the clutch pedal/accelerator both have some dead spots (calibration won’t read them accurately as they are depressed.- and yes I have updated all the drivers) And it is not very user friendly when installing on to your computer ( I had to remotely install everything several times and Google how to solve the USB issues, before I could get the product to actually function-)

Moving along to the wheel- The wheel is my least favorite part. The feel and size of the wheel is nice, however the functionality is awful. The wheel has a giant dead spot that is left of center. (I have to recalibrate this wheel every time I load up *IRACING.) This dead spot makes it nearly impossible to use. I have adjusted the sensitivity settings to try to compensate for this, it has helped but this dead spot but it is just nearly impossible to adjust for. I am not happy with this product at all.

I use many Logitech devices and are very happy with everything else I have. I really miss the G27, as this was a far better product . (even though this is based on that platform)

Hope to get a reply from the manufacture.

Brent

author: Dan Mitchell
title: Very Strong Force Feedback - Racing Wheel I Ever Had!
content: Great Racing Wheel for PC (Win 10) . I decided for the PC/PS4 version and did not regret. Even fits for a thick desk plate. Feels very comfortable, has lots of settings and looks very sturdy. Don't have the impression that it will break anytime soon. I've already had many Racing Wheels, but this is the best one!

author: Patrick Dezarn
title: Great quality and design, Love/hate relationship with buttons though...
content:
I previously had been using my old Logitech geforce racing wheel that was advertised for Gran Turismo 4 way back in 2004-2005 for pc games. That wheel worked fine as it was the first to offer 900 degrees or rotation. However, the build quality of the pedals was too archaic to handle daily use and constantly had sensor issues. However, upgrading was always a big financial decision that kept me away from upgrading. Luckily this wheel went on sale and I did not hesitate in buying it.

The first major question was xbox version or ps4 version. Both work with PC but the ps4 version offers more buttons. This is a plus if you play racing sims and like to make in-car adjustments often, or race open-wheel cars like F1. However, I would take into consideration if you also play home consoles as well as PC.

The only issue I have with this wheel, and it's minor, is that when looking at the wheel you can clearly see what button is labeled what. It's easy to build muscle memory for button placement (for me it was since the placement hasn't changed much in 15yrs) but when you connect to the PC and play a racing sim I run into the same issue. Every game just lables the buttons as 1-20+. Some games identify this wheel and preset the buttons, but switching them up in the menus or trying trying to memorize what button is 12 vs when button is 5 is annoying when you realize the layout on the wheel isn't exactly  "in order". Buttons 1-12 flow in a nice, generalize pattern on the wheel, but once you get to around button 18 through (i think) 24.,... things start to be randomly spread around the wheel and you lose track where they are.

author: JD
title: OK wheel but with drawbacks
content:
For transparency, I didn’t buy this through Amazon, purchased through a local store, but only because they had it for local pickup the same day.

Don’t get me wrong, this is a fantastic wheel for the price... Especially for the casual console gamer. BUT, this in my opinion is NOT for those who are planning on getting serious on PC with simulators like iRacing, rFactor 2, or even games like PC2 and AMS where you want to be fully immersed into the race. Here’s why: The wheel is driven by gears, not belt driven.

It took a lot of hindsight to figure it out... researching types of wheels, their mechanics, features, and new tech to ultimately determine I did a wrong purchase. There are two things you want to look for in a good sim racing wheel: torque (strength) and smoothness. This wheel definitely can have a good amount of force, just enough to tell you what’s going on in the car, but definitely not the smoothness - gears grind pretty awful completely throwing you off the immersion of the game.

Go for a belt driven wheel, Thrustmaster T300/T300 RS, Fanatec if you can afford it. But if you’re the casual player, definitely worth a try with this wheel.

author: JDZ
title: So disappointed...
content:
Logitech G920 Racing Wheel. First let me say that, unlike a previous reviewer had stated, this item came VERY well packed for a box this size and weight. Not a single blemish on the original packaging. Kudos to Amazon for that.

I really wanted to like this product because of the pricepoint and the number of positive reviews. However there is always some risk whenever you buy stuff like this and I must've gotten a lemon. I highly doubt this unit was returned because the box, manuals and contents were super clean and factory sealed.

Now I consider myself computer and tech savvy, having written programming language in LUA like most people write shopping lists. I can also build custom button boxes from electronic junk found at thrift stores. But for the life of me I could not get this wheel to work with American Truck Simulator on my Windows 10 computer rig.

I know the G920 CAN work flawlessly with ATS/ETS because of the plethora of YouTube videos and posts in forums. But after updating the firmware and numerous attempts to configure the settings and map out the buttons, no matter what I tried, this controller would not cooperate with ATS and vice versa. Even though the software showed all button inputs were functioning properly, my in-game vehicle wouldn't go in reverse and I could not brake with the pedals. I had to resign to the fact that I was sent a defective unit and had to return it. Huge thanks to Amazon for their no-hassle, no-worry return policies. I guess I'll be looking at the Thrustmaster line of products.

author: Matthew C.
title: Its a great product. but whenever I plug it into my ...
content: Its a great product. but whenever I plug it into my PC, It keeps restarting. Once the restart takes place, it goes to the home screen, and restarts all over again. it says that there is an issue and windows is trying to find a soultion. Someone plz help me! i have an i7 6700k, gefore gtx 970 windforce, 16 gigs of ram, and 650watt power supply.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Working very nice with XBox One
content: This equipment is everything what I was looking for. Working very nice with XBox One! Delivery on time! Recommended!

author: Sam
title: Love it
content: Love it

author: P. R. C.
title: but once you get it tuned to how you like this is an amazing wheel
content: It's a little jerky with the default settings, but once you get it tuned to how you like this is an amazing wheel. Use it for a bit then play with Advanced settings within your game and it'll go from "This is neat" to "How can I live without you?"

author: Amazon Customer
title: The problem child in the Logitech family.
content:
I'll preface this review by saying that I previously had a G27 (among other higher end models), and have used several other wheels from both Logitech and other manufacturers. I am by no means a fan-boy for one brand other another, although the G27 has been a darling of mine, even after having used some comparably very expensive alternatives/upgrades. The general hand-feel and the experience as a whole with the G27 just left a lot more authentic and pleasant than others, especially due to the material the wheel is made from and the high build quality exhibited by the G27.

The G920 is supposedly an improvement upon the previous G27. It supposedly uses many of the G27's parts, but with minor tweaks here and there. along with enhanced compatability for 'modern' PC's and consoles. While I can see the similarities on paper, in practice these two products are night and day, and sadly not in the way that you might hope!

The leather on every G920 I have seen and/or felt has had a poor finish, particularly where the inner rim of the wheel intersects with the cross-member of the weel. Usually appearing to not be properly sealed together. The stitching on the G920 feels very starchy, and sharp, almost as though its some kind of sharp, ill-finished plastic rather than a fabric, and this becomes uncomfortable if you're quickly grabbing and moving the wheel around during intense moments and not necessarily ensuring your hands are always in positions where the nasty feeling stitching is.

The pedals this time around have recieved a modification in the form of a lump of rubber inserted inside the mechanism for the break. This is supposed to give a more realistic feel to the pedal, but in my milage this results in is a serious amount of leg work and unless you're thinking of hard-mounting the wheel and pedals, you're going to be pulling the wheel off the desk its clamped to a lot, as you naturally pull on the wheel to gain the traction and purchase necessary to apply totally unrealistic amounts of pressure to the break pedal, desperately trying to get it to fully engage. To better illustrate, the logitech driver software and its GUI is generally very well done by allowing you to not only setup each individual button but set options for most of them such as activation sensitivity. If one were to examine the brake pedal here in the gui while attempting to depress it so far as is reasonably comfortable, you see that its almost impossible to reach anything like 50% activation.

To work-around what I consider to be an inferior breaking experience due to this, I jacked-up the sensitivity from the default 50% to 100%. Doing this made it possible to get ~50% breaking activated without having to get uncomfortably forceful, although the highest activation I was able to manage was 70-80%, and that involved fully standing on the pedal and having it be weight bearing. As some other reviews have eluded, I am sure that if I spent many, many hours crushing this piece of rubber by depressing the break extremely forcefully, it might in the long-run be more reasonable to use, but I'm just not up for having to do that with a product in order to hopefully have it usable afterwards. There are other options available such as disassembling the pedals and the brake assembly to remove the block of rubber, which I'm assured solves this and allows the pedal to feel like any of the others, although I didn't get this far in with my last G920, as there was a more serious problem that had manifested within the first 2 hours of ownership which I'll go into later but suffice it to say that the whole ordeal of owning this product left a bad taste, and mobilised me to get a refund asap.

Above mentioned concerns aside, I can't for the life of me un-feel the motion of the gears within the wheel base moving when turning the wheel. Both the older G27 and this, the newer G920 supposedly use the same gearing system with different/updated sensors. For my money, the G920 feels absolutely nothing like the G27; with the G27, I didn't at all feel any of the gearing when turning the wheel, it was smooth and seamless, and any deadzone between teeth of these cogs felt so small the it was imperceivable. Now flashing forward to the G920, I can feel absolutely every cog engaging each and every single time I make even the most minor of adjustments to steering position, and the resistance provided by this engagement results in unpredictable movement where part of the a turn will feel lighter, faster or less resistant than others- imagine going up hill rather than down hill, obviously going up (against the tooth of the cog) will feel harder work and more resistant, but it feels like this happens every 1/4cm of a given turn.

After having felt the cogs moving as described that, not to mention the amount of mechanical noise they now make, I just can't un-feel it, and it gives you little confidence in accuracy if you're planning on playing say a racing game with the expectation of being able to reliably repeat sections/turns to get better times.

Moving on from the practical problems with the wheel, within 2 hours of light use, the wheel had developed an exceedingly irritating high pitched squeak when turning left. Think fingers down a chalk board type of sound, only constantly throughout any left rotation, and the vibration from that interplay of parts being felt throughout the wheel. Not overly enjoyable.

On the force feedback / vibrations (the intentional ones produced by the internal motors), I found these to be quite acceptable so long as you turn them down as in simulation games as the wheel would produce large amounts of counter-steer when just tootling along on flat tarmac. In racing or rallying titles the wheel produced results more in like with what you would expect. A lot of reviews and comments seem to elude to the force feedback not being overlypowerful. I disagree on this point, I feel as though it is plenty powerful, although I don't feel as though there's enough variety in the level of feedback. It often feels like its an all or nothing scenario. There are smaller more neuanced sensations it can produce, but the majority of the time it feels more like a harsh, jolting movement occasionally rather than an appropriate, sustained yet more subtle feeling.

Overall the I personally found the G920 totally underwhelming, and quite a problem child in Logitechs historically good family of products. I would highly, highly recommend the G27 over this if that is compatible with your choice of system, be it console or PC.

author: ClickerSnapper
title: I have owned for about a year now, here is my take.
content:
My videos can be found under clickersnapper01 on YT. Pedal pot issue and the simple fix on YT. Pedals are solid built with steel! ( Nothing has broken! ) and I'm rough on them!
After fixing the pot in the pedals i have had no issues with them! The wheel has been great ( No issues for me here ) although there is a dead zone of a few degrees L/R and I found no way to adjust. I race in GT Sport only on PS4. Would I buy again if need to? Probably as other wheels are very expensive. Oh and the red dial ( used for multiple adjusts ) Not responsive enough for me in GT Sport so I mapped this to buttons which work when you need them and focus on the road. ( fuel lean, tcs, abs, ect...)  Force feedback is adequate and can strain your muscles if you run off the road a lot! ( Ok by me! ) If Logitech would fix or have a software adjustment for dead zone and fix the pot issues ( which I see many have experienced ) And make sure that when you dial in fuel mixtures ect. with the red dial ( instead of have to keep turning until it responds ) they would have a GREAT wheel again. Thanks though go to them for there efforts. Without a product like this I really would not enjoy racing as much as I do! I simply cannot race a car with a joycon.

author: Mimimimim
title: Five Stars
content: Love it and works great.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Kid loves it.
content: Kid loves it

author: mit
title: works great, minor pc calibration
content:
Overall, it works wonderfully. I use it for my computer though due to the low number of actual racing games on PS4 that support racing wheels. I have not tested this on PS4, as I don’t own any ps4 racing wheel supported games.

While it does work amazingly well on PC, I have to manually recalibrate it with the windows 10 wheel/controller window. The software made to support wheel on PC does not work well at all (it doesn’t nit recognize games, no remapping controls for controller buttons like A, Start, R2, and has NO built in calibration). On the calibration, for some reason, every time I plug in my wheel on PC, the automatic calibration swings a good 5-8 degrees to the right; manual calibration fixes this.

author: Brendan Gray
title: G920 Rcaing wheel is awesome
content: The G920 Racing wheel from Logitech is one of my favorite steering wheels i have ever used. After having the wheel for about a week I have used it both on PC and on the Xbox one. I like the compatibility it has between the Xbox one and PC. The thing I loved the best about the steering wheel was the force feedback option, it gives you the real feeling that you are really driving the vehicle. The best games I have the most enjoyment with the G920 was Project Cars and American Truck Simulator. The wheel was built for both of these games and it feels great. The only thing I do not like is the slim amount of games the wheel is compatible with. Other than that the G920 Racing wheel is a great wheel and I recommend it to people that are try to get the best experience out of a racing game.

author: Donovan Dixon
title: Nice
content: Fun to use

author: Alexander Zaldivar
title: Waste of Money
content: We've had this wheel for only 6 months and it is now a paper weight. The tech support from LogiTech was not helpful at all after following their detailed "fixes" for the issue of the wheel no longer responding to the PC. Driver updates, OS updates in addition to a factory restore of our PC would not fix our issue of the wheel no longer being recognized by the host computer. We even tried replacing the the power supply per some LogiTech forum posts to no avail. Almost $300 lost hurts to the core when thinking about only being able to use this wheel for 3 months.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Not worth the headache
content:
As mentioned the brake pedal is ridiculously stiff. Tried in-game options and they made no difference. You can put your entire body weight into the pedal and your cars will slightly slow down but never come to a stop. I actually had to use the ebrake to completely stop the car.

Steering wheel was also IMPOSSIBLE to turn, and when you did get it to turn, it made a clanking sound. Logitech FAQ's suggested connecting to PC and changing sensitivity. That didn't quite sound like my problem, but I tried anyway. My PC is using Windows 7, and Windows WILL NOT recognize the wheel 50% of the time. I have to unplug and replug it in to get it to be recognized. Once plugged in, the Logitech Gaming Software SAYS THERE IS NO WHEEL CONNECTED. I have read over their forums, and the forums are no use at all. If someone from Logitech response at all, they never respond to your follow up. I tried to contact their support directly and they suggested applying the software update. I tried, and it too doesn't recognize the wheel. Worse yet, their own firmware updater freezes up and must be force closed. After multiple hours talking with support they were unable to even get their own software to recognize the device, let alone resolve my issue.

I have no option but to return the wheel and shifter (sold separately).

author: Reesefam
title: A lot of fun
content: Works really well. It is kind of tough to secure to surfaces. Had to get a little creative but manage to get everything secured. The build quality is pretty impressive and the feedback is pretty good as well.

author: Mervin A. Knotts
title: ... only took a few minutes and it's been working great
content: No problem to hook only took a few minutes and it's been working great

author: Walsh
title: Somewhat frustrating initially
content:
Works pretty well for the most part. The steering sensitivity is a bit tricky to get right for some games (Forza 6).  You will need a PC and Logitech Game software to make the proper adjustments.  Logitech support is pretty useless.

Do your homework first, read the forums, you'll soon see so many people with issues and this wheel. But once it's set up its a lot of fun.

PS. Did the brake pedal mod, and it's much better now.

author: Sherry Hill
title: NASCAR racing league must have
content: Perfect for online racing

author: Nathaniel
title: Squeaks when turning left
content: Squeaks when turning left

author: Kita
title: A great wheel with some teething issues
content:
I received a G29 as a warranty replacement for my G27. While I must thank Logitech for being so generous with the replacement, I must take a moment to warn those who are considering upgrading about some issues with the G29. I am primarily a PC player, but I also enjoy GT6.

Primarily, you'll find that the G29's drivers on a Windows machine are unsigned, meaning you cannot install the device without forcing a boot-time option to ignore driver signing in Windows, somewhat of an advanced procedure and detrimental to system security. In addition, the new Logitech Gaming software has removed several configuration options available to the G27, such as the ability to adjust FFB force, damper and spring force, and pedal axis combination. This completely breaks compatibility for many older games that require a combined throttle/brake axis. The new software also means that the G29 is not compatible with older versions of Windows, while the G27 could operate fully on Windows 98 and above. In addition to simulators like rFactor 2, I often play older titles like Gremlin Interactive's Whiplash, for which the G27 was a perfect controller with both Dosbox and running natively on an old PC. The G29 doesn't work properly with that game or many of its contemporaries. Hardcore simracers won't have many issues, but those who play a large amount of varied racing games may be disappointed.

As for the wheel itself, it's a very finely-crafted device, very comfortable, with a great button layout for any game. The gunmetal finish is gorgeous, and the leather feels a little softer and more textured than the G27. I feel that the brake bias adjustment wheel feels a little loose -- turning the adjustment wheel also slightly turns the button in its center, and as the R3 and L3 buttons "float" under the wheel's crossbars, careless hand placement could easily break them. On the other hand, all the buttons press crisply and are easy to find when focused on the road. The D-pad is particularly good, you could rock a fighting game with this thing! Because of its Dualshock face buttons, this wheel is great for emulators, so long as you don't need combined pedal axes.

The pedals are identical to the G27 except for the addition of a rubber stopper in the brake pedal. While this does work well as a non-linear brake, I find the rubber stopper to be too hard, especially in comparison to the soft spring. It feels more like a Gamecube shoulder trigger. It would have been great if Logitech allowed for stoppers of different hardness to be installed or for the stopper to be easily removed, but I imagine the rubber will grow softer with use and "blend" more with the spring.

Ultimately, this is another quality Logitech peripheral, let down only by unusually poor drivers.
If Logitech continues to update their software to include the missing functionality, I will revise my rating.

author: Stephen Anthony Spears
title: Works for about a month
content: Simply stopped sending signal from steering and pedals.  Is now a $200 paper weight.  Logitech is absolute trash

author: Kindle Customer

author: Chris
title: Annoying squeak out of the box
content: I love logitech products but the g29 and g920 they just cant seam to figure out how grease works its ridiculous super common problem the wheel squeaks when turning left. People have said they exchanged it under warranty and the new one did the exact same thing but if you take it apart to add grease it voids the warranty so be warned. I just got it 2/27/19. 4 years after it came out you would think they would get their act together but be weary I love the feel of the wheel and the price is great but the headache isn't worth it. Go thrust master if you want quality!

author: Robert Yost
title: Big Hit
content: Bought this, along with the Shifter, as a gift for our nephew's 13th birthday. He knew what was in the package before he opened it. He was so excited that he ripped through the other gifts, just so he could get to this as fast as he could.  It was set up and they were playing within minutes. We didn't see him or his friends after that.

author: Amazon Customer

content: Not new, it was used and damaged

author: Sai Vang
title: Dead spot is annoying
content: Works good unlike those cheapo steering wheel setups. Impressed with the metal pedal shifter and metal foot pedals and metal steering wheel. Good quality. Only big drawback is the 'dead spot' which is where the force feedback kind of clutters instead of force while driving straight over surfaces.

author: Will
title: Great price great wheel
content: Love this wheel. They price was just as great.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Five Stars
content: awesome for our race car room

author: Carlos Gotay
title: Impressed
content: Really impressed with this wheel set up. Have purchased others in past and not satisfied. Bought it for Gran Turismo Sport and really love how the wheel fights with you like a real car amazing might be buying the one for Xbox and can't wait to use it on my PC

author: Amazon Customer
title: Five Stars
content: Awesome

author: jeff moore
title: Son likes it
content: Seems to work well

author: Timothy J Steltz
title: A great buy
content: A awesome steering wheel and pedal combo. Has  worked flawlessly so far.

author: Shane Eells
title: Next level racing fun
content:
I've had the g920 and been using it on Xbox One X for about a week, playing mostly Forza Horizon 4. I have dabbled in a couple others. Setting up the wheel is a breeze. No updates needed. It mounts very solidly with its clamp, provided you have a few inches of ledge on the mounting surface.

  It took some tweaking of the in-game settings to get it JUST right, so that was a little homework. (When doing this homework, you may come across sim racing snobs who claim this wheel sucks especially with horizon 4. Dont listen to them). Once I got all the settings dialed in this wheel works fantastic.

  Racing games are suddenly 10 times more enjoyable and immersive. You have infinitely more control over your vehicle, and it's SO rewarding once you tackle the learning curve.

  Build quality is EXTREMELY solid. Real steel wheel and pedals, real leather wrapped wheel (and yes it smells like new leather, it ain't fake) ...the plastic parts are heavy and dense. Premium feel and looks. This thing is built like a tank, and can generate violent feedback. I have actually dramatically turned down force feedback and vibration. It was almost too strong, so dont worry about some sissy ass feedback. These units are known for rock solid reliability and longevity and I'm pretty sure they have a 2 year warranty. It's also future proof if you are married to Game Pass Ultimate...as this WILL be compatible when "Xbox 2" (Project Scarlett) releases. The unit is just well engineered all the way around, so it will last for years.

Bottom line:
It is plug and play, but you will increase your enjoyment by setting up your wheel preferences in-game. If you can get this for less than $200, and have always wanted a wheel, pull the trigger. Lifes short, buy something nice for yourself! Because you will get hundreds, if not thousands of hours of enjoyment out of this little investment and driving games will take on a whole new dimension. I wholeheartedly recommend this product.

author: Jim Joe
title: Could be better, but not bad for $200
content:
For $200 it's a fair price. There are a few caveats:

1) the brake pedal is awful. Just terrible. Not even remotely realistic, I would have rather had no resistance at all over their idea of what brake pedals feel like.

Furthermore the insanely stiff spring does not allow the pedal to be depressed past the 40/100 mark, even standing on it. This means, out of the possible 256 brake positions (8-bit), you only actually have access to about 110 of them. This can negatively affect your braking ability quite a bit if you play any racing games that require skill (if you play arcade racers without any intelligence, like Forza Horizon, you'll be fine)

2) the force feedback is bonkers and will send you flying all over the track. I turned it back to 30/100 which still gives feedback but doesn't screw with your line. Completely and utterly unrealistic. Not even close! Do they not test these things out with actual drivers before-hand??

3) without a dedicated racing seat setup you'll be in pain after minutes.  A racing seat setup that positions the pedals in a sensible position is a must. Whoever designed the regular pedal position..... Quit your job please.

4) if you're not going to make it wireless, it NEEDS more than a 4ft USB cable. 10ft minimum!

author: K. Claffy
title: Logitech G29 Racing Wheel
content: This took a while for my son to get set up and working with more than 1 game, but overall he likes it.

author: Sandra T.
title: Used
content: Didn’t work

author: David
title: This was such a let down
content: I had built this up so much in my head and was just disappointed when it came in. The clamps wouldn't expand enough to attach it to my computer desk so I had to use it on a TV tray in the living room with my Xbox. The USB cable is short for a device like this in today's world if large TV's. When I attached a USB extension it wouldn't power up, tried another with the same results. When I did get it working it was a good experience. But the shortcomings bring this down A LOT. I ended up returning it.

author: Jordan
title: Four Stars

author: Austin Hester
title: Received Broken
content: It's a good wheel, but on the very first day of owning this G920 the right flappy paddle stopped working. Very disappointing and I would expect much better given all the good reviews. It was a great wheel for about 5 hours until it stopped functioning properly. And No, it's not a software issue or a PC issue, it seems to be a connection issue within the wheel itself.

author: Michael Huynh
title: I am impressed.
content: My son loves it, I started playing video game now too.

author: Stucazzo

author: rowdy yates
title: Great
content: Great controls.  Takes a little getting use to after using controller only.  Once learned it is real time.  Grandson, age 15, loves it.  As with younger generation using the paddle shifters.  A little confusing getting all the options adjusted - not the product's issues, just getting use to tons of options!

author: Romero
title: A worthy upgrade to my Driving Force GT. Works great with Gran Turismo 5.
content:
I'm not going to comment how this compares to the G27. I've never owned the G27, unfortunately, so it wouldn't be a fair comparison. I also don't own a PS4, so all on which I had to test this was a PS3. I don't own too many racing games compatible with this. Besides some demos, the only racing game I own in full is Gran Turismo 5 XL Edition.

That said, this review will be based upon my limited resources, but I thought I'd give this review as an offering to those who may be in a similar position as me, and who still would like to consider purchasing this $400 driving wheel over others.

Out of the box, this set looks gorgeous. My color schemes at home are black with blue, so the G29 already sucked me in, even if it is a supposedly redecorated G27.

When in first use it would squeak a little when turning but that has gone and I have seen others with the same problem but it goes away. The response is absolutely perfect. author: Jeff H
title: pretty much yeah
content:
Received my G920 last night, hooked it up, fired up Forza 7 and took my Civic out for a spin. Coming into the first corner of my first race, pushed the brake down until it started pushing back and went straight into the wall. Huh?

Rewound the race to start again, pressed the brake harder this time and BAM! Same thing. Straight into the wall. I know this is a FWD car and you can't really brake and turn but...what?

I looked for brake adjustments in the game and there are none. I decided to see what would happen if I pushed the brake as hard as possible. What happened was the entire pedal assembly rose up off the floor. Oops...that's not going to work. Tried again, pushing as hard as I could without mangling the entire setup, and this time I slowed the car and turn. "Do I really have to do that every single time?" Unless you're going uphill, pretty much yeah. That's how you brake with this thing and it's ridiculous.

So I did some searches online today and lo and behold, there are videos showing how to take apart your brand new $300+ wheel and remove a rubber part that makes braking virtually impossible.

I decided that, instead of taking the thing apart, I would try mashing the brake pedal down as hard as I could about 50 times to see what would happen. Sure enough, it felt a little bit closer to a real brake and I was starting to make normal turns. But it still takes too much attention away from actual driving. It sucks, basically. Finally today I just quit and figured I needed to do something. For me it's virtually unusable and definitely no fun out of the box.

Lastly, the comments about the D-Pad are true. Sometimes left is up, up is right, right is down, down is left. Keep a real controller handy.

After I "fix" my brand new $300 wheel, I'll update this and we'll see if the stars go up or down. Not sure if I'll go home and get a glutes workout by mashing the brake another few hundred times or if I'll take the rubber piece out. Kinda don't want to take it apart.

Bottom line... if you buy this wheel, plan on "fixing" it per the youtube videos.

Other than that, the wheel is great. It's a great size, even for someone large (I'm 6'3" and wear XXL gloves), and the pedals work great. author: Kizmotek
title: Steering wheel is really good for the price, brake pedal needs to be modded....
content: The steering wheel is really high quality and the force feedback is great, only complaint about the wheel is that its too small but its as good as it will get for the price. The pedals are also nice and high quality... Except for the brake pedal, its not low quality or anything but there is this pointless rubber piece inside of the spring that makes it literally impossible to press down on the breaks all the way and this doesnt translate well in games, I have to stand on the brake pedal for it to get pressed down all the way.... However, once you take apart the pedals and remove the rubber piece, the brakes are actually fine and its still decently stiff. Not sure on why Logitech thought it would be a good idea to put a rubber piece if the pedal cant detect how hard you are pressing it, it can only detect how far you pressed the pedal. Do this at your own risk, there are very thin wires inside of the pedal attachment and you could easily rip them.

Hopefully the game support gets better. Can't use it on any of my older games. Very disappointed. I was expecting to plug it in and play my old and new games. Not happening.

author: oasisguy
title: Thrustmaster TMX PRO VS Logitech G920
content:
Wish I had done my research before purchasing. A few weeks after I bought this my brother bought the Thrustmaster TMX PRO which sells for basically the same price as this or less. After using his wheel I would definitely have bought that.

Both wheels  do not come with a shifter and both do have the clutch pedal and conical brake mod for more realistic braking feel. Yet on the TMX PRO the mod is easily installed or removed depending on your preference. On the Logitech it is permanently  installed and requires invasive action to remove which also voids the warranty. I like it though, it was a little too stiff at first but after about 30 hours of racing it has broken in and feels great.

Both wheels offer an optional shifter, and the Logitech one offers 4 things over the Thrustmaster's, push down reverse, alot quieter, very short throw, and a much lower price. The Thrustmaster one is over twice the price, but it feels better, is made mostly of metal and is harder to accidentally put in to the wrong gear. The Thrustmaster also has a separate gate plate that is included with it to make it a sequential shifter. This is excellent for rally driving where the paddle shifters can be difficult to use. It is however very squishy in sequential mode not having that nice positive click that a sequential shifter should have. Because of that I would not purchase it if you're mainly looking for a sequential shifter do to its poor feedback. Their are better dedicated options out there.

The pedals on the Logitech are 8 bit giving a total of 256 unique positions. This sounds like a lot, but when running F1 cars where braking needs to be incredibly precise the Thrustmaster 12 bit pedals with 4,096 unique positions are noticeably better. The Logitech pedals do grip the carpet better though and look nicer.

The wheel, the G920 is prettier by far. The all brushed metal construction with leather wrap looks good and feels good in the hand. The Thrustmaster is mostly plastic with some rubber grips at the 10 and 2 'o clock positions. It looks cheap and initially feels cheap too. It is however about a 1/4 inch larger than the Logitech and I like the slight increase in size.

Yet this is where the Thrustmaster runs away with the show for me. When actually driving with it the force feedback is noticeably better, its more precise and less notchy. I can't say it is in a whole other league over the Logitech, but it is better. The cheapness of the plastic wheel is all but forgotten from the excellent precision feel you get from the force feedback.

That being said the Logitech is not without its upsides like better looks and overall build quality. The wheel base does have bolt holes for hard mounting. Which is real nice when using it with a stand. The TMX PRO does not. The TMX PRO table mount does work well though, and it seems just fine with out the hard mount. It does however stick down alot and will interfere with your keyboard pull out when mounted to your desk. The Logitech uses dual soft mounts that don't stick down nearly as much.  Both wheel's pedal boxes and optional shifters do have bolt holes for hard mounting.

I've debated on adding this part since it is not coming from my own experience, but to help others make an informed purchasing decision I've decided to add it. From what I've read around the net, the TMX pro does have a higher failer rate. So if you are looking for something to last a long time the Logitech would probably be your better bet. Its dual motor gear force feedback system is antiquated and has been around since the G27 wheel which is why it doesn't feel quite as nice as it could. Yet it is a proven system with many G27 wheels still in use today. I'm just speculating, but I think this may be why Logitech has chosen not to update it just because it has proven to be so reliable.

author: anifowose hussein
title: Feels like Hamilton!
content: So I did a lot of research before purchasing this and I must say it was my best gift to myself in 2018. Once I had successfully adjusted my steering sensitivities on F1 2018, Forza Motorsport 7, Forza Horizon 4, it felt so real!. I am still working on a proper setup for Driveclub. Advice: do not give up on this wheel on initial setup. Go online and check for forums with discussions about settings for a specific game and adjust according to your driving style. I have only used it for a week, so I cannot give any rating on durability but so far, IT IS AMAZING! SOMEBODY HELP!!! I have refused to get up from my Forza Motorsport 7!!!! LOOOOL.

author: Milton Poston
title: G29 and PS3
content:
Purchased this wheel to use with the PS3 system and GT6.
The wheel is not recognized by the system like previous Logitech wheels or Thrustmaster wheels.
Dead zone is wide until you start to race then it tightens up. This may change if the wheel is added.
Force feed back is almost non existent on flat tracks, excessive on dirt tracks.
Results may be better on PS4 system. I do like the pedals and build quality of the wheel.

author: TornadoTwistar
title: Faulty Potentiometers on the Pedals
content:
I've had my G920 for over 2 years and in my time I've only used it for iRacing...it has some very bad potentiometers on all 3 of the pedals to the point that I find myself taking apart the potentiometers to clean them 2 or 3 times a year (mostly the gas and brake pedals that are faulty).

For the wheel itself, I've not had any problems with it on my PC and it works how it should input and mapping wise when using it for iRacing.

While Logitech has a decent gaming mouse and keyboard hardware selection, their racing wheels IMO are just hot-garbo to the point that I won't be using Logitech for a racing wheel.

author: Christine Anderson

author: Robert A Carpenter
title: One Star
content: Very poor instructions in box.  It get's a poor rating until I sort it out.

author: Amazon Customer
title: This feel nothing like an actual steering wheel.
content:
First off it turns out the support for this wheel isn't that great for many games, like Gran Turismo 5. Imagine loosing front end traction and going off track and getting 0 feedback from the wheel. Not what I was expecting.

Second, Omg. It feels like you're driving with a ratchet. You literally feel EVERY tooth in the gear that's providing the resistance. Because of this, it's not smooth at all, you feel it move in steps, so the force feedback isn't smooth or progressive, and then you get some loud pops which I'm assuming is a tooth slipping.

Then the build quality.. Everything else was OK except, 1) The paddles, made of plastic and the pull feels so rubbery, if it wasn't for the 'click' you'd have no idea where the engagement point is. 2) The red dial.. feels like cheapest and thinnest bit of plastic, it feels soooo brittle.

For the high price tag, more than the console and game, I was expecting this to live up to what it advertised but it fell soo far short.

author: Justin
title: Excellent Unit
content: The wheel works great, clamps are very strong and the clamp locking system is excellent. However, while the wheel does “plug and play”, you should install the Logitech control app so you can customize the wheel to user preference. In the case of Forza Horizon 4 (first game I used it on), it required a bit of fine tuning (YouTube was a good resource for finding a baseline), however more “serious” racing sims might not be as bad. Only problem with the pedals is the overall size, they are generally easier to use without shoes/footwear on, as the clutch and break are rather close, but this is a minor problem. Overall, the unit was easy to install, and is a decent racing wheel for the race enthusiast on a budget.

author: mark
title: Buyer Beware
content: For the price you pay the wheel n pedals are nice BUT... There is no where to hook up your headset. Tried plugging my headset into a controller and using the wheel and there is a conflict between the two.not all functions work on the wheel. Tried playing 2 player split screen on forza 6 n you cant . the wireless controllers wont work .does this thing need an update ??? Know i have to lay out another 300 for a wireless headset . thanks logitech

author: Ml

author: Tyler Bergthold
title: Great value, great quality
content: The wheel is great quality and the force feedback is very good, though it does give an uncanny valley sort of effect. The pedals are good quality and while the brake pedal may be a little stiff, it allows for faster maximum braking. The wheel was also fairly priced. The gear shifter is also a nice addition.

author: John Buczynski
title: Excellent steering wheel and pedal set!
content:
As my first steering wheel, I purchased this mainly for GT Sport and F1 on PS4.
First, the build quality is very very good. The wheel leather quality is great, to the point it’s nicer than many cars I’ve been in. Assembly and connections were straightforward.
For GT Sport, it does it’s job. The level of play is now to a greater depth with the precision this wheel allows. It opened up the game for me and I thoroughly enjoy it after months of near daily use. The pedals have a solid feel to them and durable, hence the metal. The throttle and brake pedals have different resistances between them, which may or may not be beneficial, depending on what you’re used to. The only irk I have is sometimes the red adjustment knob doesn’t work immediately when you’re driving around a track - it’ll sometimes work immediately, sometimes it will not and then be overly sensitive, which can be critical in some races. Don’t let this small detail deter you from buying this steering wheel set.
The force feedback has good strength and has actually aided me in bettering my autocross driving as a result of practice and feel in a game. In the F1 2018 game, the wheel vibrates and knocks like crazy down a straightaway - not sure if the system is trying to process a lot at once and combats itself, leading to vibrations. However, I think these are more game programming items than build quality of this wheel. Overall, an excellent wheel.

author: Benito Huerta
title: Very satisfied.
content: Works great, very responsive and quite sturdy. All metal sure to last a long time.

author: Carlos Q.
title: Very cool.
content: Cool gadget!!!!

author: SemiSecure
title: Feels great
content:
I have about 20 hours on this wheel, so not too much yet.  It feels great and durable.  The mechanism for resistance when turning feels good as well.  All buttons and paddles feel like quality as well.

There are comments about the brake sucking.  Those people are very wrong.  The brake is great, you just need to adjust settings in your game to get it to the feel you like.  I had no issue with the brake once I spent 5 minutes tweaking the settings in Forza 7.

Was sad to find the shift lights don’t work by default on pc and are very difficult to make work, but oh well.
Has worked without fail for me. However, when it hasn’t been used for any period of time, it makes a high pitched squealing noise when turning it to the left that gets quieter with use and eventually goes away. Thought something may have been wrong but looks like it’s a common thing. Doesn’t bother me though with game audio going
Overall, would recommend the product.

So this is a great wheel, problems with it is that it now combines a driver which personally I like and dislike, in some games there are bugs or something is wrong but when I tried to use it in American Truck Simulator and Euro Truck Simulator 2, the part where i can adjust the "force feed back gain" didn't agree so much.... I'm not sure if this is a bug or I got a defective or even if it isn't supposed to be used on the G920 but when I was a G27 user this wasn't a problem what so ever.
Another thing I found weird is that the shifter from the G27 works for shifting but the buttons on it aren't programable... This is a bummer since I wanted more buttons and I was hoping that this was a "loophole" that would allow me to use it and program it with more buttons.
Honestly I would get this wheel for its looks and upgrade, but if I was to choose between the G920,G29, the G27 or even the G25 I'd be smart and get the G27 even though it's now discontinued/ over priced....

Pros:
-It looks great
-It's a slight upgrade from G27
-It has a "XBox Controller" on it disregarding the triggers and joysticks
-It looks like a race car's wheel mounted on a plastic box with motors in it

Cons:
-Compatibility issues
-DOESN'T COME WITH A SHIFTER (and if you get the G27 or use the G25 shifter, in certain games it just doesn't want to be mapped)
-IT'S EXPENSIVE at $300-$400+ I'd honestly just save up and just literally get the G27... or worse comes worse get the T500RS by Thrustmaster....

What I paid to get this M3H it's okay, it's not the end of the world, thought despite that I hope logitech would be a bit more reasonable since I personally like a wheel along with good pedals that doesn't have a rubber stop and a shifter that has programable buttons on it and also lastly a wheel that is circular, but despite that this wheel works rather well on the XBOX so I would give it a star for that so I guess 3.5 stars even though it doesn't show...
