author: V. Hutson
title: Fantastic!
content:
My son loves this!  After using it for a day we also purchased the shifter--which really adds to the fun.

To really enjoy all of the features of the wheel (shifting, clutch, etc.) you need to have a PS4 game that has these features.  Unfortunately, there are currently only 2 PS4  games that do--Project CARS and DriveClub.  I bought both of these games as well--and I'm happy I did.  The driving experience is great.

The wheel provides feedback that feels very much like real driving.  In fact, it seems so real at first that when you crash--it is physically shocking!  The foot pedals are heavy enough that they don't slide around.  We attached the wheel to a wooden desk that works reasonably well. It works great when only the wheel is used.  However, once we started using the shifter with the PS4 games the desk tends to move around a bit.  Perhaps I just need to shift with less force--but when you're in these games the adrenaline can really start to flow and I'm shifting like a madwoman!

Bottom line is this is a fantastic (and expensive wheel) if you have the PS4 games that support it.  I recommend buying the shifter as well.  My fingers are crossed that this will work with the next PS5 console!

author: Ian B
title: Great wheel when it’s on sale.
content:
I’ve had this on my wish list for a while and when it went on sale I had to jump on it. This is a sub-$200 controller and is overpriced when not on sale.

While the build quality is very good, the materials used - and subsequently the cables included, are sub-optimal at best. The leather is especially cheap and ill-fitted in some spots.

It seems no matter what your setup is, the main USB cable isn’t quite long enough and requires an extension to prevent a clothesline situation between your wheel and console. Same issue with the power cable. It is simply not long enough to use without an extension.

The included wire management is adequate but is really ineffective if you don’t have the wheel mounted to a Playseat-style bracket. If you’ve got this clamped down to a table, chances are you’ve also got some cable management issues.

As far as how the wheel works, it is plug-and-play for console and PC, though PC users get the option of software fine-tuning for the best experience.

The wheel itself is nice enough to hold on to, but the switches/buttons feel very cheap and the paddles, while they are metal and large in size, have an unpleasant feel around the edges and have a mushy travel that results in less-than-satisfying gear changes.

The pedals are decent. Spacing is a bit too close for the sake of being compact, but is only a problem for big feet I suppose. The pedals need to be mounted to a bracket, otherwise they are pretty useless. The very aggressive carpet grip on the bottom plate can prevent them from moving under pressure, but there’s NO WAY you aren’t going to destroy your carpets after few uses. The brake pedal is progressively difficult to depress, in an effort to mimic real brake pressure, but it is just too stiff. If a game doesn’t allow for adjusting dead zones, you’ll never be able to reach 100% activation of the axis without standing on the pedal.

For the standard price it should definitely include the novelty gear shift. A clutch pedal with paddle shifters is so unintuitive and is really more about bragging rights to say your controller has a dedicated clutch.  If you don’t also have the gear shifter then it is unlikely you’ll ever use the clutch.

Overall, I enjoy this controller because I bought it on sale.

I did pay $252 for my G25 and after a very long search, ran across this G920 for $300, including pedals!  Great price for a quality product.  All metal wheel and pedals. No plastic feel. And truly believe I will get another 8 years out of this one.  In my opinion, Logitech is the standard for PC wheels. Setups nice and great quality. Highly recommend ESPECIALLY at the price I paid.

author: Chase
title: I just got this g920 and unboxing was great; quality
content:
I just got this g920 and unboxing was great; quality, appearance, feel, the works. I'm using on a PC so configuration is different (and why I gave 4 stars). I haven't found a whole lot on setup process in the box or just in general, although just enough to get it working.

For those using PC this is what I've gathered. Go to the Logitech website and look up your model, download the software and firmware update, run the software and select a racing profile, map it to the game, open game (install game before creating profile, it will recognize installed games on Windows 10, Windows 7 users may have to use installed folder paths to game exe root, and idk about 8 users you're on your own lol). ! Reboot ! It's never a bad idea, even if I sound like tech support "have you tried turning it off and back on again?". Open game and go to control settings and make sure the input and buttons are set to the controls not the key board. At that point if it doesn't work, reboot with updates, if selectable, confirm all settings in software and game again. That should be about it. I might do a video in case other people are having issues, like the comment if interested

author: Amazon Customer
title: FM6 settings and review for G920
content:
I have had my G920 wheel for 11 months now and have logged about 33,xxx miles on Forza Motorsports 6 with it.  It is a great product but it does require some common sense to get it properly configured for optimal operations.  The brake pedal is stiff, which is great however it needs to be compensated for by adjusting your in game settings.  On FM6 I run my deceleration outside dead zone at 70 and it works phenomenally.

The remainder of your settings are personal preference, but I will post them here to help others.  To get to these settings on FM6 you need to go to: Options: Controls: Advanced wheel controls (by pressing X button in controls menu)

Steering:
inside deadzone =1
outside deadzone = 100
Acceleration :
Inside deadzone = 0
Outside deadzone = 100
Deceleration
Inside deadzone = 0
Outside deadzone = 70
Clutch
Inside deadzone = 10
Outside deadzone = 50
Hand Brake
inside deadzone = 0
outside deadzone = 50
Vibration scale = 50
Force Feedback scale = 100
Degrees of rotation = 420 (again personal preference)

In game I run Normal Steering.  I find Sim steering very challenging and hard to predict and catch power on oversteer.
The remainder of assists are all off.

***WHEN DRIFTING TURN VIBRATION TO 0***  I had to send my first wheel back to logitech for warranty after 3 months.  I suspect this is due to running a vibration setting when drifting and the wheel was constantly vibrating.  It would get warm and I believe it shook it self apart.  I have been drifting on 0 vibration for 6 months now with no issues.  T

The logitech warranty process was very straightforward and they were easy to deal with.

author: AmazonBuyer
title: good wheel from logitech with some noticeable flaws...
content:
I was extremely excited to try the G920, as I've been playing a lot of Forza 6 since release. I received it one day after release, having preordered it. I'm actually going to be returning it after a week of trial and looking to a different brand, as I feel that are a couple of fundamental flaws that don't belong in a $400 product. These views are after several hours of use in Forza 6 and Forza Horizon 2 on Xbox One.

First, the brake 'feature.' The amount of force required to press the brake is so great that I was deflecting the heavy-gauge plate steel on my openwheeler racing seat setup about an inch, and not registering more than 55% press. Thus, I had to set the max to 55 in my game settings. This isn't a realistic feel at all, unless you're trying to duplicate the feel of cable-pull brakes from the early 20th century. I also don't like that I am losing a ton of resolution by having to set the range so low, and on top of that, you're only really guessing where the brake bottoms out. It's a huge issue, in my opinion.

Second, the center deadzone. I read and watched every review I could before purchasing this wheel, and they all said something to the effect of 'it has a deadzone, just like all helical gear wheels do.' Having never owned a racing wheel before, I figured that it was no big deal as it was written off so casually. That's completely false. This is the best way I can explain it - if you drive a modern car on a freeway, and you're on a freeway (60+mph) curve, you'll be turning your steering wheel and operating your car completely capably at about 1/3 of the deadzone this wheel has. This leads to very little feel on high-speed curves, and I constantly was fishtailing on straights after curves until I set a center deadzone in my game settings. A quality piece of equipment should not necessitate this, in my opinion.

A minor nag - the white LED is extremely bright, and in your face if you look at the wheel itself. Not an issue while you're playing, but any time you look at the buttons to navigate menus, or if you're in a darkened room, it's really annoying.

The good stuff:

The construction quality is top-notch. All of the materials are very nice and the setup has a superb fit and finish. It's a very nice looking setup, and it feels good to use. The paddle shifters have a satisfying click and travel.

Packaging and setup are great - just a few unsealed bags and twist ties to go through. The clamps to hold the wheel on seem to work very well.

There's a USB quick-release on the cord, so you can leave the plug in your xbox if you need to disconnect the wheel. This leaves a very short cable hanging out, which is very convenient.

I wish I could recommend this product, but I can't. The flaws are just too much to overcome for me.

author: xchrisp

I unpacked and set it up on a folding table (just to try it), I love the steering wheel and it's feedback, you end up really fighting the steering column!  It reminds me of an old school bus I drove across country without power steering.  You will have strong arms playing this over time.  I really like the paddle wheels which I use for shifting.  My biggest complaint is that the brake peddle doesn't work much at all until you have your whole weight pressed on it.  To get it to work in reverse with the peddle you have to really stand on it.  I am looking for adjustments in the settings but nothing seems to improve it.  Not sure what to think yet as it effects my game playing abilities.

author: Dave
title: A really great wheel for the price.  Excellent for Xbox One, requires some help on the PC.
content:
This is a really good wheel for the xbox one.  The force feedback isn't as strong as other wheels for the xbox one, but you won't find those other wheels at this price point.

The pedals are amazing.  The brake pressure is a little high and I had to tweak it down in game.  But after that it was great.

The shifter addon works as described if you purchased it with it.  The floppy paddles are real metal.  Everything feels great with this wheel.

Why only 4 stars?  There are still some serious issues if you try to use this wheel on the PC.  Unlike other Logitech wheels in the past, they haven't updated the profiler to work with this wheel 100%.  You'll have some games that don't support the force feedback but does on other Logitech wheels.  You'll have others that read the pedals incorrectly.  Some will have the dead-zone off.  It is a bit of a hassle to get it going on games that don't support it properly.

Its my first force-feedback wheel so i can't say much out of my experience so far, but its been really nice, the reaction time is really good and the feedback is really strong.
The construction is top quality, doesn't look like a toy, the pedals are really good too and the feel is great, looking forward to buy the shifter.

author: Chen Gao
title: Perfect as your first gaming wheel
content:
This is my first gaming wheel, so I can't compare it to others, but it's much better than playing games with keyboards or controllers. The feedback feels quite real, when you drive through speed bumps or kerbs the wheel shakes accordingly, when you lose control it rotates like crazy. It's simply amazing for a starter.

The point of a gaming wheel is to have better car control and a more realistic experience, so it works better for track racing games like GT Sports, not street racing games like  NFS Payback. The latter one is actually better with keyboards.

A few drawbacks:
1. the break paddle is a bit stiff so you really need to fix your chair. I tied my chair to the table with some ropes, which seems a bit silly.
2. there's no cooling system so if you play for too long, the wheel actually overheats.

author: John Anselmo
title: Boogity Boogity
content: Incredibly realistic. Steering is precise and feedback is quite accurate. Braking takes effort, so if you come in hot, be prepared to stand on em

author: Enjoying Life
title: Not worth it!!!!
content:
Bought this wheel to replace my Logitech G25 that I have been using since it first came out.  I primarily play Project Cars 2 and Assetto Corsa on the PC using VR.  I decided to purchase this wheel because I wanted to try it out with my Xbox One X for the Forza games, as well as hopefully enjoy a better ffb wheel for my PC2 and AC games on my PC.

First impressions:  the ffb was actually worse than the G25.  The wheel had no 'weight' to it when driving.  Eventually I found that I had to inscrease the center spring strength.  But then the problems started happening.

The Good:  The wheel feels great, with good material.  The pedals are decent in that you can move the throttle pedal over to improve the heel/toe.  The brake pedal has some stiffness to it to add realism.  The XBox style buttons on the wheel can be programmed on the PC.

The Bad:  I bought the new shifter for this wheel as well, but it doesn't have as nice of a feel as the G25 shifter. Also, the buttons on the shifter were useful, but this shifter does not have them.  The experience with the XBox wasn't that great, as the FFB was underwhelming, and I would hardly feel any vibrations from spinning tires or driving over rumble strips.  I had expected this wheel to have a stronger FFB than my G25, but that is NOT true.

The Ugly:  The reason why I gave this wheel 1 star.  I installed the Logitech G Hub software on my PC to run this wheel setup.  It doesn't work.  The wheel won't properly calibrate to the right.  If you center it and move a mm to the right, the software immediately goes full right on the calibration.  There is no gradual movement, just an IMMEDIATE right.
After uninstalling the Logitech G Hub, I used the Logitech software recommended for this wheel.  THAT fixed the problem... but now causes another problem.
When racing, if you turn the wheel too quickly through a turn, such as trying to keep from losing control in a corner... the wheel suddenly goes off center for the remainder of the game.  At first, I thought maybe I damaged the car in-game and my wheel alignment was off... but sure enough the graphic display of my VR wheel did NOT match the same position as my Logitech wheel.
This happens ALL THE TIME.  The wheel is absolutely useless when playing.  I contacted Logitech Tech Support and I am simply referred to the online support section.
Logitech SHOULD FIX THIS PROBLEM WITH A FIRMWARE UPDATE but for whatever reason, they have stopped updating this wheel.
STAY AWAY FROM THIS WHEEL!!!  My 15 year old Logitech G25 STILL is better than this POS!

Overall I'm really happy with this purchase!

author: gtc
title: Better than a controller, but bottom of the pile for wheels
content:
I'm really conflicted on this wheel. During the 360 era I was fortunate enough to get a Fanatec CSR and ditch the old plastic Microsoft wireless wheel. The CSR really ruined me on what kind of performance to expect for the price, as it was a stellar deal at around $400 (for the bundle). Since Fanatec can't seem to cater to that kind of market anymore, I had to settle for either the Thrustmaster or this. The G920 went on sale so that won out.

It's... okay. Certainly better than the old Microsoft wheel, but after comparing it to the build quality of Fanatec I'm left wanting. The force feedback is weak, and most times I barely register that it exists. The actual input feels so disconnected and twitchy that I can't even drift with this thing and spin cars out way too easily. I do hear a lot of people complain about the brake pedal stiffness, but that's one of the few things I actually LIKE. Brakes are not supposed to bottom out, people. Bleed your lines. Having some resistance makes it a lot easier to hit that locking threshold and stop faster.

All in all... if this is the ONLY thing you can afford, buy it I guess. It's better than using a controller. I'm seriously considering returning this and just paying triple for the new Fanatec CSL.

Four stars because of price, five star experience.

author: Joshep Marcus
title: Review from a sim enthusiast
content:
I placed an order on Sept. 24 and arrived on Sept. 26. First, I'm leaving a product review from an sim enthusiast point of view. This is not my only Logitech wheel, now on to the testament.

I've owned logitech wheels for many years and still, to this day they are still functional. Not only are they reliable but they can be customisable and fun.

This Logitech G29 for PS4 and PC feels alot like the G27 but a bit improved. It feels good and it's very quiet compared to it's predecessors. When Force Feedback kicks in it rattles but not as much as the G25 and G27, the gears feel somewhat pleasurable when taking corners.

Pedals are way better than the G25 and G27, but not as much as the Thrustmaster t3pa pedals or the Fanatec Clubsports pedals. Clutch feels like a modern clutch, brakes feel alittle like in real life but requires mods to make it feel premium, gas pedal feels perfect. All in all it's worth the upgrade from the G25 or G27 pedals.

Shifter, i cannot testify if it is better then the old ones since i'm using the G27's shifter. G27 H shifter is compatible with the G29, but the extra buttons won't work but that's okay with me. I have not tested the G25 H and sequential shifter on the G29 but i'm sure it'll work.

The Paddle shifters click louder on the G29 and feels alittle heavy, not much improvement here. They are very responsive and sturdy, it will take a hammer to break them.

Pros:
Better handling wheel
Extra buttons on the steering wheel (you don't have to use a controller)
Leather wrapped steering wheel
Overall better pedals then its predecessors
Included are clutch, brake and gas brushed aluminum pedals
Wheel, paddle shifters and pedals feel sturdy
Dual gear Force Feedback motors
Best wheel for the money
Overall very reliable product and easy to maintain

Cons:
A little deadzone but not that noticeable
Small wheel rim
Gear motors (most of the time the Force Feedback feels unrealistic and it clunks)
Feels plastique

Judge for yourself, the pros outweighs the cons, but that's just my personal opinion. If you're on a budget and want a very ready to race and reliable wheel, and you are either a Sim enthusiast or game a lot this is the best option out there. If money is not the problem you should consider other hardcore brands, but make sure to get a warranty as premium wheels will break more often than the Logitechs. Overall (i know, i've used this word way too much) I'm very happy and satisfied with my purchase and this wheel completed my setup for GT Sport, Assetto Corsa, Project Cars 2 and so on. I truly recommend this wheel, it will last you for a very long time, just like my old DF, G25 and G27s.

author: John T.
title: If the hardware issue is known, then why don't they fix it before selling it?
content:
Pile of garbage...  turning the wheel left or right triggers about half of the buttons.  Apparently Logitech's QC was piss-poor when it came to this product.  I figured I'd check their forums for a solution.  Well, it's a known hardware defect.  No use of them recalling the unsold products to fix them before putting them back on the market.  Just sell it and let the consumer waste time and money to send the broken device back and have them refurbish it.  It's a shame too, Logitech wheels have always been good to me.

Granted, not every G29 has this issue, but let it be known: you are taking a risk when purchasing this product.  The odds are that you will get a lemon.

author: Josh
title: Worth it
content:
Great product so far. I love the feel of the leather (or leather-ish) wheel material, and the aluminum paddles and pedals. The mounting clamps work quite well, although I did end up getting a stand so I have a little more control over positioning. Also nice that it has 3 pedals, so I don't have to replace those in addition to buying a shifter if/when I decide to go full manual.

Force feedback seems quite good, although it depends on the game. Forza 6 is kind of "meh" - I still think that game works better on a controller. However, Dirt Rally feels incredible. It's so good, I honestly think this was worth the purchase for that one game alone. Controller steering was always a little wonky in that game, but this has made it a great experience.

content: I wish I didn't have to buy this. I have a perfectly good G27 that is not compatible with the PS4 for seemingly no good reason. Beyond that, this wheel technically functions just fine. The break pedal is as stiff as everyone says, but it's not a deal breaker for me. For me, the real issue was the decision to sell the shifter separate and put ALL the buttons on the wheel itself. This is a problem because it can't be very difficult to locate the necessary button during a race while the wheel is being turned left and right to control a vehicle, ESPECIALLY if you do drifting at all.... get used to not having an e-brake. So overall the wheel functions fine, I wish the shifter was included and the buttons were on the shifter but that's my personal preference.

author: snowbro6
title: Not quite what I expected, but still good
content: This is primarily a review for PC racing games. I tried using it for PS4 but I wasn't willing to buy the extra stand. I found the overall build of the wheel to be very sturdy. I was very impressed by the pedals which are themselves mostly metal. I also appreciate the extra carpet spikes on the bottom of the pedal stand that keep it from moving. The pedals also have a progressive feel that is very similar to real brakes. My main problem with the wheel is the feeling of the gears inside the wheel that provide the force feedback. When you first play something like Assetto Corsa, the feedback is intense to the point where it shakes the wheel when centered. What results is a jarring grinding feel as the wheel shifts back and forth. I highly recommend dialing the force feedback down to make it feel more like a real car. Overall, I expected a more fluid motion in the wheel when driving. Then again I'm not really disappointed, I've been able to use the wheel in multiple games and it has enhanced the experience over the typical controller.

author: Miranda Hartlage
title: Two Stars
content: I received my Logitech G920 two days ago. The wheel is nicely packed and protected for shipping and convenience. After setting up it up, took about 30 minutes, I began to play FH3 and ATS. I immediately noticed 2 major problems and 1 small. Small - When not actually in a vehicle (Still in game, just not driving) the wheel centers normal.... until you turn it to the left of the center, and then it locks all the way left. Turn it back past the center to the right, and it centers fine. Major - 1. When turning the wheel back to the center (drifting, just turning fast, etc) faster than the wheel is set to auto center, the wheel starts clicking/snapping and locks and unlocks. This is really annoying when playing at night, as the wheel is usually really quiet, but that quickly changes. 2. In game when going STRAIGHT the wheel goes back and forth over and over again until YOU perfectly center it... Put it barely to the right again, and she starts again. This is SUPER annoying, this means its almost impossible to drive in a straight line. On top of all this the logitech settings are 99% useless. I noticed no difference when turning up/down the sensitivity on the wheels, as I was trying to fix the brake peddle, which is like pushing a boulder. Also unlike my TMX Thrustmaster FFB wheel, the wheel settings don't actually allow you to adjust the force of the force feedback. Therefor making you use in game settings to adjust it. This is USELESS because in most games (Forza Horizon 3/Forza Motorsports 7) THERE ISNT A FORCE FEEDBACK CONTROL AT ALL! I asked a question 2 days ago and it still hasnt been answered, although i canceled it and filed a warranty claim to replace it.

author: Henderson
title: I am very happy with this wheel
content: I received my G29 yesterday and immediately plugged it into my PS4 ans started playing Project Cars.  I am very happy with this wheel.  I had a Driving Force GT for years, and it is still going strong. I gave it to my daughter's boyfriend.  Although I never owned a G27, I am certain this is an improvement.  They have stiffened up the pedals and the wheel shifters to give it a more authentic feel.  I actually have to put my weight down on the break to get full breaks applied, much like a real car.  This gives you more realistic and precise breaking.  The clutch, which I have not used yet as I am waiting on the shifter has a nice medium spring load which feels good as does the gas pedal.  The wheel is smooth and quiet with virtually no dead zone.  I have yet to adjust any setting in the game, and I don't think I will need to.  The buttons are all programmable within Project Cars, including the dial which can be used as two buttons, one clockwise, and the other counter clockwise.  This really has all of the positive attributes of the Driving Force GT and the G27 as well as some additional improvements.  It is likely to be as reliable as both previous wheels which is why I chose this over the Thrustmaster.  If I were to suggest an improvement it would be to make the wheel larger, but it ultimately does not detract from the experience, so no deduction in points on that.  A+

author: Germo
title: Five Stars
content: Love this new wheel. works great with project cars 2.

author: mcgeehe
title: Best jump off point. 2 year review
content:
You can't go wrong with this wheel if you're just starting out in sim racing. These Logitech wheels are known to last forever. I've owned mine for almost 2 years now and it gets used a lot and still works like new. During long play sessions the motor will start to get pretty warm, but I've never had it shut down or lose FFB strength. You will want to get some leather conditioner to keep the wheel (yes, it's genuine) from drying out over the years. Also, the pedals are REALLY good, you can easily use them until they quit or you want to shell out for some really expensive ones. I plan on using them with a Fanatech CSL in a few more years.

GT Sport has the best FFB profile I've used so far, that game really makes this wheel shine. I highly recommend playing either GT Sport or GT6 with this wheel first. Project Cars 2 also feels really good, you just need to tune the wheel settings first. For PC2 use Jack Spade's profile (PC only) and then follow a tuning guide to get no clipping, if you're on PS4 just tune for no clipping.

This is a great first wheel, you really get a lot of FFB for the price and the peace of mind knowing that it's probably going to outlast your NEXT wheel. From here I'd move onto a T500 or a Fanatech CSL and keep the G29 as a solid back up in the event of repairs being needed.

Best of luck. (don't buy the extra sifter, you probably won't use it)

author: jon
title: Dont worry about the brake pedal!
content:
I dont know what other wheels some of these reviewers are talking about.  I just purchased the g29 for my return to online sim racing.  I was made very nervous by all the negative reviews talking specifically about the brake pedal.  It's stiff yes.  It should be.  I think it feels great both on ovals and on road courses.  I felt compelled to write this just so people aren't turned away by these overly negative reviews.  Iracing was completely plug n play...I came from an old school logitech momo wheel that had tons of issues on launch with sensitivity ect.  This was a dream in comparison.  Also a huge improvement in the overall feel and accuracy of the wheel.  My first race in the nascar monster series (after purchasing the car naturally) was a second place finish at talledega.

I always previously struggled with tracks like this with my previous wheel.  It was just nearly impossible for it to work with drafting...at least in the early years of its release.  I was able to tuck in behind and ride 30 laps at Talladega incident free (tho I saw plenty and had close calls) to a second place finish.  If the line had been 200 yards farther down the track I may have been able to get my nose ahead.

Anyways...dont be scared by the negative reviews. The wheel and pedals all work and feel great.

author: Dr. E
title: Problems on PC with many games
content:
I used this primarily for the PC and many of the "compatible" games have problems.  None of the pedals were mapped correctly. The brake pedal was the accelerator and the clutch was the brake. I downloaded the Logitech Gaming Software program to update the wheel which was supposed to fix many problems.  I tried to remap the pedals and the only options I could change were the wheel axis sensitivity and the wheel rotation degree.

The first game I tested was Crazy Taxi.  The game crashed whenever I loaded it with the wheel.  I did not mind this with as it was an old game and it did not state it was compatible with the wheel anyways.

I next tested Burnout Paradise.  I had to manually set up the controls from within the game which was no problem.  The pedals were still mapped incorrectly but the force feedback on the wheel worked.  Besides the incorrect pedals, I felt the controls were fluid. The wheel had a nice feel and the clamps that are built into the wheel kept it securely on my desk.

I then tested Project CARS.  Previously, there were problems including the incorrectly mapped pedals and no force feedback.  However, this has been fixed in patch 4.0 released by the Project CARS developers.  There are no complaints as I have never owned a driving wheel game controller before and my only experience is either in an arcade or driving a real car.

Before you purchase this, you should either use it exclusively for the Xbox One (as it seems there are no problems) or research if this wheel works with the games you want to play on the PC as it seems many other people had problems with a variety of other racing games.

author: William G.
title: A solid product, and a consumer-unfriendly release from Logitech.
content:
The Logitech G29 is one of the most frustrating products I've used in recent memory. Not that it's a bad product. It's not even slightly bad. It's just that, for some reason, Logitech has rested on its laurels and released what is essentially the EXACT same product as the G27. Now, bear in mind the G27 was released in 2009. Yes, 2009. Let's put that in perspective: The Logitech G27 was released the year before the ORIGINAL Apple iPad was released. Yep, it's that old.

And now, in 2015, Logitech is releasing the "exact" (mechanically) same steering wheel and pedals, for far MORE money, and with no shifter included anymore? What...?!

*In the interest of fairness - the button layout on the wheel is of course different from the G27, and the brake pedal has a rubber piece (Logitech calls it a damper) underneath which stiffens up the pedal. The damper under the brake pedal means you need to push quite a bit harder than on the G27. It will be interesting to see how that additional pressure affects longevity here. If you had trouble with the G27 pedals shifting around on your floor, the G29 will probably shift even more due to the additional pressure required to press the brake pedal. Bottom line: When driving around, the wheel is the same, and the pedals (minus a stiffer brake pedal) are the same.*

Now, this also means many (all) of my same criticisms of the Logitech G27 are still applicable. If you have the time, you can read my review of the Logitech G27 Racing Wheel. My criticisms and compliments are essentially 100% applicable here.

Project Cars:

If you own a PS4, and are even remotely interested in a steering wheel setup, Project Cars is, as of August, 2015, where it's at. I found it extremely difficult (nigh unplayable) with a Dualshock 4, so the G29 is extremely good fun here. The force feedback needs some work, though, and the developers are supposed to release an update in the near future (it's August 10 as I type this). Currently, vibration of apexes of corners don't consistently set off the force feedback, and just in general it's a little off of where it should be. That said, it's still EXTREMELY fun, and transforms the game. It's a bit fiddly to make the wheel work in-game, so here's my little guide:

1.) Don't plug the wheel into the PS4 yet.
2.) Turn your PS4 on and load Project Cars using a Dualshock 4 controller.
3.) On the main menu when it asks you to Press X to start - don't -, just plug the G29 wheel into the USB port on the PS4.
4.) Wait for the wheel to spin/calibrate. Then, press the PS button on the wheel and choose your avatar/login name with X.
5.) Press X on the wheel to start Project Cars at this point, and then you can navigate the menu and play the game.
6.) You may need to turn off the Dualshock 4 off (holding down the PS button and going to Devices to switch it off - I've had it work sometimes without it doing this, and other times the wheel won't work until I turn off the Dualshock 4. Clearly this needs better support!

(*EDIT August 19*  The Project Cars patch that came out this week seems to have addressed the above issue with the G29 not being detected!)

DriveClub:

DriveClub is, today, an exceptionally fun game. Despite being released half-baked, it's come into its own in recent months - with constant support from the developer. With the G29, it's even more fun, though there's certainly a learning curve. If anything, DriveClub becomes more of a sim than ever before with the wheel, and you really need to be careful to brake before the corners, and not accelerate too hard out of them, especially in RWD cars. Either way, the force feedback is more effective here than in Project Cars (though not perfect - crashing into walls has no effect on the wheel force feedback, for some reason), but you can't go wrong with either game. I definitely recommend both. It's driving heaven.

PC use: It's a G27 to Windows. It works exactly the same. Zero improvements. It's a G27.

If you don't own a PS4, don't bother. It's the same wheel and pedals, mechanically, as the G27, but no longer includes the 6-speed shifter (sold separately!), and is much more expensive, because... reasons. So for PS3 and PC owners, stick with the G27. It's far better value (and will likely get even cheaper with the G29 now out).

I'm very disappointed in Logitech at this point. Six years on from the release of the G27 and Logitech seem content with re-releasing the same product..., for more money..., with a piece of hardware now missing (the shifter).

But, you might say, this is a really great steering wheel, so why 3 stars? Because it's by far the most consumer-unfriendly Logitech product out there. It's a slap in the face of gamers followed a veritable punch to their nether regions. If this were sold, as the G27 before it, with the shifter included, and for a similar price (translation: for the same price or a little less money than the G27 because manufacturing a G27/G29 HAS to be cheaper these days), then I'd still be disappointed with the lack of innovation, but give it 4.5 stars because it's a good product.

That the G29 costs SO much more than the G27 AND removes the shifter from the package is quite frankly - a travesty.

Oh, and a couple of further digs at the G29:

1.)  The Options/Share buttons are in the wrong place. They really should be reversed, since I keep hitting the Share button when feeling for the Options (Start) button. Why, Logitech, would you put the more commonly-used Options button in the MIDDLE of a cluster of buttons? *shakes head...* This makes restarting races a more annoying procedure, especially in less-than-well-lit room.

2.) The LED tach cluster is too low/too small on the steering wheel. I wish it were located at the top of the wheel like in a Ferrari F458 Italia. It's pretty much not possible to notice them during actual racing. But again, this was an issue on the G27, too, and nothing has changed.

Overall, 3 stars out of 5. It's clear that Logitech's heart was not in this wheel, and it shows.

PS On a side-note, I remember Logitech tweeting back in August, 2014, that the G27 wouldn't work on PS4 because of some " security chip" the G27 wheel was missing to work on the new Sony console. However, for example the Thrustmaster T500RS Racing Wheel - Playstation 3, which was released way back in 2011, has no such issues on the PS4. So I've no idea what Logitech is going on about here.

PPS Bad, Logitech. Bad.

author: David Smith
title: Excellent wheel all around.
content:
This is a really excellent wheel. Top quality. Had been contemplating purchasing a wheel (compatible with both PS3 and PS4) about two months ago to further enhance my enjoyment of GT6 racing especially after the stress put on my hands and fingers using the stock DS3 hand-held controller hours on end. At first I was thinking of purchasing the Thrustmaster T150 but decided to do some checking/comparisons and reviews before deciding. On the one hand the T150 was cheaper while on the other hand the G29 was considerably more expensive. After much consideration I decided to go with the G29.
Reasons being: (1) Superior finish, both in base material and genuine leather covering. (2) Superior pedals with stainless steel. (3) Superior mechanics overall. (4) Excellent reviews. (5) Longevity.

So with the above in mind I decided the best decision was to put out the extra money (consider it an investment) and purchase the G29 about a month ago. I've been using it every day since, each for a many hours a day, and convinced I made the right decision. It has increased my racing enjoyment ten-fold including racing ability. I am extremely satisfied with it and wish I had purchased it before as it would have definitely helped previously. But as they say, everything in time.

There is nothing negative I can say about it. All positive and gets a full 5-stars. Additionally my hands and fingers are very thankful for the stress relief. Now I'm just waiting for the next release of GT6...GT Sport knowing full well that my investment will still be compatible. Win-Win.

author: Zane S.
title: Not a BAD wheel, but save yourself the trouble and get a G27 or Thrustmaster.
content:
Got the G29 in last night, primarily to play Euro Truck Simulator 2 right now, with plans to play Assetto Corsa, Dirt Rally, and BeamNG.Drive down the road. Wheel and pedals are very well built and so far pretty solid. Setup was very quick, and even breaking down the wheel so I can move it aside is quick.

The steering wheel and all 25 programmable buttons work beautifully, the major problem is, the pedals don't work correctly on PC. The brake registers as the brake, the clutch registers as the accelerator, and the accelerator doesn't register at all. This is a known issue with the wheel, and it seems Logitech is ignoring the issue. In my searching of the internet, I've found a possible "duct-tape" fix that I am going to try and implement tonight, but as a "quality" product I should not have to be doing this. This puts me off about Logitech products as a whole, and I am going to seriously consider never buying their products again.

It is my opinion that if you are looking for a good steering wheel for PC, you are better off buying the G27, or even a Thrustmaster wheel.

I hope some of you find this review helpful.

I tried turning the feedback down to super low levels in Forza Horizon 3 but it was still making my car spin out at every chance....

I do like the wheel overall, I will give it a real go on Project Cars, or Forza 3 later on where I think this wheel would really shine.... don't recommend it for off road games though (at least not with rumble on)

You can really feel the gears moving and FF is just a lot more choppy.  I've gotten used to it after a while and am really enjoying my racing experience with Assetto Corsa and Project Cars 2.  I also bought a GTART Wheel Stand which makes it 10 times better as well.  I didn't have any trouble getting it working in Win10 64 bit fall creators update.  I just installed the Logitech gaming software and plugged the USB cable into my PC and it was recognized right away.  Overall I'm very happy with my purchase @ $200 but will still keep my eyes open for a hot deal on a Fanatec CSL Elite or CSW v2.5 wheel to upgrade too.  The belt drive technology is definitely superior.

title: Horrible quality
content:
Logitech's quality has severely declined, I would recommend saving and purchasing something else.

The first g29 I received had a horrible screeching sound when rotating the wheel left, right out of the box. Amazon was great and got a replacement sent to me quickly, however the second wheel had it's own set of issues. It made a grinding noise right out of the box, and over the course of a couple hours also developed a squeak when the wheel would rotate to the left, and the squeak was progressively getting worse.

I'm now on the third g29 from Amazon and after about a week of use the wheel has once again developed a squeak. On top of that, the gas pedal was also loosely-assembled out of the box, and had to be fixed.

At this point I'm giving up on finding a decent product from Logitech. Their wheels are plagued by quality issues that are simply unacceptable at this price point.

author: Amanda
title: Quality product minus the stiff brake (fixable/how to)
content: This wheel is great. The force Feedback adds a realistic feel to the game but the motor is powerful and my cheap folding table was tipping while fighting the wheel to regain control of my cars. You can disable if by unplugging the power cord for the motor and just leaving the USB connection to the xbox/pc plugged in. The wheel is really sensitive without the motor however. Plan to have a sturdy set up for this wheel. My only complaint is the brake. The brake is really stiff and it takes a lot of force to fully depress the pedal. If this was not correctable I would have returned the whole thing! Fortunately you can remove a small rectangular piece of rubber from the break to reduce the tension from the spring. You'll need a set of torx wrenches size 10 and 30. You'll need a size 1 and 2 Philips screwdriver and a 10mm socket or crescent wrench. Make sure it's unplugged. Remove the brake pedal (middle pedal) with the Torx10 then remove all of the screws from the back of the pedal box. Open it up and pull the break pedal out. Be careful not to damage any of the wires! Use the 10mm wrench and the Torx30 to remove the nut and bolt that holds the brake together. Then pull the rubber piece out and put the spring back in. Make sure all the wires are placed properly in their spots before closing it back up. The game play is significantly improved with this brake mod! The spring itself is still pretty strong and I might go with a different spring later but it's playable now. Also, The pedal box has a spikey kind of "carpet brake" that you can pop out to hold the whole thing in place. It works surprisingly well on my rug. Before my brake mod the force of pressing the pedal would move the whole pedal set up now the carpet breaks work just fine to hold it in place.

author: Kenny
title: Fantastic for simulator games of all types.
content: I bought this mainly for Euro and American Truck Simulators. It works great for both and has great wheel controls in the options. I noticed the description of this wheel keeps mentioning "force feedback" but I don't believe it said anything about the wheel being mechanically driven.. meaning theres an actual motor behind the wheel that has 100% control. Through that motor, you can control wheel stiffness, centering, etc. There is no spring that launches the wheel back to the original position. I was pretty surprised by this when I plugged it in for the first time and the wheel spun all the way in one direction, then all the way in the other direction, then back to center. I assume is was an auto-calibration. But it did all that without me doing anything other than plugging it in. It's pretty advanced stuff and knocks the socks off of the original "Farming Wheel" that this is replacing. As far as the brake petal, I can see how the stiffness could get annoying in a racing game where you need a fast response, but its great for simulator games. The stiffness prevents you from slamming the brakes when you're coming up to a stop. It makes for a nice and smooth stop that you have a lot of control over.

author: Mitch
title: Firm brake pedal.
content: Really helped bring my gaming experience to the next level! This was my first time owning a wheel and I really enjoy it. The brake pedal is very firm!! This has helped me build strength to press a real brake pedal! The pedals are very sturdy and stable.

Also I haven't found any game except euro truck sim, american truck sim and race 07 that works well with it. Understeer isnt a thing once car turns and try to counter it seems to do nothing but quickly switch and lauch the other way causing spinouts. I bought with idea to use in forza horizon 4 but no matter the settings seems impossible not to spin out especially offroad

author: JuiceMcGoose
title: That would be nice, but you aren't going to be on the ...
content:
Besides the G920, I currently own a Fanatec CSR Elite/Clubsport pedals, Fanatec Porsche GT2, Logitech G27, Logitech Driving Force Pro, plus two of Logitech's older wheels. I race on Xbox One, Xbox 360, PS3 and PC. I've used a wheel to race for about 10 years now.

This wheel doesn't have the Auto-clutch feature of Fanatec and Thrustmaster. That would be nice, but you aren't going to be on the Hardcore Leaderboard in Forza 6 with any wheel unless you are seriously dedicated anyway, because wheels need Normal steering on and STM only on in that game to make the cars controlable.

But besides that...this wheel rocks. The problems with FFB people in having in Forza 6 are the games fault. Use this wheel in Project Cars on Xbox One or PC, or the other PC sims, and the Force Feed Back is right on. Also, the pedals are as good as Fanatec ClubSport pedals. Honest. Nobody is paying me to say that. It's true. Plus I'm on my third ClubSport brake load cell. They wear down over time. Knowing Logitech, their brake pedal will probably be reliable. With Forza 6, you need to go into Advanced Wheel settings to slide the Outside Deceleration down to around 60%.

So if you consider how well this wheel/pedal set works, $400 is a screaming deal.

author: Z. Jordan
title: it's easy to see this bushing is the cause of the ...
content: I had heard about brake pedal problem on the G920 but not on the G29, and so I contacted Logitech about it.  I was told the pedals on the 29 & 920 are the exact same.  So I bought the G920, lo and behold the brake only had about 50-60% use/travel.  I opened up the pedals (~16 screws & a 6mm allen wrench/10mm box wrench) and found a 1/2x1/2x15/16" rubber bushing in with the pedal spring.  Seeing that the full pedal travel is 1 & 1/2" and the bushing is 15/16", it's easy to see this bushing is the cause of the problem.  Improvement suggestion, remove the bushing and have a fully functional product.

author: Katelyn
title: Squeaky
content: Was satisfied with the product initially. However within a couple days the wheel began to make an obnoxious squeak noise when turning it to the left. I tore the entire base of the wheel apart in hopes of lubercating the otherwise “dry” gearing. After this 4 hour process, The squeak did stop. But week later it returned. I do not plan on returning however be aware that this problem is very common

author: Customer J
title: Good wheel for the price
content: Decided to move up from the controller to a wheel for playing GT Sport on PS4 and project cars.  My first wheel, but it seems to be well built, the steering wheels is comfortable and responsive, the force feedback is strong.  Pedals feel good, overall good product and bought it on sale during Prime day, so thanks Amazon.  Would have been nice for them to through in the shifter, but the paddle shift is nice and have a satisfying click.  I was impressed to see they were metal and not plastic.  Plug and play with the PS4 with perfect, plugged it in and drove immediately, no setup required.  I've had a few Logitech peripherals, and this seems to be in the same vein of high quality as others I've used (mice, keyboards, remotes, controllers).  Good wheel, good price, get to racing.

author: Grumbo
title: Awesome wheel with force feedback
content:
So i bought this to work in conjunction with Project cars in Oculus Rift VR.

The wheel itself is wrapped in leather like it would be in a real sports car, and its hand stitched! It feels wonderful and natural when you're gripping it. I love the attention to detail logitech did here, like the shift lights on the top of the wheel. On top of that the wheel has easy to find buttons (important when you are wearing a VR headset). Everything is where 'it should be' so to speak. The wheel itself connects to the desk/table/whatever via two clamps that you can screw with some hidden hand screws. The one thing I am not thrilled about with this wheel is the paddle shifters. They do make a 'clicking' sound when that are actuated but, you cannot feel it. This clicking noise isnt helpful at all when in VR since youre most likely wearing headphones, without the tactile feel of a 'bump' its sometimes a little hard to know if you pushed it far enough. Thankfully you can hear it in the engine while in game.

The Pedals work great on carpeted floor, just make sure you drop down the spikes on the bottom of it. I cant comment on how they work on a hard surface, but i imagine there definitely needs to be some more rubber under it. As for the feel, well the clutch/accelerator pedal feel smooth and linear. For the brake however, its got a lot more resistance, especially near the end of the stroke. Its a nice addition from previous set ups honestly. Its how it would feel in a real car when you stomp on the brake pedal. I wish it also had some force feedback to simulate ABS for cars that have it, but i think thats just wishful thinking on my part... and besides race cars generally dont have ABS anyway.

All in all i think this is a great wheel for anyone attempting to use with VR.

author: R. Williams
title: 1 star because Installation is a nightmare  - No Customer Support from Logitech - sad ...;
content:
Final update - Received the new wheel and nothing .... so after several more hours searching for answers (google) I found a comment "When you have tried everything, it's time to completely reset your pc"  So I did a complete reset and then reinstalled the g920 and it works perfectly. And it is a very nice wheel , when it works

update - No Response from Logitech Customer Service.  Really , no response !  But Amazon is happy to replace this defective unit with a new one - free of charge -  Thank you Amazon.

 I received this monster yesterday and just started installing it this morning.  It is now 4pm  and it still does not work properly.  First note that I have confidence that some day soon it will be working but it is a disaster out of the box.  There is absolutely no instruction provided with this thing.  Yes there is a picture gram of the wiring but seriously - who really needs that ?  You will need to go to google  to find out that you need to down load Logitech gaming software plus up date the g920 firmware.after that you are totally on your own.  I have been trying to use it in 4 games - Euro Truck Sim2 , Farm Sim 17, Dirt Rally and Assetto Corsa.  Just to be sure it not a single game issue.  I can get the thing to steer and the gas and brake work but there is no force feed back at all.  I have searched the games forums and there are just no answers for this problem.  maybe the unit is defective. I have emailed customer support.  If it ever starts working I will up date this review.
Right now I'm really wishing I had bought the cheapest wheel

author: Jay Q.
title: Met expectations
content: I recommend this product. Price is a little high but since there is not a lot of options for Xbox one racing wheels l was willing to give it a try. I bought this wheel to mainly use for project cars and it has not disappointed. Works well Forza titles as well , but l have found adjusting the sensitivity settings low works better for forza. Quality construction and it just feels like it is made to last. Force feedback can be very strong and the pedals feel great too. The progressive brake pedal really helps.l also purchased the shifter and have been very happy with it as well. It does take some getting used to since you don't get any feedback through the shifter, but it does add to the experience if you are driving manual shift. If you love racing games and are considering a wheel I recommend this product. It will also improve your lap times. I have found myself increasing the difficulty of my games.

author: Terry Hicks
title: You can control how heavy the wheels are for force feedback do they slip what percentage break clutch seat adjustments height it
content:
I got my wheel last week or so. I read almost everyone's reviews of all product to be used on the xbox one. The break peddle to hard?
. In the advanced settings where it's says throttle % on down the line... Breaks, steering how far you want to turn the wheel for a complete turn I use -6 To turn the adjustment is made at the bottom you will see how far your travel is and how how hard you want the wheel to comeback to the center that one scared me the first time I used it I wasn't expecting it to be so strong and  for the breaks for being to hard. Adjust them to how much pressure % force needed for 100% use I use 25% it's not to hard like normal to me.
 You can adjust this wheel to however you drive how hard you want to step on the breaks. To preven from sliding a lot on gravel lower hour throttle so you can't burn out in rear wheel drive cars. You can control how heavy the wheels are for force feedback do they slip what percentage break clutch seat adjustments height it is very nice once I learned that I can customize the wheel to how I like and feel the weight the engine effect it has on steering what percentage. There's so much to this steering wheel that people seem to not understand it or how to adjust it correctly. Trust me I had all he same frustrations as every one else here about how hard the breaks are. Next  how many times do you have to turn the wheel just to make a u turn first off it was two complete turns of the steering wheel that's were I already stated the -6.
 At first I wasn't happy at the steering wheel it was to difficult to run dirt Rally with. the steering wheel away to difficult to complete turns then fight with the wheel wanting to go back to zero when I need it to go right.  To much of a fight. I fix it by adjusting your throtle breaks force feedback and how far you want to turn the steering wheel . Me just A 1\4 turn on the wheel is almost enough to make the sharp turns. Just thought I would let people know there's a way to fix most of the issues by yourself if you play with it in advanced setting.
Terry

On top of that, it adds an amount of depth/realism that you just would never get with a controller or mouse/keyboard. Even though the customization options are limited, it makes up for it with hours of enjoyment. Playing with a mouse and keyboard has never felt to dull in my life!!!

author: Darius
title: Works great with forza 4 and f1 racing games

author: Wayne
title: Very good racing wheel and pedal set!
content: I've got a Thrustmaster T150, 2 pedal set at home for my PC and PS4 and like it very much.  I got the G920 for my office PC whenever I get some down time.  I have to say that the gear driven ffb is not a problem.  It's very strong and the ffb dead zone some have mentioned is not an issue on my set.  If I were to directly compare the 2, I would say the G920 is better overall.  It feels more well made and sturdy.  I just wish I could play GTSport with it, but that's what my T150 is for.  I use the G920 for FH3, F7, PC 1 & 2 and Assetto Corsa, all on PC.

author: Josh
title: Very nice wheel for casual or serious sims enthusiast.
content: Works awesome out of the box and very high quality for a lower end wheel. After reading tons of reviews and watching comparison videos. I bought a thrustmaster tx and it was doa, it was supposed to be almost as good as a high end fanatec but light years ahead of a Logitech g920/g29. I then ordered the g920 to replace it and wow it's a nice steering wheel. A nice grippy feel but not to grippy and the buttons and pedals feel sturdier than the tx. After using it with some driving sims it worked great even out of the box. I would recommend this for any beginner or sim racing enthusiast and do not recommend a thrustmaster tx. Save the extra money for buying more games and get the g920.

author: Rogue
title: Motor skipping
content: Whenever I’m driving in a game and start turning or drifting instead of the wheel consistently fighting me it kinda skips kind of like the motor is engaging and disengaging. Not sure if it’s normal or not. Kinda tempted to return it and get the Thrustmaster Sparco wheel. It’s about 250 dollars more but probably better.

author: Bryan
title: IT SAVED MY LIFE.... LITERALLY.
content: so yesterday, October 13th, 2018; it was raining pretty heavily in Phoenix. I was coming home from work on the free way when suddenly on the way i made a lane change and hit a big puddle of water and lost traction on the right side tires and started to hydroplane. Thankfully I've been using this steering wheel to play Forza and drifting was my go to. So naturally I began to gather a certain feeling when using the steering wheel, what to do, and how to do it. its sounds kinda cringe but when the hydroplane event commenced the first thing that i thought about was Forza.. therefore when i was sliding left and right in the middle of the freeway next to other people, i knew exactly how to handle the steering wheel...  and that is how this product saved my life, it gave me the chance to practice driving.... or... atleast to a certain extent.

author: ethan

The stitching on the wheel leaves something to be desired as it isn't sharp enough to cut but will grab at your hands. Honestly if you don't plan on ripping this thing apart and modding the brake spring i wouldn't buy it. Braking with this setup is honestly the hardest thing iv'e ever tried to learn lmfao.

author: John
title: G29 vs T300
content:
If you are trying to decide on which wheel, let me help.  I bought this a while back and it arrived fine with no damage to the box.  I installed it for my PS4 racing games.  Right out of the box it does some kind of test by rotating the wheel as far right and left as it will go, making a loud clunky noise.  I knew this wheel has gears but I didn't realize how noisy and clunky it would be.  It has good force feedback, but the gears just take away any positive experience.  After trying it for a while, I noticed that when I turn on the ps4 it would turn the wheel full left and right and make a horrible sound, which may have been faulty from the factory or maybe this is normal.  Either way I was not happy with this and I returned it and got the Thrustmaster T300.  Wow, what a difference, night and day between these 2 wheels.

The T300 does the same wheel test but it's smooth and relatively quiet, because it is belt driven.  I played some project cars and hit the wall and the wheel almost took my arm off....lol.  I had to turn down the settings, because my arms were getting tired after a few laps.  This is definitely the experience I was looking for.  I would say this wheel is for kids and the Thrustmaster is for adults.

I did enjoy the leather wrapped wheel, and the pedals were amazing, but in the end the better product wins.  I wish they did sell the pedals by themselves, because they are fantastic,  but I got the T3PA pro pedals and they work great also.  I can't really give a full review because I think the wheel wasn't working right out of the box, or maybe that's just the way the gears are supposed to sound.  Just in my opinion, the Thrustmaster gives a better feel of road bumps and crashes and an overall better race experience.  Hopefully this helps you out on making a decision.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Flaw in Pedal Connection Design Causes Short
content:
The only thing worse than the engineering of the pedal connection to the wheel is Logiteck's support.  I purchased the set for Christmas 2017 - barely 3 months ago.  The wire connecting the pedals to the wheel routes from the front of the pedals, requiring a 360 degree turn back under the pedal assembly to route up to the wheel.  Pressure on the pedals moving it forward pinches and in my case split the wire.  Resulting short makes pedals inoperative and whole product useless.

I attempted to remove the damaged section of the wire as a repair while also contacting logiteck via chat.  The chat resulted in my being cut off after the rep told me I had violated the warranty by attempting a fix.  Several subsequent emails including one bizarre sequence where I was told they declined to replace my product as it was out of warranty and a minute later sent a mail asking if I was satisfied.

All I need is replacement pedals ... Logiteck claims they do NOT have just pedals.  I've said I'd pay for pedals ... they don't have any spares.  So my course of action is to pay full retail (about $70 more now than the pre-XMas sale price) for a complete set that I don't need.  And they ask if I'm satisfied.

Not sure which is worse ... the design flaw that caused the problem or the support? ..  leaning toward the support.

author: Caitlin Flores

author: Bryan

I would invest in a different shifter but the steering wheel and pedals are great. But a pain in the butt to set up every once in a while. I would also invest in a stand for it while playing

author: Gage Henson
title: Dude
content: Super awesome. Could have bought new injections for my truck for this price, but i was drunk.

author: FRod
title: Costs as much as your console but still a Great Wheel!
content:
Wheel looks great, leather feels of high quality. Makes Driving in games like Forza 6 way more fun than using the remote.
I bought this to go with my PlaySeat Challenge (foldable racing seat Playseat Challenge) because I knew there was no way to sit properly on the couch, and still get the feeling you are racing.

Pros
+ Great feeling wheel, feels almost as good as the perforated leather wheel on my real car :D
+ Looks good! I know it doesnt mean as much as how it performs but there are some hideous wheels out there!
+ 3 Pedals, In case you want to learn how to drive manual. Good feedback, although some have complained that the brake takes strength to push.
+ Makes Racing games a blast! Even my young kids were playing on it and having fun.
+ Best wheel in this price range.
+ Works with PC

Cons
- Expensive. Have to think long and hard on whether you want to spend the same amount of money on a wheel that your console costs. Sweet spot for a wheel should be $250, not $400.
- Shifter comes separate. I dont need it (yet) but doesnt feel good knowing shifter will cost you an extra $60.

Should you buy this wheel?
If you own a PS4 (G29) or an Xbox One and love racing games then this is a must buy wheel for you.

author: JF
title: Best bang for the buck!
content:
When purchasing a wheel I had a hard time finding the right balance of quality and price - there are other wheels that have more features and better feel, but much lower durability at equal or higher price.  I was on the verge of dropping nearly $1,800 on a fanatec setup, but was concerned about the long-term durability.  At that price, I can buy 4 of the G29, so that's what I went with - and I'm glad I did.  For a first wheel at low cost, the compatibility and quality is on point.

Pros: Great feel, low cost, clutch pedal included (looking at you, thrustmaster), PC/PS4/PS3 compatibility (G29 model).  Less than $70 to add on a 6 speed shifter.

Cons:  You can definitely feel where they cut corners to make this at such a low price point.  A lot of plastic components, the clamps do not seem to be strong, the wheel is a bit on the small side, not as precise as it could be, but definitely good enough.  I'm not crazy about the logitech software to configure the wheel and find it a bit frustrating to get the settings to stick.  The remainder of complaints concern the 6 speed shifter, but that is not included with this, so that'll be reviewed separately.

Improvements: Pedal mods - i'm not going to do this, but these little flaps feel nothing at all like a real car.  I know there are plenty of mods to get a better feel out of the pedals.  The paddle shifter had a plastic 'click' to it that sounds like it's cracking rather pressing a button - I also wish it was a bit larger.

Overall, I would highly recommend this wheel to someone getting into sim racing.  I don't see myself upgrading from this setup for a while, if ever.  I'm happy enough that when it comes time to buy another for compatibility or when this one wears out, I may buy this again or whatever logitech's next revision is.

-----
Edit: Since the wheel and shifter were purchased separately, but listed on the same page - I can't leave a separate review for the shifter, so here it is:

I can't say I'm thrilled with the shifter on its own, but it does the trick.  It feels cheap, it offers very little, but it completes the kit, it's small, and it works.  I don't regret buying it, I'm not thrilled with the purchase either.  I'm happy enough with the G29 that it makes up for my disappointment and the lack of any feeling in the shifter.

Pros: works, short throw, small, and dirt cheap in comparison to other shifters

Cons:  No resistance, no weight to it, all plastic, no additional buttons, no sequential switch/option

There are mods to the shifter that add tension and will even allow you to make it a sequential shifter.  I may buy a 2nd shifter to mod - to make it either a sequential shifter or a handbrake, but that's something I'll address later.

Overall, if you want a shifter to complete your setup, this is cheap enough to go for it.  If you're on the fence regarding whether or not you want a shifter, just skip on it.

-----
To summarize the reviews for the wheel a shifter: Wheel kit is great, shifter is cheap enough that it warrants its purchase if you want a shifter with your kit.

author: Jonathan
title: Not worth the $300
content:
First time writing a review and only because I've had quite a few problems about this product.

When I received the package today it was poorly packaged and looked like its been opened. Although the contents didn't look to be tampered with. Upon setup of the wheel and pedals it was straight forward.

Once I go the software downloaded (PC) and everything calibrated it worked pretty good on the few games I tried, although I didn't like the feel of the wheel.

Then where the 2 star review comes in, the buttons stopped working when all the software was up to date and connected to the PC. When driving in some games it often would correct itself to the center when it's not needed and ruins the experience. After working in the settings nothing seemed to work to which I had to return it to go for the Thrustmaster set which I tried saving some money on buying this instead.

If this has any influence on your purchase buy with caution and do some reasearch on the games you'll be playing and make sure they're no current problems with the wheel setup. I heard of some problems with Forza Horizon 3 but didn't expect it to make it unplayable.

This was my first wheel and I wasn't amazed by this product as I'd hoped.

In short either save up for the Thrustmater VG TX Leather Edition or save a hundred and go for the Thrustmaster TMX.

author: Jyaku
title: No prior wheel exp before buying this
content:
Edited: NFS2015 does not work on PS4 as of yet. Pretty sad about this...

I never owned a steering wheel. I have never used the G27, played a few racing games at the local arcade (Initial D, Max Tuning or whatever) and on my friend's setup ages ago which I can't even remember what it was.

I've been researching wheels since earlier this year, before the G29 was announced and through out.

I was considering the Fanatec Porsche, Thrustmaster 300RS and the 500RS as well as waiting a bit to save up for a Fanatec Clubsports...

Well, I wasn't sure how much I'd get into racing games so I held off for awhile reading reviews and I couldn't commit to nearly 1k dollars for a Fanatec CSP set and frankly speaking all the bad reviews scared me away from Thrustmaster. So it was either the Logitech G27 or the G29.

Well I'm glad I went with the G29. Originally I thought I didn't need to get PS4 support but I realized that most of my friends play consoles for racing rather than PC gaming so I figured I'd get the one that has the support.

This works right out of the box for GT6 on the PS3 and it is awesome. I never got into that game because it was too hard for me to play with controller, but this, this made it so much more fun.

The other games I've tried so far is Project Cars and Grid Autosports.

Project cars is a weird one for me, initially it worked but after tweaking some settings it messed up my controls (pedals were backwards) and had to fiddle with the settings to get them to work right.

Grid Autosports just straight up doesn't work. I gave up. Not even gonna bother with the headache. Menu keeps scrolling, can't change keys, stuck facing backwards and steering doesn't engage. I don't know if it's the Logitech software, my settings for the wheel, or the game but I gave up.

It doesn't work in Need for Speed Undercover. Couldn't get to the settings.

I'm just waiting for the new Need for Speed reboot, preordered  it and waiting to play with friends. Plus GT7 sometime maybe next year.

Controls wise it feels fine, I was a bit skeptical of the wheel size since it seemed so tiny but it actually is really practical. I'm amazed on how small the actual wheel base is and it's pretty quiet. The pedals aren't bad, but I have nothing to compare to besides arcade ones. I may consider getting Fanatec's Clubsport V2 or V3 later on but for me it works fine. The paddle shifters work fine, I had a 2015 Mustang rental recently and it had paddle shifters and these feel about the same, if not better.

I have my wheel base mounted to a Obutto Ozone cockpit, works great, pedals I haven't figured out how to properly mount yet but they aren't slipping everywhere so I'll figure something out later.

Final conclusion: At this price I wish it included the stick shift. The driver support is a bit whack. I don't get how to get games to work on it but it works fine in consoles. The profiles are a joke for this inside the Logitech suite. Half are still assigned to keyboard. I don't regret it though. It's a lot of fun and a totally different gaming exp.

Edit:
So I've had this for over a month now, and to be honest... I still love it. I'm just disappointed with the lack of game support. Project Cars isn't a bad game but the cars I like aren't in it and the style of driving is.... not really something I find all that fun. GT6 is awesome on the PS3, I play one or two races daily.

Don't buy the stick shift. It isn't worth it. It works in Project Cars. That's the only game I personally can confirm it works.

Games I've played so far that work with this wheel, NFS: The Run (a bit awful though, can't really adjust settings, not very fun), Project Cars PC, GT6 (ps3) and thats it so far that i've gotten to work without too much fiddling.

Games that don't work that I've tried, The Crew (PS4), NFS 2015 (PS4), NFS Undercover, Grid Autosports (this is kinda weird one, it works for some, I haven't found a way around it)

I do want to add that this is kinda bs as some of the games on some websites say they are supported. Do research to make sure it's compatible with the games you plan to play.

author: Rob
title: Excellent force-feedback wheel. Quiet! Do not physically modify your brake pedal, read more!
content:
Excellent feedback - especially with FM7 configuration. I've increased the resistance to help simulate actual driving a bit more. Only complaint is that I wish that the steering ratio would match each car individually instead of having a global ratio... maybe it does, but it doesn't seem like it. I like the fact that Dirt Rally has a preset configuration which works nicely... and makes the game 500% more enjoyable (you can actually rally now). As a novice racer in real life, this is pretty good... aside from the brake pedal stiffness (which is unreal to get 100% in FM7 w/default settings).

Contrary to another review, you should NOT modify the brake pedal - as this may void the warranty and is unnecessary with newer games (I'm unsure of how far back for games you'd need to physically modify the brake pedal).

The correct solution is to modify the outer dead zone for deceleration to about 50-70% -- you can test the optimal setting by driving and watching the red bar on the bottom-right hand of your HUD in FM7 -- this shows you braking pressure. If you're braking as hard as you physically want to brake, and the red box is not filling up, then lower your outer deceleration dead zone a bit more. Tada! The same applies to some other games as well.

author: Edster
title: Solid and it keeps working!  Which is important.
content: I had a Thrustmaster that broke after less than 10 uses...  I bought the G29 as a backup while the Thrustmaster was being fixed and repaired.  I like the G29 so much that I'm hesitant to switch back now that my fixed thrust master has come back to me.  If you're debating between wheels and what's better than the others, this G29 is the one you want.  I went google searching and I am not the only customer that has had their Thrustmaster die on them.  Seems to be some type of an over heating issue or something with the motor and it seems to be common.  Do yourself a favor and buy this wheel now because you'll end up here anyways if you don't.

author: Peg Chacich

content: This was the best price I found and exactly what my grandson wanted. He loves it and the quality is right up there. The 2 day shipping is really great. He set it up right away and it works great!

author: J. Fail

author: Chris
title: As the saying goes, "If you want quality, you have to pay for it," and that's the biggest downside to this wheel by far.
content:
I bought this wheel to use with the Xbox One and, more specifically, Forza 6. The last wheel I owned was the Xbox 360 force feedback wheel in 2007, so I have no reference point to compare to other Xbox One or PC wheels.

Initial impression is the wheel and pedals are built really well. I won't go too much into the quality, as the description covers the types of materials used, but it met my high expectations for at least perceived build quality. At the price point the wheel is set at, it's disappointing the shifter is not included, but I digress.

As others mentioned, the brake pedal is pretty stiff, but I don't find it so stiff that I would make any changes. It could be slightly less stiff, but I think that will wear in over time. Overall, I like the way the pedals feel individually, but your experience with other wheels and real cars may influence this (I've driven cars with stiff brake pedals, which may be why it doesn't bother me so much). That being said, it is pretty necessary to put something heavy behind the pedals so that you do not push them away.

My plan is to build a stand at some point, but my impromptu setup was to attach the wheel to a folding wood TV tray, I then added about 20 pounds to the tray to weigh it down, and then as I mentioned I always back the pedals with something to keep them in place. It works well enough.

As for the wheel the in use, after a little getting used to, it's very fun and adds another dimension to Forza 6 (the only game I've played it with). Being able to more reliably use partial throttle around a corner, being able to feel the understeer, etc., are a few of the doors that open.

The force feedback is pretty quiet and feels good when you're on track. The feedback does seem to be pulling to wheel center more than it's pulling in relation to what your car is actually doing, but it still feels good. The main time that it does not feel particularly realistic is when you go off track or your car gets really out of control, at which point you are frantically turning and fighting the wheel to correct.

Assuming this wheel has no internal issues that cause it to stop working, the only downsides I see are
a) the need to build a stand (or buy an overpriced one) if you plan on using the wheel a lot (improvising like I did works but it's not ideal, and you won't get away with putting the wheel on your lap)
b) the price (and that the high price does not come with the shifter because, let's be real, if you get the wheel and shifter for $360, which is the lowest price I've seen, you could buy a console and game bundle for less)
c) no headset jack
d) no ability to use wirelessly (which may be a blessing since lag could be an issue wirelessly)

Beyond that, it's a really fun piece. If you're a racing game fan and can get past the price, it's definitely worth buying.

author: J. Banville
title: Doesn't feel natural
content: This is my first gaming steering wheel. Maybe I was expecting too much. This thing uses gears attached to motors inside to give the wheel "weight" and force feedback (ffb). One problem is that u can actually feel (and hear) the meshing of the internals gears. And the way that the ffb kicks in doesn't feel natural. There is a little play in the centered position where you can shake the wheel and the car on screen shows the steering input, but the mechanism isn't activating, so there is no wheel "weight", but turn the wheel a little more and BAM!, u feel the weight. In short, this wheel is far from "natural" feeling. The build quality is top notch though. I only tried this on F1 2015 and Forza 6. I'll b returning it and trying the Thrustmaster tx 458. A utube channel called sim racing claims it feels more natural. I'll post a review of it soon.
