If you have a cockpit or a stand for the wheel its not really a problem though. The wheel works okay for some games but is also really bad for some.

author: Wesley Johnson
title: Best wheel I ever had.
content: Don't bother spending money on thrustmaster or fanatic crap. This is by far the best wheel for the $.

author: Tedcr
title: A very well built unit with fun feedback.
content: Very well built.  Compatible with all the newer racing games.  A few of the older previous versions of AAA racing games require some fiddling.  So far all but one of those have worked.  Go to the website of the game you play or want to play and check wheel compatibility and user forums before you buy.

author: Edward
title: Wanted to upgrade.
content: Was more then expected. Just remember to set up for your style of driving depending on game.

author: Charles
title: Missing settings to use paddle shifters on an auto transmission
content: Logitech G920 Dual-motor Feedback Driving wheel XBOX One X over all it is a very nice setup well made, I have never used a wheel setup and this makes a world of difference playing racing games. I would have gave it five stars but the reason is it does not have a setup to use the paddle shifts for an auto transmission, on some tracks you have downshift instead of braking, when you tap the brake to down shift it gets you in trouble.car makers did`nt put those gear select numbers there for nothing they are there so you can down shift manually or up shift manually. It is not a hard fix Logitech just needs to program the wheel to use the paddles to up and down shift with the paddles on a auto transmission then do an update to the settings on the setup settings. over all I am happy with it.

author: Charles Caranna Jr.
title: Quality proven, great price
content: If you’re looking to buy a wheel in this price range with confidence, this wheel is the way to go.  Had it since March ‘17 with absolutely no issues or concerns in reliability.  While its direct rivals are tempting to consider and may be equipped with more options, you can be assured this wheel will last a long time with sensible care and use.  It’s a slick working wheel with proven and reliable technology.

author: CAShooter
title: Compatible with with PS3, PS4, PC
content:
While I;'m irritated that Sony changed their USB port to no longer allow the older racing wheels (G25, G27), this is a better setup. Even is backward compatible so I can still play my PS3 games as well as the new er PS4 games. Or use it with the PS4 as well as the PC.
Haven't tried it with the XBox. Probably will shortly. Racing software on the PS4 just isn't meeting expectations.

author: Sonnette
title: Excellent product
content: Steering and pedals are outstanding. Some are not thrilled with the brake pedal but I'd say it has a very good feel to it. Got them both for $300.

author: Khalid M. Al-Ghamdi
title: Very Very BAD Product
content:
I bought a new G29 from amazon last month and it only worked for 3 days until it totally broke down and went crazy spining right and left and I tried every possible solution and read alot regarding this issue but unfortunaly found that this problem is not new.
I am in contact with Amazon Service to return this piece of junk that cost me a fortune.
One star only for it to raise the issue but it actually deserves minus 10 stars

author: Astronomy buff
title: Works great in WIN 10 64bit
content:
Just received this since it dropped in price to $203.  Works great in WIN 10 64bit, Project Cars 2.  Downloaded the latest Logitech Gaming Software and it set up everything without any hassle.  I haven't plugged the G29 in to my PS4 yet so I'll update this review as I use the wheel.  The stiff brake pedal is no problem for me and I actually prefer it over a looser pedal;  to me it feels more like a brake pedal should.  I don't feel that I have to jam my foot that much harder but instead it gives me a much more progressive control over braking.  I upgraded from a Logitech Driving Force GT which still works great and has been a great wheel for me; I've had it for years, can't remember how long and it also worked flawlessly in WIN 10, so I'm hoping this wheel will last as long.  One tip I would give people concerning warranties; if you used a credit card to purchase many times your CC company will extend your warranty by as much as two years.  I use a VISA and they offer this.  So if your original warranty runs out your credit card company will probably offer you an extended warranty beyond the manufacturers.  Check it out on your CC company's website.  Also, sometimes they will price match in that if you find a price lower within 90 days they will reimburse you the difference.  I haven't used this service but it is stated on my CC company's website and I  have talked with a rep on the phone about it.  Do your homework and check out their website to see what they're providing you as a card holder.

Update June 30, 2018.  The Wheel still works great.  What I've found is that it doesn't like to be plugged in to any other USB other than the one I first installed it on.  The Logitech Gaming Software doesn't like this either so just plug in to the same USB  slot every time.  Also, in Project Cars 2 I actually had to assign the pedals to an axis before they would be recognized.  After assigning them they worked fine and I was able to calibrate.  I've been using the wheel a lot and feel it's been an upgrade from my Driving Force GT; which is also a great wheel that I'm going to hold on to.  I also still like the brake pedal the way it came and don't feel I have to remove it.  I have had no problems using it and I still prefer it over a less stiff pedal.  I still highly recommend this wheel and am having a great time using it.  If I have problems I'll update this review.

Update July 10 2018.  Wheel works great still.  I installed a USB 3.0 card in my computer and the LG29 plugged in to that with no problems.  However, when I booted up the computer today the wheel didn't power on and did not show up in the Log Gaming Profile.  I plugged it in to a USB 2.0 port and only the wheel was recognized, not the pedals.  I then plugged it in to the original USB 2.0 port when I first installed the wheel and everything came up recognized.  I think it likes to be plugged in to exactly the same port it was installed on.  Wheel still works great and I'm really enjoying it.  I believe this will work fine with USB 3.0, you just might have to unplug it and then plug it back in every time.  I'm choosing to keep it plugged in all the time to the original USB 2.0 port.

Update July 9, 2018:  Wheel works flawlessly on Win 10 and I'm able to plug it in to just about any USB port, both 2.0 and 3.0, and have it recognized.  Like any wheel you'll need to tune it to your liking.  I'm very happy with this wheel.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Works GREAT! no need to mod anything
content: I did not buy this from Amazon. I bought it from Dell.com for 100 dollars cheaper with shifter. Works GREAT! no need to mod anything. Breaks actually feels like real breaks! I just wish this company would make one vrs for all consoles and PC!

author: David A. Marlow Jr.
title: Racing Wheel...
content: This racing wheel is great, a lot of fun to use.

author: G.B.
title: Good, not perfect
content:
Original unit made a very high pitched noise when turning the wheel to the left. Return and replacement from Amazon was quick and painless. Second one did not make the high pitched noise. I've seen this problem in several reviews and forums. I was tempted to just live with it, almost didn't return as defective. Very glad the second unit did not have this issue (edit: it does after a couple of days)

Pedals and wheel are good for the price. Force feedback is strong except in the center for about 10 degrees, where there is none. I understand this is a design limitation based on the dual force feedback motors. It is very noticeable in a truck simulator, hardly noticeable at all in a rally racing game. Depends on what you are playing.

I would consider this wheel the "high end" of the video game controller spectrum. Not as good at all as the low end of the racing simulator spectrum, but you get what you pay for.

Update 4/27/17: second wheel started making the same squeaking noise when turning left after a couple of days. The noise is less consistent than the first. Also noticed the red toggle wheel is much stickier on this one and much less clicky, meaning less feedback to know how many clicks you've adjusted brake balance, engine braking, or whatever you have it set to. I will be keeping this unit but dropping to 3 stars due to inconsistent build quality and the squeaking noise.

author: Joan A Rosario
title: súper excelente
content: me estoy curando brutal

author: Kristi C.
title: Logitech G29 exceeded my expectations
content: Always wanted a wheel for my games, never bought one, didn’t want to be disappointed. Eventually decided on the G29, and let me tell you, i am thrilled with the purchase! For the price, quality and force feed back, for the ps4, you can’t beat the G29.

author: Jeff F
title: New or Really Repackage or Poorly Done Refurb?
content: Really disappointed to receive unit with a dead power supply and a shifter that is missing the notch for 6th gear.  I suspect this was repackaged or poorly done refurb.  I have contacted Logitech support, but this is a sad way to start.  Daughter was looking forward to learning how to drive this weekend with this and City Car Driving in VR.

author: Randall Muravez
title: Works great. Get a good stand.
content: Works with Xbox seamlessly.

author: William Marshall
title: Happy with the wheel but disappointed
content: I love the wheel and shifter. I replaced my Mad Catz wheel because it didn't have the clutch or shifter available. I'm disappointed that a week after I bought it the price is now $60 less.

author: Derek
title: Great quality
content: My son hasn't stopped playing. Love it. Easy set up..

author: James Parker
title: Five Stars
content: This is a really awesome wheel that great for Forza Assetto Corsa and the truck simulators

author: Tashdid S.
title: Very Good Product
content: The Logitech G920 was the first ever steering wheel I owned. I bought it for sim trucking and racing and I absolutely love it. The quality of the product is really good, the steering wheel is wrapped in leather, and the center portion of the wheel is a really durable metal. The software is really simple to use and you can tune your settings very easily. Only thing that I didn’t like was the brake pedal is very stiff. It’s really hard to brake with just the stock settings due to how hard it is. Besides that the steering wheel is amazing!

author: Tsunami
title: Great for gaming
content: Makes driving realistic

author: Pam
title: Very Nice Updated Version of the G27 but Needs Logitech Gaming Software Updates and/or Game Patches to Work Well on pc's
content:
I bought the G920 wheel and H shifter 3 weeks ago after my 4 year old G27 wheel stopped working. By the way, Logitech tech support in trying to troubleshoot my G27 wheel was not very good. The G920 wheel is basically an updated version of the G27 with new buttons, etc. to allow play on either pc or the Xbox. Both the wheel and the shifter are again well made and work well. I avoided the issue of the G920 having a stiffer brake pedal by simply continuing to use my G27 pedals which are identical. The H shifter appears to be interchangeable with the G27 too, however the extra game buttons on the G27 shifter don't work with the G920. Also as others have noted the G920 has a little white LED power light on the lower wheel spoke which is too bright and a distraction. I solved this with a small piece of black electrical tape with a tiny slot in it so I can just see the power light.

I'm using the G920 on a higher end Dell XPS 8500 desktop pc with core i7 and NVIDIA GeForce GT640. Again as others have noted using the G920 on a pc is not that easy. The wheel comes with the new Logitech Gaming Software which comes up with a new very nice graphic control panel and then automatically detects your games on first start up. But then creating a game profile and settings becomes much more complicated than with the old and much simpler profiler . . .I still haven't figured it out but have been able to use the wheel well with some games (e.g. NFS Shift and NFS Shift 2 Unleashed) by just programming the wheel within the game. Two apparent significant shortcomings in the new Logitech software are the inability to select separate or combined pedals and the inability to assign functions to the H shifter "buttons" 12 thru 18 (even though the H shifter is now a separate $60 purchase). I finally did find in the "Settings" option for the wheel that you can still set wheel degrees of rotation from 0 - 900.

Bottom line is that it is a very nice and well built wheel/pedal/shifter combination which is a pleasure to use for the games you can get it to work with. However, if you have a G27 that's still working I recommend staying with it until (hopefully) Logitech  makes some needed software changes to make the G920wheel more compatible with pc's.

UPDATE 2-21-16: Just added "Project Cars" to my racing game collection and am pleased to say the new G920 seems to be fully integrated and works great with this game, Logitech Gaming software picked it up immediately when scanned for new games. When I went to set up controls within the game the G920 was specifically recognized (including separate pedals and the "H" shifter) with the control assignment page even showing an exact replication of the G920 wheel and buttons.

author: Nick
title: Five Stars
content: excellent product

author: Colette
title: Five Stars
content: Kids love it and it durable!

author: Josh Wight
title: Absolutely perfect!
content: Great intermediate wheel!

author: James and Jessica Kane
title: Received previously returned item.
content: Product functioned and only had very slight bit of wear on it, but you could definitely tell it was returned from the wear and the fact that all pieces were unpacked and thrown in box.  Very dissatisfied to spend over $200 and receive used item.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Feels like the real thing.
content: Easy to plug in. Steering wheel feels like a real car. Response is dead on.

author: Stan
title: Not Ready For Prime Time on PC
content:
The Logitech G920 is supposed to work with the XBOX One and PCs running Windows 7, 8 and 10.  While there are many good reports regarding this wheel on the XBOX, using the wheel with a PC is another story.  Read the Logitech Community forums before buying this wheel for a PC.  Some folks have gotten it to work using games which communicate directly with the wheel and not a driver.  Presently, there is no good Windows driver for this wheel.  I believe the G29 has the same issue.  When contacted, Logitech has only offered non-solutions in spite of the out-cry from users since its release (9/2015).  I am sure that Logitech will address the problem eventually and is probably a fantastic product when they do.  However, I am done waiting and am returning the G920 for a refund.

Pros: Very nice build quality (which is why 2 stars and not 1).  That is all I can say since it is not working.

Cons: Does not work yet on a PC.

author: Jeremy
title: I enjoy it very much
content: As my first wheel, I enjoy it very much!!! I do a whole bunch of iracing, and it works great for that. The whole product feels high quality down to the metal pedals.

author: David
title: My experience
content: I bought one but every time you went to the left I would make a dislikeable noise and it was loud so I send it back got another one and the one I have right now makes the noise but not near as much as the other one but it work perfectly is just the noise that bothers me. I recommend this product if your not so picky and it a great product for beginners and for experienced users.

author: Krystian
title: Not a bad wheel, brake might be a little too stiff.
content:
This wheel is pretty good, especially when paired with the H-Shifter and works well on most of the major games. The only issue I have is a common one, which is the piece of rubber on the brake seems to not allow it to be given a good amount of braking range and can lead to a very stiff pedal. You can't take it out since it voids the warranty, but most games will not having you braking hard enough to hit full brakes thankfully.

Aside from that, overall, pretty happy with the G920.

author: Sammy
title: Great wheel
content: This wheel is great but not as good as thrustmaster but excellent for the price.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Five Stars
content: excellent product and price !!!

author: Colin
title: Wheel input stopped after one use
content: The wheel itself quit working after one use. I set everything up, had a great time playing Assetto Corsa in VR with it - then the next time I went to use it, the wheel does has no input at all. All the other buttons work fine, I didn't change any settings. I tried reinstalling the logitech software, tried different USB ports, restarting the game/PC, tried re-configuring the game's settings - but when you turn the wheel it just isn't even detected any more. I have read a number of reviews that say they experienced the same issue as me. It would seem that Logitech does not build items to the same quality as they used to.

author: Matthew Edwards
title: Great buy!
content: Great wheel! Love the force feedback. However motors inside can cause this wheel to be a bit noisy.

author: TavidS
title: ... for her son for his 12th birthday and He loved it!
content: I bought this for a friend of mine for her son for his 12th birthday and He loved it!! highly recommend...

author: Talihasi
title: Faulty product that should be removed from store shelves
content:
While it initially worked it randomly started pulling forcibly to the left in all games regardless of settings. Looking it up on the internet and it looks like thousands of reports of the same problems. In fact in less than the year I have owned it, I have suggested it to 7 people. All 7 now have none working steering wheels.
Whatever is going on with this wheel it needs to be pulled from the market. Logitech knows and has sense day one

author: David Efflandt
title: I thought I would get better control with a wheel than 1" thumbstick
content:
After trying DiRT Rally with my Logitech F710 gamepad for a while, which is more of a sim than an arcade game, I thought I would get better control with a wheel than 1" thumbstick. I ordered the G29 instead of G920 just because I liked the blue better than gray. I am a Linux PC user. The game did not recognize it in Linux, but recognized it as a G29 in Win7 and it worked great. Back to Linux and eventually I figured out that if I change it to an alternate mode in Linux from G29 to G27, DiRT Rally recognized it and I wrote a script to switch its mode and set lock to lock in degrees. Then everything worked including wheel with force feedback, paddle shifters, and all 3 pedals. So I am enjoying DiRT Rally with a lot better control and feedback of track surface. Linux DiRT Rally should support the G29 in its next update. Until then the Linux shell script to switch The G29 to G27 and set its range is posted in the Steam Linux Force Feedback (LinuxFF) group.

I cannot believe people disable the brake pedal resistance. Anyone who drives a real car knows that the brake pedal has resistance when you get to a certain point and that if you stand on the brake 100% you are likely to lock up your tires (unless you have ABS). And any sensible game should have settings to set at what range you get 100% braking if you want that to happen with less pressure. But I like it the way it is, have ABS disabled in DiRT Rally, and still occasionally lock up my tires if I am too hard on the brakes. But I am familiar with threshold braking without ABS in real competition driving, so that suits me fine, I simply know to ease up on the brake if the wheels start to lock.

So Logitech racing wheels may not be inexpensive, but add to the realism of racing if the game gets it right. That does not mean that you will not crash, but eventually you will become a better driver with finer control.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Like it

author: John Scott Cosgrove

content:
I had some concerns about the quality given some of the reviews.  However, since I had a very positive experience with the prior version model (which won't work with the PS4 - licensing issue) I decided to buy it.  After using it for over 30 hours, it works very well.  A solid improvement over my previous version.  BTW, it has a switch that allows you to use it with PS3 as well.

The primary reason I bought it was to use with Gran Turismo Sport.  It does the job very well!  Highly recommend it.

author: S.BOS
title: NOT WIRELESS TO XBOX ONE...SAD TECH!!!!
content: Ok seriously, these guys could not figure out a way to make this wireless to the xbox one? I understand that they need one from the wheel to the peddles but a standard connection to the xbox one should not require a USB. Thinking of returning.

author: Dejah S.
title: So many settings!
content:
I cannot believe how many settings this thing has.  You can control the resistance of the wheel and the pedals, force feedback, and everything.  I got it as a gift and he absolutely loves it.  It was incredibly easy to install with its clamp, and the whole thing feels very well made.

We have noticed some lag in response time, but we did some research on this.  It turns out, the problem is with the game, and not the controller.  So please be mindful of the possibilities in lag when you make this purchase, or even for your future racing games.

author: Elton
title: The G29 the wheel you need
content: The G29 Wheel is great it made my racing and driving games more enjoyable.

author: Jay Robinson
title: Was an amazing setup until it stopped working after a few months
content:
Got this as a gift, and I had never been more thrilled to be given something! I had an amazing time with this wheel, and the Logitech quality was thorough. The force feedback is way stronger than you think, too! This thing could pretty much pull me out of place! But I only had it for about 6 months until it stopped working. It's got the shift lights all illuminated and the green light is blinking. The pedals and shifter work, but the steering axis and feedback don't. As far as I can tell from the internet, this is a power delivery issue. But no matter where I plug it in or reset all the places it connects, it still won't work...
UPDATE: I have since bought a new power supply, which did nothing but cost me another $20. Very disappointed, especially since Logitech won't warranty an item for me as I wasn't the purchasee. I'm hoping they at least respond to this review, but it's doubtful.

author: John B Claeys
title: Insane accuracy
content: I've just started using my wheel. I'm amazed at the realistic responsiveness of the wheel to the corresponding content on the screen. You feel every pump of the pavement. The brake pedal has extra pressure to make it feel like you're pushing hard on the brakes to slow the car enough to get through a corner. I've only spent one afternoon using it but it was well worth the price.

author: jose l.
title: Good Entry, Good Daily. Buy If You Can!
content:
Pros:
Good Force Feedback
Easy To Setup
Perfect For Beginners

Cons:
Makes Loud Noise From Motor Through Use
Doesn’t Come With Shifter (Not Much A Con)
Some Games Don’t Work With It (Ehh)

This wheel is amazing for entry people and can even be used by people who actually compete. From personal use, I enjoy this wheel a lot. I’ve owned this wheel twice, first time it was used and the second was from Amazon brand new. You can tell the the motors do wear out from use but it’s very minimal. When I purchased this wheel, I was expecting either a used or refurbished wheel but I got a new wheel for less than $200 including shipping & tax. If you are looking to purchase this wheel, I’d say do it. You won’t regret it.

Theres a reason the price dropped 50%  because everyone is having the same issue. Save your mkney do some research and find a better wheel. And also.. dont buy anything expensive from amazon. Lately their customer service is lacking big time between the wait time and employees literally not know what the hell to do. Go to ali baba. Shipping time is a couple weeks but the products always come as described and believe it or not,  its easier to get through to these guys in china than it is to these mooks at amazon

author: Brian E Beaty
title: My kid loves this

The only comment I have about it is that it self-calibrates often and with little warning (the steering wheel will rotate itself around), and it makes a bit of noise while doing so. If you aren't going to be actively using it, unplug it

author: T. Howard
title: $349 at Best Buy without shipping costs
content: This was a good deal at $350 with free shipping and I was about to buy it off Amazon but they started to gouge people with the price. If you pay $500 with shipping for this wheel you are getting a terrible deal. It's a solid wheel that requires some setup to get it exactly how you want it. The pedals are mediocre though. It's worth $350 max. At $500 you can get some other wheels that have better pedals like the thrust master VG TX. I still have it 4 stars but that's at a reasonable price. If you have $500 to spend is suggest you keep shopping and take a good look at a thrust master VG setup which allows you to upgrade to different wheels and pedals and their shifter is superior than the Logitech. I like the Logitech but only if it's $ 100 less than the VG TX.

author: Diesel
title: it is a good wheel!

author: JetDriveSolutions
title: They fixed my issue
content:
*EDIT* The issue has been resolved. Thanks.

Huge disappointment. Doesn't work on Windows 10 computers. Nobody that I know who has this wheel is having any luck with installing it to their Windows devices. Great f****** job Logitech.

author: Befragt
title: I love it!
content:
I'll preface this by saying that I've never had, or even used, a driving wheel for a home video game before.  That said, I love this racing wheel - it absolutely changes the experience for any racing game.

First off, I'd note that this isn't some flimsy plastic contraption - it's a solidly built wheel, made of metal and wrapped in genuine leather - just like a real steering wheel.  The pedals are similarly realistic - while they aren't totally identical to those I use with my stick-shift car, they are a really good approximation, and they are pressure sensitive to boot.  It rather seems that the only difference between braking when playing Xbox and braking my car is that I don't fly forward when braking using the racing wheel!  One caution is that the pedal pad can slip when you are applying a lot of force - I have a nice rug under my unit, but if you have hardwood or vinyl flooring you might want to consider how to anchor the unit.  Also, make sure that you have a decently heavy table or other surface to anchor the wheel itself to - otherwise it will go all over the place.

Shifting - there is a separate stick shift unit that costs another $69 or so, not included with the racing wheel itself.  Why - I don't know - this unit costs enough already.  Anyway, I guess because this is an "authentic" race car simulator, shifting is accomplished using paddle shifters to go up or down, in connection with the clutch pedal, of course.  This works well, and again, I guess it's authentic because some race cars use paddle shifters, but I prefer a separate stick shift myself.  I'm just not in the mood to shell out additional cash for that.

Perhaps the coolest feature of this wheel is the way it provides "force feedback" - when you turn during a race, the wheel reacts as if you were really in a car driving over that terrain - so it can "fight you" or whatever.  Very cool.  The force feedback is transformative - it really makes driving games more engaging and realistic.  A "wow" experience.  And it seems to really help the times and experience as well.  When you go off the course or collide, the wheel can really jerk around.  Sure, it's not like you're in a car getting thrown around, but it really does change the dynamic.

I'd note that there are stands that you can purchase for this wheel as well.  I obviously don't have one, but if you're a SERIOUS gamer I think that's definitely something to consider - the peddles and the steering wheel can shift in the heat of game play - but its also a significant additional expense.

In all, I can truly say that the Logitech wheel is awesome.  At a price that's almost equal to that of an Xbox unit itself, however, you need to ask just how serious you are about racing games before taking the plunge.

Now, I use this wheel with Forza 6.  Initially, it was a pain in the butt to deal with - Forza 6 didn't make it easy to set the wheel up.  So eventually I learned that you had to play enough games that an "option" menu appeared.  Then you need to exit Forza 6, make sure the wheel is plugged in and recognized by the Xbox One, and restart Forza 6.  You then need to use the wheel to start up, and you need to go to the options menu and make sure the wheel is recognized.  From there, you're good to go.  But it was a frustrating pain in the ____ to deal with.  Not Logitech's fault, by the way.

Forza 6 does allow a lot of customization for the wheel.  I am not that serious of a racer, so I haven't done that yet, but the option is there.

I can say this - every one of my kids' friends who comes over is entranced by the wheel.  So the only downside is that we have a steady stream of kids headed to our basement to play.  I guess there are worse problems to have.

author: Lorinna S.
title: Great wheel

author: Larry Ray
title: Great Beginner Wheel
content:
Logitech G29 Review.

I have always been curious about the G29 and now that my girls are older at age 9, I wanted to add some distraction to their existing hobbies and lead them into the fun of sim racing.

I remember my first wheel experience wasn’t that great back in the day. We didn’t have sim rigs, we had TV stands or you slide the wheel desk under your legs and the pedal tray kept moving around on you. It would have been great but I returned my first unit and opted for the friendly PS controller.

Fast forward to Forza when the new Microsoft XBOX 360 wheel came out. I tried it and really loved it. The pedal desk stayed in place on carpet, I had a desk to clamp the wheel to and it was a blast. I then ventured into a Playseat with it and fast forward many years I’m not in a full PC setup with DD wheel, motion, transducers, VR, and widescreen monitor. My hobby really envolved, but it all really started with the XBOX 360 wheel with it’s simplicity of plug and play and just plain working with enough FFB ques to make it fun.

Now my girls are getting into Sim Racing or at least show interest so I’m starting with w Logitech G29 for their first ride!

So….I spent about 1 week with the Logitech G29 and for its price point of $208 on Amazon, I find it’s a really great buy. I mean you really can’t go wrong with it. It’s low price, looks great, works great and want to twist my kid's arms off while using it.

Let's get into the complete review, shall we?

First up….

Aesthetics:
• Good looking wheelbase and pedals for the price of $208 on Amazon
• Love the smell of the leather rim
• Love the metal pedals
• Has a real plastic and toy-like feel in person.

Build:
• Quality construction with some heft to the wheelbase and pedals.
• Metal brake & Shifter pedals
• Hand-stitched Leather Rim
• Adequate pedal resistance in all 3 pedals.
• Surprisingly quiet operation.
• Helical Gearing has some cogging, but really smooth

Features:
• PS3, PS4, and PC Compatible
• Hard mount option
• Desk mount solution
• Should work on XBOX One with the Collective Minds Drivehub
• 900° rotation
• 2.2 NM of Torque
• LED indicator
• 14 pushbuttons, plus Dpad, rotary dial and paddle shifters.
• 3 pedal kit with the clutch, simulated load cell rake pedal(not a true load cell) and throttle

Pros:
• Low-cost entry wheel kit solution for PS3, PS4 and PC use.
• Don’t need an elaborate or expensive sim rig to use. Mount to wheel stand or desk
• Light enough to be portable to friends house along with your PS4
• Good FFB effects for curbing, wheel slip and wheel centering in games like Assetto Corsa and PCARS 2. GT Sport has weak FFB with this wheel, but it also does with others I tested.
• Plug and Play. No PC updates needed, everything just works out of the box.
• The mass majority of racing game that supports wheels already have Logitech G29 wheel support natively.
• Light enough forces to not hurt younger kids when in use.
• Hard mount and desk mount solutions. Desk mount clamp actually works.

Cons:
• Carpet ant-slide doesn’t really work. Need to add a block behind the pedals to keep from moving.
• The slight dead zone in the middle of the wheel before feeling forces.

Thoughts.

I bought this wheel kit for my kids to get into sim racing and to play with GT Sport for myself. I didn’t want to spend to much just to play GT Sport and my kids certainly at age 9 do not need the heavy wheel forces of a Fanatec CSL and others like it.

I was still disappointed with the FFB in GT Sport, but that’s defiantly a factor from the game itself, not the G29. Even with my Fanatec Clubsport V2 with a Drivehub, GT Sport FFB was very disappointing. At least with the G29, you don’t break the bank for such limited experience. It’s a shame because GT Sport is very fun, just lacking in FFB and feel compared to even PCARS2.

Speaking of PCARS 2. On my PC I tested PCARS2 and Assetto Corsa Competizione and both games didn’t disappoint with the G29. Sure they are not wrist breaking forces but did offer up plenty of curb feel, wheel slip and centering spring to have me turning fast laps around the track as if I was using a higher-end wheel. Plus all the button controls just worked. No mapping needed.

For the price of $208 on Amazon, I highly recommend this wheel for newcomers to sim racing for PS4 or PC usage.

author: Chris P.
title: Overpriced wheel hampered by subpar pedals.
content:
I owned this Xbox One wheel for fourteen days before returning it to Best Buy. Instead, I'm using a Thrustmaster VG TX Racing Wheel Leather Edition wheel/pedal set for Xbox One and PC I purchased here on Amazon(Thrustmaster VG TX Racing Wheel Leather Edition Premium Official Xbox One Racing Wheel for Xbox One and PC), which I absolutely love.

And now for why I can’t recommend the Logitech G920: the pedals are just not up to par. Upon unboxing the Logitech I was blown away with how the wheel and pedals looked. The leather wrapped aluminum wheel is a thing of beauty and feels great in the hands, although it is a little small for my tastes, giving it more the feeling of a toy rather than a true racing sim wheel. Once I hooked everything up to my Playseat and got all my advance wheel settings configured in Forza 6, I noticed that the force feedback and vibration through the wheel felt pretty good, however, modulating brake and acceleration through the pedals was difficult as it is very hard to get a feel for the braking. If I was coming from a cheaper wheel/pedal set with no adjustability of the brake pedal I probably would be none the wiser, but I’m coming from a Fanatec CSR Wheel and CSR Elite pedals from Xbox 360, which was a great wheel and pedal set that allows the user to adjust the backpressure of the brake pedal using a spring adjustment behind the pedal. This Logitech G920 has no brake adjustment on the pedal itself, so you are left with the predetermined brake damper setting from the factory with no adjustment similar to cheaper wheels on the market, which is a shame because the pedals look really nice. It’s like Logitech created an awesome Xbox wheel, then threw some pedals in the box and called it a day. At this price point, they should have put a little more thought into the pedals. This Logitech is just not a four hundred dollar wheel/pedal set. At most, it should have been priced at two-fifty to three hundred dollars.

Again, I can’t recommend this Logitech wheel but I can recommend the Thrustmaster VG TX Racing Wheel Leather Edition wheel/pedal set, which costs for just a few dollars more than the (over-priced) Logitech. The Thrustmaster is a much better buy as it allows for fine brake adjustment using an included conical brake mod that screws in just behind the brake pedal. The Thrustmaster servo base itself is quite substantial and seems heavier than the combined Logitech G920 wheel and base it is attached to. The Thrustmaster leather racing wheel feels great and is slightly larger (and hence less toy-like) than the Logitech G920 wheel, and the Thrustmaster set even allows you to switch out the wheel and/or pedals with a number of alternative offerings from Thrustmaster if you so desire. For seventy dollars (at press time) more than the Logitech, you’re getting a whole heck of a lot more product with the Thrustmaster, and it seems to be a bit more substantial product that will last longer as well. Happy racing!

author: Ridge
title: Terrible wheel, or I got a badly built one.
content:
What absolute Garbage...
When I first got wheel and set it up, I noticed the clips that attach to your table had a crack on it, and I didn't think much about it and I should have sent it back because I was drifting in forza 7 and the clip broke off when I was turning the wheel so now it can't stay on the table.

The wheel worked flawlessly when I got it, not a single problem.
But after about 3 days of use. I could hear a grind sound when I turned the wheel to the left, but not to the right. And it seemed to get a delay or possible short in Wires...

The last thing I have to complain about is the stick.
The way it was designed is horrible, you're not able to rest your hand on the shifter at all when shifting or it locks you out of gears.
For example if you put pressure on it pushing it down, it locks you in 1st and second only, 3rd and 4th, and 5th and 6th (reverse)
And after a couple of days the shifter wobbled in the gears a bunch.

I'm just ungodly disappointed in this product, I've always liked Logitech products, but this let me down big time.
Especially since I spent 300 of my hard earned dollars on this junk.

author: meagan parson
title: Not the racing wheel we grew up with in the 90's
content: Incredible racing wheel and pedal set. Most realistic feel I've ever felt outside of an automobile. It takes a couple dedicated hours of playing with your setup to get it dialed in but once its there, WOW. It's not the same experience at all. Totally new kind of gaming experience and the most realistic feeling drive sim you can find for this price point. The feedback is amazing. Strong enough that you really feel like you're fighting a car but so precise and delicate that you can tell at the very point in which you start to lose grip. Minus the g-forces felt in your own body when driving, this is as close at it comes outside of super pricey sim setups. I'd HIGHLY recommend getting a seat/stand combo or something similar. Sitting otherwise, is pretty uncomfortable but still doable. Stop debating on getting a wheel and snag this baby. Whether you are someone who games casually and looking for a way to up your racing games, or someone who competes online in esports racing leagues, this wheel has something to offer. I'm upset at myself for debating on it for so long now that i see how much fun it is!

author: ConstantReader
title: Good for the price range
content:
A couple of warnings to readers; this was my first racing wheel and therefore I will not be comparing the G29 to other racing wheels, this review is based purely on its own merit. As of this review I have used it only on the PS3, I may post an updated review once I have it set up on PS4 and PC.  The only thing I will say compared with other racing wheels is that I looked up the prices and this seem to be the best one in its price range (in other words you get a lot for your money).
The G29 force racing wheel from Logitech is overall a great buy if you are willing to pay as much as an actual console costs and like racing simulators and driving simulators.
Pros: The materials are of good quality and the wheel and pedals are very sturdy. The buttons are in a good layout and easy to press when holding the wheel from any normal steering wheel hand position. The G29 is very responsive to the various button presses and turns in-game. It gives a good amount of feedback and once setup, the vibration and feedback are easily adjustable. Cons: The G29 was very hard to set up on the PS3, it took a good hour before I got it working in-game. It also requires a different kind of setup for each game; some games don’t require any setup, others take a very specific set of steps to get it to work. It isn’t compatible with every game. Based on the controls and instructions it should be much easier to set up on the PS4, however at this moment, I still haven’t been able to set it up with PC. The vibration starts out set at too high a setting and if you don’t like a lot of feedback from the steering wheel, you may want a different one. It doesn’t come with a chair, you have to buy one separately for the same price as the wheel, but that is again, very inexpensive for what it is.
Overall, I think if you want a racing wheel that is fairly inexpensive, is solidly made, has good response and feedback, and you are willing to spend some time getting it set up, get the G29. But if you are willing to buy it, I suggest getting the racing seat accessory as well.

author: Yvette
title: By far the best one yet
content: I had the G25, G27 and now the G29. By far the best one yet. Response is INSTANT when using with Gran Turismo. So glad I didnt hit the "cancel order" button. Well worth the price and qualoty build is perfect.

author: Hunter Warrior
title: Superb racing wheel for the PS4
content:
The Logitech G29 racing wheel is the first wheel that I have owned. I have tried some racing wheels in friends place and stores but none has been able give me an experience as immersive and satisfied as the G29.

My first impression of the G29 racing wheel is its hefty, quality construction. The leather wrapped steering wheel feels sturdy and comfortable. The feedback feels tactile and realistic. The button layout is neat and easily accessible. It features all the buttons on the DualShock 4 controller, minus the touchpad.

The floor pedals are superb. They are constructed of brushed metal and appear to be durable. They have realistic resistance and require a different amount of pressure to press down. Specifically, the brake pedal has a non-linear feel to it that resembles the brake of a real car. In fact, they all have a feel that is pretty close to real deal - the brake pedal feels like a real brake pedal, and the accelerator pedal feels like a real accelerator pedal.

I have hooked up the racing wheel to my PS4 and given the Project CARS and Driveclub a good spin. The overall experience is on a totally different level from that using a DualShock 4 controller. The force feedback is pretty realistic, on par with if not better than that on the older Logitech racing wheels that I had tried before. However, I didn't find the shift/RPM indicator lights on the wheel particularly useful since I would have been fixing my eyes on the screen anyway. The paddle shifters are just decent. They have a somewhat odd and plasticky feel to it. There is certainly room for improvement.

Unlike its predecessor G27, the G29 doesn't come with a stick shifter. which is now a separately sold accessory for $60. For a racing wheel costing as much as the PS4, you would think it would include a stick shifter like the G27 did. This is a real bummer. While the G29 is well made, it is not substantially better than the G27 in terms of bill of materials that they had to exclude the stick shifter in order to keep the cost down. I have been using the paddle shifters now and don't really miss the stick shifter. Still, it would have been a nice gesture for Logitech to include the stick shifter in the first place, as they did in the G27.

All in all, the G29 is a very nice racing wheel. It is well made and sturdy. It makes the overall racing experience so much more immersive and enjoyable to play. It is pricey but it adds a new level of realism that isn't comparable with that using a regular controller. The absence of the stick shifter is a disappointment (perhaps I may purchase it sometime down the road just to complete the experience). Anyway, the G29 is an excellent racing wheel that I am happy to have.

author: Grimmy
title: A nice wheel with much force
content:
There are a lot of low ratings for this item, but they seem to be complaints about a couple of things: lack of PC support for the previous model, inability to use the previous model on the PS4 (not Logitech's fault), lack of shifter on this model (not reviewing this item per se but a complaint based on comparison to the old model). While these frustrations are understandable, they don't answer the question: What about this item?

There's a switch on the top of the wheel to, er, switch between PS3 and PS4. If you don't set this right, you'll notice funny things happening or not happening.

This is a nice looking and well-built set. The solid pedals feel like the real thing as far as comparing brake and gas pedal resistance and travel. The wheel is also well built, with a nice leather cover - nicer than my real car! However, the triangle button placement seems a little out of reach for quick access to reverse. Those of you who don't crash as much as I am doing will not mind, though.

As noted, there is no shifter included. This can be annoying as you have to shell out some more moolah for that, but you could use the steering wheel paddles in the meantime. The paddles are solid, but they are a bit rough around the edges, and could have used more rounding. Sometimes in the heat of the wheel jerking all over you may feel a bit of a bite - no blood, but not as comfortable as it could be. Possibly this mimics the real thing, and is not an issue for "real" drivers as they wear gloves, I don't know.

There are 13 mappable buttons on this thing. Wowza. Note that GT5 does not seem to provide a way to map these unless you try the G27 setttings, which are not quite the same.

The interior machinery on this thing is metal, which should make this a more durable wheel than others which use plastic, and the force is strong in this one. Yes, it can produce a LOT of torque. If attached to a small, lightweight table it will verily yank it around (in combination with the force you exert). Even attached to a normal desk you may find the friction screws loosening after a while. (Note that they include small attachments for thinner desks (preinstalled) which you may have to remove.) You can get a stand to remedy this, and I suppose you will if you're hard-core: Racing Steering Wheel Stand for Logitech G27/G25, G29 and G920 Wheels, Deluxe, Original Wheel Stand Pro Stand. Wheel and Pedals Not included.. Or a seat: Openwheeler Racing Wheel Stand Cockpit Blue/Black | For Logitech G29 | G920 and Logitech G27 | G25 | Thrustmaster Wheels | Racing wheel & controllers NOT included. These may work better.

You will have to attach a power cable and a couple of USB cables. Why isn't this wireless? I suppose it would end up costing more, with minor lag, although no lag is minor in racing games. So it's a tradeoff.

All in all, considering this set for all it's supposed to be, this is a great racing wheel. The couple of minor annoyances can be remedied with a separate shifter, which unfortunately is not included. It produces strong force when needed, should be durable, mostly feels good, and looks great besides.

author: djeclipse25

content:

The unit is spendy, and for that price Logitech should have included a headphone jack. Having to use another controller has caused me to drop my controller and ruin the USB port :( when I was spirialling out of control and was trying to correct for it LOL
It's adds a whole new level of realism, and fun to gaming.
I love this thing, and would definitely recommend buying this though I have not compared to the competitors, I am quite satisfied with it's performance.

author: J Steven
title: Excellent entry-level wheel for the aspiring sim racer
content:
I bought this wheel along with the compatible shifter attachment. Originally I was going to play Assetto Corsa, but I have more recently gotten into the Dirt Rally games. Both are "simulators" rather than the more arcade-y feel of the likes of Forza or Gran Turismo. It is definitely compatible with all of the above.

Force feedback is a per-game thing for sure. Each game has their own settings you can configure and it can be difficult to get the same feel the way you want it in each game. It does work great for me. The wheel and shifter mounted well on to my table, although you have to refrain from pulling the wheel "up" since the back end of it will rise. Granted that's not something you should be doing anyway, but it can be a kind of beginner mistake when getting used to driving with a wheel.

The shifter when treated too roughly can come away from the table, even when latched on tightly. (Your mileage may vary). I recommend that you lightly "flick" from gear to gear as opposed to wrenching it around like you would on a real gear shifter. The paddle shifters also work as advertised although I prefer the actual shifter.

Overall I would recommend this wheel to anyone getting into sim racing and doesn't want to shell out a lot for the most premium wheel offerings out there. Don't let "entry-level" scare you away, this is a high-quality racing wheel and it does the job very well.

author: aman singh

author: Chad
title: Great wheel once you mod the brake pedal
content:
I really like this wheel, though I wish I didn't have to buy it. I already have a Logitech g27 with the shifter that cost quite a bit less than this wheel without the shifter. I realize this isn't a review about the price though, so I'll move on and talk about the wheel.

First, the setup for the wheel really could not have been easier on my Xbox One or my PC. I hooked it up to my Xbox first. I plugged it in and it worked. I didn't have to do anything else for the xbox to recognize it. I launched Forza 6, set the steering option to "Simulation" and I was good to go! I ended up tweaking the deadzones in forza a bit more to my liking, but that was just software settings, and small ones at that.

For my PC, I downloaded and installed the latest Logitech gaming software before I plugged the USB cable into the PC. Once it was installed, I plugged in the USB cable, the wheel spun around a bit and it was ready to go. I launched Assetto Cora and to my surprise, found a premade config for the Logitech g920 with and without the shifter. I selected the one without the shifter, went into the controller setup wizard, and all controls responded perfectly. I don't know if I had to go into the controller setup wizard, but I did just in case. After that, I launched a race (in manual shifting mode) and ran a few laps around Mugello just to see how it was. There were no issues at all. Everything worked just as you would expect.

For anyone that has ever owned a Logitech g27, you will instantly be familiar with this wheel. It feels very much the same, but with the extra buttons for the xbox control. The wheel is the same size, though it now has a flat bottom The leather feels great, just like it did on the g27.  Even the wheel base is identical to the g27. This is a good thing because that was rock solid on everything I clamped it to. A noticeable difference from the g27 is that the wheel no longer has the LED shift indicator lights. I understand that xbox games may not support this, but it would be nice to still be able to use them for PC games.

The wheel itself is very quiet. I can't imagine anyone having any complaints about the noise from this. One minor thing I don't like about the wheel is the LED light just above the xbox button. It's REALLY bright. I ended up putting some black electrical tape over it and you can still see the light through the tape!

The pedals look exactly the same as the g27 but with black pistons instead of red. One thing about he pedals though, as you can see in almost every review out there, is that the brake pedal is amazingly stiff. So stiff that I had to put the back of my chair up against my couch to keep from pushing myself backwards just to get the car to slow down at all. I've never driven an F1 race car, but I have never had to press any brake pedal as hard as this one to get 100% travel. It was ridiculously stiff. This is all because of a small piece of rubber that is inserted into the break pedal spring to give it "progressive" pressure. In reality, it ended up being almost no pressure to start with, then a massive amount of pressure from about 20% all the way to 100%. It was not gradual at all. You could clearly tell when the pedal hit the rubber. Real break pedals don't work like that. After 2 hours of racing, my foot hurt and all I could think about during the race is preparing myself to brake HARD on the next corner.

It is a simple fix though (see my photos). *Doing this will void your warranty.* It took me about 20 minutes to take the base apart, take the piece of rubber out of the spring, and put it all back together. This made an amazing difference. All three pedals now feel exactly like the pedals on the g27. The brake pedal is still more stiff than the accelerator or clutch, but not so stiff that it's almost useless. After a few laps, I had stopped thinking about braking and just started thinking about racing again.

To the credit of the pedal base though, it stuck to my carpet like crazy. I easily pushed my chair backwards but the base never slid a bit. It stuck to my carpet like crazy.

This could have been a 5 star rating if I didn't have to mod it to get the brake pedal to work normally and if it had the shifter included. You can use the g27 shifter with this wheel, but I plan on selling my g27 and I can't really sell it without the shifter.

The only thing I hate, and is almost a deal breaker for me, if it weren't for such an easy fix, is the break pedal. I don't know how that stiff PoS made it through QA but with a simple mod(buying a spring or remove the little rubber piece in the pedal) does the trick and allows you to actually not kill your pedal and your leg when trying to brake. Everything else on the wheel it of top quality. Paddles feel great, wheel is well stitched, and the base feels well built. I will never play a racing game without a wheel again!

author: MrMister
title: You'll never want to go outside again.
content:
Most fun toy I have ever purchased for myself. I use this product in conjunction with Project CARS for Xbox One, and Forza Motorsport 6 for Xbox One. Both games give an incredible amount of feedback to the driver as to what the car is doing. I've driven many cars in my day (albeit none of them have been race machines by any means), and this wheel accurately provides torque steer, sensations of understeer and oversteer, and the sensation of a car getting squirrely under hard braking. There is a minimal deadzone at top-dead-center of the wheel, and just about any function of the wheel you do not like you can change within the advanced settings of a game. The pedals feel great. At first, I hated the brake pedal, as it has a conical piece of rubber within the spring to give it non-linear travel, but after adjusting the inside/outside deadzone for the brake to 1/55, it feels great, and no longer requires sliding my chair back to stop a car. That brings up another +1 for this wheel; the pedals have a little claw on the front that grips carpet -- I couldn't get them to budge under hard braking.

The wheel can not provide anything without the direction from a game, so I cannot review the wheel with anything other than PCARS and FM6. I would assume that on a game like Need For Speed, Forza Horizons (1&2), or any other arcade-style game, it would feel cheesy and unrealistic, as those games are cheesy and unrealistic. BE WARNED: It took me (a fairly tech-savvy guy) about 3 hours to set up, calibrate, and dial in the wheel and pedals and their respective deadzones and other settings with Project CARS. It is a very immersive game. You can adjust every parameter of the wheels performance with the game, and to be honest you have to before it's any fun: It is most definitely NOT plug 'n' play. Now that I have it dialed in, though, it is much more fun than Forza. On Forza however, it is simple. You start up the game plug in the wheel, and voila, you're ready to rock. It works incredibly well. The only parameter I adjusted was the brake (as I stated above), and the "rumble", which felt a little too violent for my glass table. This is the game I would start the wheel with, just because it is so easy to set up. Get yourself hooked on the idea of a wheel before you commit to screwing with Project CARS.

All in all, it's a great buy. Quality construction, good table clamps, easy to use, fun, quiet, and it's made by Logitech so I'm sure if anything goes wonky with it, it would be a simple phone call to get help/parts/replacements/etc. I could've been happy with a little more diameter of the wheel, and I think that for the money they could've included the shifter, but hey, if you were running the business you'd do the same thing.

Buy it.

Tell your wife and kids you're sorry, but you can't see them for a week.

Play this for a week.

Be happy.

author: Drew K
title: Great for the entry-level sim racer who wants to start getting serious
content:
INTRO:  Buying this wheel was a big deal for me.  About 6 months prior, I had decided to make sim racing into a hobby and buy a wheel again.  Dirt: Rally was kind of what prompted it, but iRacing is life now.  When I started shopping for wheels I had my eyes on a G27, but winter is kind of slow in my line of work, so I planned to buy one the following spring.  That winter, to my great chagrin, the G27 was discontinued following the release of the G29, and prices doubled.  So I decided to get a G29, and jumped on a $100 off sale that spring.  I almost wish I would have gotten the G920 for PS4 compatibility rather than XONE, but I still haven't bothered with either of those consoles so that shows how much that matters to me.

IMPRESSIONS:  On first impressions, the package as a whole looks and feels nice.  The leather and brushed aluminum look great.  Very similar to a G27, just a little more sleek and modern looking.  Mechanically, it at least feels like it was made with better materials than my old Microsoft FFB wheel.  I've never used a Fanatec wheel, so I can't compare the G29 to the best, but I have no complaints about my G29.  The FFB, pedals, and shifter all feel well-made, with the shifter being perhaps the weakest link.  The knob and leather boot are a nice touch, but the shift gates feel somewhat cheap and plastic.  Glad I paid $100 less to soften the blow of buying the shifter separately.

FUNCTIONALITY/SETUP: Setup is fairly easy.  It has clamps underneath to secure to a desk or table, and holes for mounting screws.  I made a custom ramp box to mount my pedals at an angle and secure them.  Eventually I will buy or build a rig to mount everything to, but for now I have a board behind the pedal box to hold it in place.  If you're on carpet, the pedals have a spike strip you can deploy, but I wouldn't trust it with adult legs.  If I make sure to screw the clamps down tightly, I don't have issues with the wheel or shifter coming loose, though it did happen a few times early on, which can be disastrous (not to mention hilarious as you maneuver to a safe spot with the wheel in your lap).

BOTTOM LINE:  This is a good enough wheel for the price.  You might be able to get a decent Thrustmaster for less, but I have no experience with those.  I went with the G29 because it was the successor to the G27, and the G27 seemed to be the most popular wheel of its generation.  As an entry-level sim racer, I think this was the perfect wheel for me to buy.  Some day I will spring for a Fanatec kit and buttkickers, etc. but I am very happy with this one for now.  I have been using it damn near every day for a little over a year now, and it shows no signs of wear.  If I wipe everything down it still looks and works like it's brand new.  -1 star because it's almost twice the price of a G27, with more features removed than added.  C'est la vie, it's probably still the best wheel under $500.

author: Amazon Customer
title: My first Force Feedback wheel and love it, whish I had gotten one sooner
content: My first Force Feedback wheel and love it, whish I had gotten one sooner. Many complain about the brake pedal feel and personally like the feel of the resistance it gives.

author: Ivy Reisner
title: Mindblowing!
content:
I've always liked racing games.  I can't say they were ever my favorite genre, but I enjoy them.  I played Forza 4 on the 360 with an economy wheel and had a splendid time of it.

Playing Forza 6 with this was an entirely different experience.  My hands were shaking; my heart was pounding.  It has been a long time since a game did that to me.  The wheel fights like a real wheel.  You go into a skid and you need to struggle that wheel to go where you want.  It's not so much strength as skills, and it's amazing.  If you release the wheel slightly, like you might in a real car after a turn, it rights itself exactly as a real car will.  It turns pretty much as much as a real car's wheel will in any direction.

You can, of course, attach it to a table or something like -- it connects with a small clamp tightened by two knobs on top that look like buttons (twist them if you're having trouble and the clamps with slowly descend or ascend)  but if you're going to go with a wheel of this quality, you may want to go all the way with a wheel stand.  It makes a difference in comfort and stability.  On the folding table I tried the table tipped, the whole thing shifted around, and it was bad.  With even an entry level stand, so long as it has a board to clamp this too, it is perfect.

If you want the most intense racing experience possible, you want this wheel.  There are cheaper out there, but the quality difference is severe.

author: A. Roller
title: May Be Ok For Kids I Guess....
content: I wasn't sure what to expect when I started looking into steering wheels, pedals and gearshifters for my computer.  I figured surely they were just about the same as the real life thing.  Boy was I wrong.  The steering wheel is smaller, makes it uncomfortable for adults to use.  The pedals are too close together, also makes it very awkward and not user friendly at all, if you're an adult.  Not to mention, I used the first time and then after that I couldn't get to work again.  I'm sure it was something minor that I needed to do on my part, because it came on, it just wasn't detecting it in game, and or initializing correctly.  Anyways, this was not anything what I expected so I ended up sending it back.  I typically really like Logitech peripherals,  but this is unacceptable.  I use a Logitech G Pro keyboard and mouse, and they are great!  Have used Logitech components for several years, heck I'd say probably 15 years or more, and never have had an issue with them, however I'm sad to say the Logitech G29 Racing Wheel needs some serious work done to satisfy the average gamer.  Make your steering wheel actual size for one, I'm not sure why you wouldn't.  Also the pedals, make them about what they would be in a race car or even a regular vehicle geez, why put them so close together that it feels awkward and have trouble hitting one or the other, and they're not big enough either.  Anywho.  I hope they make a better version of this in the future.  For now, the only option is something like this or spend thousands of dollars for a real simulation setup.  If you have kids, and you're looking for a steering wheel combo, this may do.

author: Danny
title: Bought this for Gran Turismo Sport (PS4) and I'm very happy I did.
content:
This is very simple to set up.  A quick read of the simple instructions and five minutes later I was racing.  Had some in-game set up to do,  (the game I'm referring to is Gran Turismo Sport) sencativty and how much torque to apply.

but with this being my first SIM racing wheel I had no trouble setting it up to my liking.  The wheel itself feels very comfortable in my long skinny hands, it's very responsive to the slightest bump in-game, and I can be very precise and smooth with the in-game vehicles.  The pedals are very sturdy and feel like a real car, although the brake pedal is pretty stiff it's accurate, sensitive and is very manageable.

I also bought a chair/ mounting platform to use in combination with this setup.  The wheel and pedals feel very sold and able to take aggressive sharp inputs.  But I don't feel the it is needed as you can easily attach it to any object that the mounting arms fit around (a table or desk)

Overall I'm really pleased with product and will most definitely be a return customer.

author: John Berger
title: It's a great wheel, but once you remove the rubber block from the brake, it's even better.
content: I bought this wheel yesterday to play racing games like: Project Cars, Assetto Corsa, Forza Motorsport etc. This wheel is great, but with a hitch. There's a rubber block inserted in the brake pedal that you have to remove in order for the brakes to function properly. You have to remove the screws attaching the assembly plates together and the spring piston linkage in the brake pedal assembly. It's a bit tricky to remove, but once you remove the rubber block from the brake assembly and put back the pedals assembly together again, the wheel's even better. I like this wheel and I just wish that Logitech didn't put in the rubber block in the brake pedal. Driving with a wheel beats using a controller.

author: CaptainHappy
title: The only way to race
content:
If you love car sims, but still use the controller, you should really get a ffb wheel. I've only owned this and one other Logitech wheel: The original, full quality, red case Momo force. I miss that wheel, but this is a great replacement. Unfortunately, I've never used the competition, but I highly recommend this wheel. Also, if you like stick shift in real life, just get the shifter. I've been heel-toe-ing all over the place, it's awesome!

Be sure to plant the pedals firmly, the platform easily shifts as you alternate clutch and throttle. If you 'stand' on the brake, it helps dig in to your carpet to prevent movement. Overall, the metal pedals feel very nice. As others have mentioned, the brake is a bit stiff to start. Mine softened up nicely after about a week.

Look out! The wheel turns lock to lock every time you plug in the usb, open Logitech software, or start the computer. I forgot about a cable laying between the spokes when starting the pc. The wheel/cable turned my cluttered desk into a Rube Goldberg machine, ending in a spilled beer. My fault, easy to do, you've been warned.

It's a bit small. My Momo wheel was actually full size and felt like it came out of a real car. Keep in mind, that wheel was much more expensive several years ago. This one is still pretty great, especially with all the added controls.

The 'leather' feels good, but has already developed a small cut. It feels very thin. Nicely stitched, tho.

The wheel turns almost 3x lock to lock. Compared with the old wheel, this is much more realistic in street cars.

You really can't go wrong with this. Have fun!

author: Winter
title: Pretty decent...
content: I bought this for my son and I to use for Forza6 and am impressed overall but not completely happy. It works well, that's the bottom line. However, I think it could have a better pedal feel and it should be more adjustable that way. The pedals do not mimic a real car in that there isn't quite the feel of a hydraulic clutch or brake system. The throttle is ok however as most fly-by-wire cars today have a pedal that isn't really connected to anything either. The steering, being force feedback does work well and gives a genuine feel of being behind the wheel so to speak. It would neat if someday they could add forcefeeback pedals to give you the real experience of trying to clutch and brake an angry big block 60's muscle car, but for now they just feel kind of dead. Lastly, the mounting options are secure and I never had a problem with the components coming lose, so in all, not a bad buy.

author: Jim Robertson
title: Works with most PC games...
content:
I primarily purchased this and the optional shifter for Forza 4 right after release.  I purchased it to feel more immersed into the game play instead of using the game pad.  After receiving the unit(s) and installed on a driving wheel stand, I installed it on my PC.  Windows 10 picked up the device with no problem.  I calibrated the wheel, pedals and shifter using the Windows 10 gaming utility.

After configuration, Forza 4 picked up the wheel, shifter and pedals.  However, the PC version of the game didn't recognize the button types as Xbox buttons.  It displayed the numerical values instead.  Not sure why, but all peripheral component buttons worked.  I had to memorize what button did what game function but I used the keyboard also for specific functions within the game.  When I attach the wheel/pedal and shifter to the Xbox One, all of the buttons work and display as designed.

One of the Need for Speed games on EA did not work at all with the Logitech Wheel.  No controls worked at all, to include the pedals, the brake pedal was reverse, the clutch was gas, etc.  Basically unplayable.  That is why I rated the Versatility a 2.  Website searches showed that others had the same problem I was having with the game.

For the price paid for the wheel/pedals and shifter I would figure would work with all driving sims games but doesn't.  I enjoy the immersion of game play (ones that work) with the wheel and hope that other new driving sims will support these peripheral devices.

author: Aaron Wilkinson
title: Logitech G920
content: I bought one back in 2014 and didn't get installed until later and it turned out to be bad so when I decided to really get into simulators again I bought this and have been very pleased. Plugged it in and needed and update. After that it has worked flawlessly! Been using it on my pc as well as my xbox one. I would recommend this if your are wanting a good wheel to begin with!

author: Kevin H.
title: Liking it...
content: Liking it... No problems unlike Thrustmaster. All inclusive pedal group.

author: Steve R
title: Great Wheel, Horrible defects (Long Rant)
content:
I love this wheel, I really do, I wanted this to work out more than anything.  after a couple days of using it the wheel made this loud squeaking sound when you turned it left.  It was actually louder than the game itself with the sound nearly maxed.  After seeing so many positives I just assumed I had a bad wheel, I sent it back and received another one.

Right out of the box, loud squeaking sounds when you turn left, I googled the issue, and found pages upon pages on reddit, Logitech's forum, and youtube, talking about this exact issue.  Logitech Customer support is absolutely useless.  They have never acknowledged the problem, they haven't answered anyone's questions in the forum.  They refuse to do anything about it.  I filled out my support form to them, gave them the model and serial number and everything they needed to know, my only question to them was can this issue be fixed without taking it apart and voiding the warranty.

2 days later i got reply that said they need the model number, serial number, when I purchased.  Info I just gave them, I sent this 2nd one back, hoping to get one that worked.  Amazon was awesome with the returns, and I hate to have done this 3 times, but i really wanted this wheel to work.  The 3rd and final wheel came, I got one last email from Logitech that asked the exact same questions as before, and wanted me to scan my receipt for proof of purchase to see if it's still in warranty.
I just wanted to know if there was a fix, that was all, I sent them the receipt from Amazon, and never heard from them since.  This 3rd wheel, right out of the box not only had a squeaking sound, but it was making loud clicking noises as if the gears inside were rubbing up against each other, at this price point I don't want to end up sending a brand new wheel for them to work on and more than likely get a refurbished one back that will more than likely have the same issue.

If you can get a wheel without the squeaking and clicking and noises it makes, then you have the best gaming wheel I think you can buy.  and maybe the squeaking may not be a bad issue, you just have to live with it.  I don't know, but I don't want to pay that much to hear that all day.

author: Anonymous
title: Great Wheel
content: Luv this wheel.  Works great on my xbox one w forza motorsport and horizon.  You have to almost stand on the brakes to get the forza motorsport cars to slow down, but I have to almost stand on the brakes when I take my car to the track too.  So, pretty realistic.

author: Amazon Customer

author: D. Turner

content: Product took 7 days before it even shipped. Product received DOA. Returned and purchased a Thrustmaster T300RS instead. Save your money and buy a TX or T300 instead.

author: C. HAWKINS

content:
Yay!! Yay!! I am so happy with this driving wheel.  It is soo nice.  I have only been playing GT 6 with it so far, cuz that game is really very entertaining.

The look and feel of the wheel and pedals is really well thought out, and the control and precision is impressive. And it works with PS3 and PS4, so when I finally upgrade to the PS4 I won't have any issues.

After using it for about 2 months I had to change my mind great wheel
I have finally gotten it's to work properly on the PlayStation 4 with F1 2017 now I can change my 4 🌟 review to a 5 🌟 review more information F1 2018 on PlayStation 4 I love it and Gran Turismo sports played them both I love the wheel with F1 both I am used it on a computer table and the pedal on carpet floor I need to look into a racing simulator seat

author: Matt
title: Poor quality. AWFUL game support.
content:
Horrific support and it's a pain trying to set this up without support. Independent tools aren't really existent so you have to rely on the poor software integration and logitech's poor drivers.

In some games this worked amazingly well and auto realigned. The old Need For Speed: Most Wanted game worked great with this, surprisingly.

Every other game? Nope. Half baked support and features. You'll need to do some SERIOUS tweaking if you want your game to use this wheel in its full capacity.

And it's not worth it. The quality is average to subpar considering the price. It uses gears which create great resistance feedback but make the wheel feel awful. Very grindy and rough feeling and sounding.

Build quality is poor since the clamps release. Considering this wheel is supposed to be used with force and give back force, the clamp system is laughably stupid and bad. It's entirely pointless unless you're going to Drive Miss Daisy around.

If this were 100 bucks cheaper it would be ok. As it stands, take the criticisms this wheel gets seriously. It truly is awful and because of the broken clamp system I had to return this.

author: Jared Bjork
title: So many compatability issues.
content: This is a very difficult product to use, as most games have major compatability issues with it.  The power supply I was issued shorted out within 15 hours of usage.  All around not high quality for the amount of money it costs.

author: Brad Gunderson
title: Pretty good
content: Works as expected.  I wish it included joysticks, like traditional controllers, just so it could be used with more games that don't allow controls to be customized.  However, so far so good.

author: Denio Magana
title: LACK OF VIBRATION
content:
Stay away from this wheel...
I’ll start with the only reason this wheel is not worth buying.
CON:
it doesn’t have Vibration feedback,only force feed back .
MEANING: when you depend on the feel of the vibration telling you the tires are about to lose traction or steering is about lo lock ...that is not included in this wheel.

PROS: Built to last.
  Easy mount.
  Amazing beautiful wheel feels solid and the leather finish awesome.

Notes:
 the brake pedal mod is fixable with easy effort.
Logitec software Rocks.

But if you depend on the vibration is nowhere to be found.

author: Andy
title: REFUND?!
content: Okay I sent back the item but didn’t get a refund? I sent it back with the shifter but only got refunded for the shifter!!!!! WTH I just got robbed

It's a good wheel.
Plug and play; combined with Oculus VR it makes for a pretty immersive experience.
Sure, you can feel/hear the helical gears. So what?
It may be old tech but it's reliable (looking at you T150 that burned up in 3 hours).
The T3PA pedals have a better feel to them, but this setup is good enough for the casual sim racer like myself.

author: Devilzreject

content: Really happy with this set.  Works great on PC (some older titles need a little work to get it to play nice)  Brake and clutch feel good, feed back is firm and runs fairly quiet.

author: Gage L.
title: Would not recommend for PC
content: This has been nothing but a headache. I got everything set up and was able to use this travesty of a wheel for about 30 minutes. Then it happened... I updated the firmware and it hasn't worked on any game since. I've tried multiple (easily more than 10) troubleshooting methods but to no avail. Logitech support is one of the biggest unfunny jokes I think I have ever witnessed. I have yet to try it on my Xbox but i honestly don't care to. I bought this to use on my PC. Sites like Reddit, YouTube and the Logitech site itself are littered with people having nothing but issues with this thing on PC and with Windows 10 specifically. As of right now its just $250 paper weight and I don't see that ever changing at this rate. If you want to buy this to use on an Xbox One then it may be a good choice and even on PC if you can be lucky enough to get it to work. The 30 minutes of actual game time i had with it was good and it felt great but it's just not worth the trouble one tiny bit. Go for the Thrustmaster.

content: These things are awesome I had a Logitech driving force gt for 8 yrs and it's still going strong with hundreds of hours on it. Bought this to upgrade to a PS4 and it meets every expectation. If your a guy like me that loves to come home drink a beer and just kill it on the track then this baby's for you. Once you use one of these you'll beat your self up for ever using a regular controller. Also if your somewhat of a handy man you can make up your own rig instead of spending 400-800 on a decent racing sim. Mine is made out of some old workout equipment I cut up and welded back together. And a chair I bought off of Amazon for $120 that's very comfortable.
