content: I wanted this for very long time and i was so excited about it but unfortunately this is not that realistic and you won’t like it specially in the beginning!

author: DT Vegas
title: Buyer beware
content: Buyer beware. Logitech support is THE WORST. Ordered for our 15 year old son. He plays the Forza games and does well with the controller.  He struggled to get good when using the wheel. Then the xBox light began flashing. All the buttons and pedals worked but no steering. After trying to navigate the Logitech web site for twenty minutes to find one basic remedy. That did not work so I sent an email explaining what I had already done. It took five days to get a response telling me to do the basic reset I had already tried. There were five emails over ten days and was unable to get resolution.  I emailed Amazon about returning it. In three hours they had responded with resolution. Logitech should take a lesson from Amazon on how to take care of pying customers. I have since purchased a new keyboard and did not buy Logitech due to these issues.

author: Mac
title: Three Stars
content: Slides around on tables that are smooth at all. Feels alright, but kinda expensive.

author: kenneth Smith
title: Spent Hours Troubleshooting
content: I ended up returning this.  No software provided, barely any instructions.  After downloading and installing the proper software, I still had problems with it staying connected.  After I resolve the connection issue, the brakes were too hard to actually work.  Tried to calibrate the sensitivity, but nothing I tried worked.  Turned to YouTube to figure out a fix, and there were video of people taking it apart and modifying it.  That's when I said, naw.... I'll just return this junk.  If it doesn't work out of the box, then why would I pay $200+ for it.  I've always loved Logitech products, and I even had one of their older model steering wheels.  Never had any problems with Logitech until I got this unit.  Hopefully Logitech's quality isn't going down the drain like every other company.

But I don't speak other languages and I certainly wasn't going to deal with installing Windows 10 N off a guess to fix this. I got Windows 10 KN because it's more lightweight and doesn't have so much of Microsoft's garbage like windows media player preinstalled. But I guess that was the wrong call...

author: Dustin Kienzler
title: Brake peddle is Horrible.
content:
The wheel is nice and feels good when driving after a lot of setting tweaks in games.  gas peddle and clutch are good but the brake peddle is WAY TOO stiff. I'm a big guy and I have to damn near fully step on the damn thing to get it to actually brake. I have to push soo hard that My chair without wheels slides on the carpet and my ankle hurts after about half hour of using it. it is horrid. Because of this unless you mod it to take the rubber out (it will void your warranty) I can't recommend this product at all as the peddles are half the appeal when getting this.
To be far everything else is good. the force feedback is a bit rough though, as it likes to try and turn the wheel quite hard when only going 60 down a straight road with no bumps. (turn it down or off and it feels good)

Also, if you do not have a proper desk and chair setup to mount this to that allows alot of body movement and a stable mount for the wheel  the setup will feel inadequate. I feel like one of the special racing seats also sold on amazon is almost necessary to fully enjoy this product. Also the plastic screws that allow you to mount the wheel to a desk feel flimsy and breakable

author: Itadaki
title: Just Doesn't Work on Windows 10
content:
It seemed to work on my PS3, but I only have one driving game there (Burnout Paradise). It might be that I needed to acclimate to the new controls, but the wheel felt laggy and I would end up oversteering all the time. It was no fun.

On Windows 10, it just doesn't work. I downloaded the latest LGS app from Logitech's site and straight away it fails to find the majority of my games on Steam. Logitech's solution is a convoluted set of instructions (outdated too, given the LGS interface had changed since) that result in me editing a Game profile and manually browsing to the game EXE buried in the Valve Steam directories. Not for your everyday consumer.

Even so, it still wouldn't work. LGS detects the wheel and paddles, and the wheel spins on plugging in -- to calibrate. And then nothing. The Crew, Dirt 3, Burnout Paradise...nothing.

Logitech's support forums are full of unanswered threads from people with problems, and their FAQ doesn't even acknowledge the issue.

I've tried updating all my drivers (I have IOBit Driver Booster), uninstalling GeForce Experience (F1 2016 suggestion), manually reinstalling the driver in Device Manager, plugging into different USB ports, unplugging and replugging from USB while outside the game, inside the game, etc.

This is going back to Amazon.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Great product
content: Nice feedback

author: omar kreidieh
title: ... Driving Force GT on the playstation and it was perfect. I was given this steering wheel as a ...
content:
I owned the previous Driving Force GT on the playstation and it was perfect. I was given this steering wheel as a gift so I can't comment to the price. However, despite it being supposedly better built, I couldn't see much difference between this and my previous driving force GT. More importantly, the brake is very stiff, and I actually can't play on it anymore because I have been getting knee pain from it ( im only 28 and have never had this before, and its just knee pain in the left knee which I use to brake.) The other major problem is that thrustmaster seems to provide a lot more support to developers these days. Thats why for example on assetto corsa, theres a huge deadzone for this wheel, when reviews with other wheels didn't show a lot of problems.

Update: If you look up online, there is a small piece of rubber hinged in the brake pedal on the inside that you can remove to improve playability. The brake is still stiff afterwards however.  Bad move logitech. Most people are having to remove this eventually for their legs to survive and yet that would void their waranty. Really? Who came up with that decision instead of having a normal progressive force brakes or adjustable stiffness like other comparable competitors?
The wheel is great otherwise, good feel, good force feedback. The pedals are a huge issue though and should be a dealbraker for most.

All in all, I would go for the thrustmaster over this...

Update:
I stopped using this and my knees were back to normal and I could play basketball. Tried it again when GT sport came out and OH MY GOD. The pain is unbearable. Avoid this wheel/ pedal like the plague!

content: The wheel overall works very very well. A great feel too it. Honestly feels like a real wheel. When I opened the box it has that new car smell. author: Amazon Customer
title: Hard to rival at this price range,
content:
Great product for the price. I currently have Fanatec Porsche Turbo S wheel setup and while the steering feel is great, its pedal is an absolute crap. On the other hand, Logitech offers a good amount of resistance on all of its pedals. While the steering feel may be a step behind that of Turbo S in its stock form, users should be able to adjust it according to their taste using Logitech Gaming Software.

The one thing I would change is the optional shifter, as it is way too soft to be realistic; I often shift to 5th gear instead of 3rd because there is literally no resistance between gear shifts.

author: Amazon Customer
title: IMPOSSIBLE TO DRIFT WITH!!!
content: I would give this product a 2/10 a no good, for the 280 dollars spent it is the worst wheel shifter pedal combo you can get from a drifters point of view when playing forza/assetto corsa/gta this wheel cant keep up with the standard 60 dollar wireless controller an heres what i mean, when playing a drift game the left stick on a controller is the wheel when u press right or left that is all the way angled to the right or left this g29 wheel setup does not have the power nor capability to that of a 60 controller heres my example every-time i play on a lil 60 dollar controller i can actually counter steer in these drift games because of the angle the controller analog stick gives out going back and forth instead of a wheel that has to go a whole 2 an half turns to counter steer in a blink of an eye not to mention how much you half to counter steer and you cant do this because of the 1 1/2 turn radius with the wheel if im all the way right then would half to go 3 full turns to counter steer its impossible to drift with an have fun SUCH A WASTE!

author: Mike
title: Great wheel from Logitech!
content:
I've waited some time for Logitech to come out with a wheel for the Xbox and finally they have. The g27 was a huge success and has been known for it's reliability, I just hope that this one holds up as well.

Initial impression
Disclaimer: This is my first wheel so i don't really have anything to compare it to.

I am very Impressed by the quality of the wheel and the pedals. The wheel feels pretty solid, the leather feels real good (smells good too), and the click from the paddles is very satisfying. The peddles feel pretty good and in my opinion, not bad for something that cost $400. The brake peddle feels really good, but does take some getting use to when compared to how easily the other peddles press down.

If you have never used a racing wheel before, it def take some getting use to. I've used it now for a total of 4-5 hours and am finally starting to get a hang of things and have the settings to my liking. The force feedback does have a slight dead zone when the wheel is centered but nothing that has bothered me or is really noticeable unless you try to feel for it. I'd be interested to see how this wheel feels compared to a belt driven wheel.

Pros:
Quality product for the price
Rather quiet for all the vibration and force feedback
Brake peddle feel really nice!
Buttons on the wheel make it real easy to use
Peddles come with a clutch

Cons:
No adjustability on the peddles
Wires. I wish there where less wires, or at least slightly longer wires (I had to use a usb extension since my xbox sits in the corner)
Very bright LED light on the wheel face (placed a piece of take on top)
Wish it had the wheel dial from he G29

I'm sure ill find some other pros and cons the more time i put into using the wheel, So far i will say that i am satisfied.

author: LamoidZombieDog
title: Amazing
content:
Let me just start off by saying it's amazing... The wheel spin smooth the pedals dress nicely I was disappointed when a button came non-working and time a button messed up in the spring when pressing.. It was resolved easily by sending mine to Logitech and they sent me a brand new not refurbished but brand new one and now works fine the one that I received from Logitech does have a slight squeak when turning the wheel very fast to the left but that's okay do not get the Xbox one unless you really need it for the Xbox and don't know of any good controllers to make it work with the PlayStation one the PlayStation one has multiple more buttons and controls than the Xbox One in overall is better it works with the PlayStation 3 4 and PC no problem I don't use it on the PlayStations I use it on my PC only I prefer it normally with American Truck Sim or with euro Truck Simulator 2 overall it works good drives amazing and it feels like a real car when you drive in

I want to know this was made with a voice-to-text automator sorry for any spelling mistakes

author: Joseph Cimino
title: Five Stars
content: Works great, lots of fun when playing Forza

author: ZAK kane
title: Very disappointed with force feedback.
content: To be clear, the reason I'm giving this 2 stars rather than 1 is unlike most people my xboxONE did recognize the wheel. Unfortunately, after I booted up FORZA 6, the force feedback was very low. I tried various settings and different rotation settings but nothing would fix it. I also tried only signing in with the wheel to see if this would resolve the issue. I did not contact customer support, as I am very knowledgeable of how to use sim racing wheels. I currently own a logitech driving force GT that gave me better force feedback then this wheel ever delivered. I'm very very disappointed in logitech. I have to say the build quality on the petals and the wheel is excellent and the leather feels great in your hands, however this is not a wheel that you can be happy with because the force feedback is so weak and you don't get any feeling that you are driving a car. In my honest opinion, the force feedback feels more like an assisted steering rather then the motor holding the wheel back making it tougher to turn. At $400 I was expecting a lot more but I guess I will spend the extra $70 to get a thrustmaster wheel. It is at 11 AM right now and last night I received the wheel at 5 PM. I played for about two hours and try to get the settings to work for me but in the end I was disappointed. I think in the future logitech needs to release new drivers for the XboxONE that make the wheel more compatible. Logitech, I'm sorry but you won't be getting my business anymore. I thrive off sim racing games, and the fact that my wheel that is 6 years old performs better than a new wheel is unacceptable. I'm happy that I'm going to get a refund.

author: Marilynn
title: Easy to set up
content: Really well put together product. My son plays with it for long periods of time and seems to enjoy it.

author: Daniel J Silvey
title: Super Nice Racing Wheel
content: Another great product from Logitech, I’m impressed.  I had to have two, this one for PS4 Pro.  Lots of fun.  Quality seller and a low price.

author: Tyler T
title: Left turn squeal, and an okay shifter
content:
The G920 looks great. This is my first forced feedback wheel so i have no preferences on how good it feels compared to others. Metal pedals and paddle shifters. As most people will say the brake is very difficult to depress all the way to 100% because of the rubber piece they gave it to make it feel more of a progressive pressure feel, however if you adjust the deceleration deadzone down to ~35 and you'll be fine. I've also noticed if you have set the rotation to anything different, if you hit the home button it'll reset the setting back to 900° of rotation. Overall its a great wheel but...the biggest complaint i have (which seems to be a very common issue with the g920 and g29) is that when it turns left it produces a very high pitch squealing sound that can get annoying. It's a sound as if you can all of a suddenly hear dog whistles, so putting on a headset is a must if you don't wanna hear it.
(In the photo i bought the stand that is in the "frequently bought together", it's $189 for a stand...a little ridiculous for a stand if you ask me)

Decent shifter. I have never driven a manual car and i believe this is designed as a short throw shifter, so i have issues knowing if its in gear all the way because it's such a short throw. It doesn't really feel "notchy" enough when shifting as i would like. I have the g920 wheel so I'm unsure if there are any other shifters that work with wheel or not

title: Worth the money over using a normal Controller.

Great feedback, comfortable wheel, and outstanding construction and design.

author: Sergey
title: This is a great wheel
content:
I enjoyed driving around in Crew 2. The only down side was the game.

One thing i don't like about the wheel is how weird the feedback is, im scared to turn it rapidly and break all the gears inside.

Other than that i removed the feedback and drove around for fun until after 2 months, crew 2 became obsolete. Multiplayer died. Haven't tried other driving games yet.

author: JWINK
title: Ok starter wheel
content:
I use to own the G27, but it was not really compatible with a PS4.  I truly want to get a Fanetic wheel, but they are a bit overpriced in my opinion and their sales are rare.  So, until I can get that, I grabbed this G29, which for all intents and purposes is essentially the same wheel.  It does kind of stink that Logitech and Sony couldn’t figure out how to make the G27 compatible as there are not really any differences.

For the price, this is a pretty decent quality wheel, although by no means it is at the level of Fanetic wheels.  It has a bit of toy-like look and feel with its mostly plastic components.  The leather racing wheel is good quality though, although a bit smaller than it probably should be.  I assume that is to compensate for its feedback motor.

The wheel’s force feedback mechanism is a bit noisy and feels a bit notchy and not as smooth as higher end wheels with its feedback.  The pedals are decent although it would be nice is if they had some feedback as wheel.  The shifter feels pretty mediocre as it looks like something that would break easily with rough shifting.  It does the job and is about what you would expect for a wheel in this price range though.  The plastic table clamps are to me one of its weakest links, as they at times don’t seem to hold well.  I am using a metal racing stand and they hold, but these could be better quality.

With that being said though, the wheel is pretty durable and has held up with use.  One thing that is on my wish list is wireless controls.  Granted maybe that is not possible, but it sure would be nice to not have to deal with cables for each of the components.  For some reason, Logitech still uses old style plugs for the wheel as well to connect to each other.

Of course, this wheels biggest weakness as compared to more expensive alternatives is that you cannot change wheels or add other components, meaning what you see is what you get.  For a starter wheel, this is a good way to go.

If you are looking for a high-end experience, then you will need to step up to much more expensive alternatives.

4 stars

author: Justin H
title: Shows promise, but buyer beware...
content:
The wheel is generally pretty well-made - it feels solid, the wrap around the wheel is decent (though my stitching had a few frayed spots), the motor is nice and strong when it wants to be. The pedals are super-heavy and secure even on my usually-slippery hardwood floor (and includes a flip-down set of spikes to dig into carpeting), the pedals generally have a good feel to them.

However... Logitech has some quality control issues with their gaming hardware. Brand new out of the box, the left paddle shifter has about a 30% success rate registering clicks - researching on the Internet, this seems to be a super-common and widespread problem of cables disconnecting internally or otherwise faulty switches. The gas pedal occasionally has issues reading correctly, the brake pedal consistently has issues reading correctly forcing me to set a deadzone in excess of 50% to work fully. For one of their higher-end products, I'm very disappointed in the quality of this product and the fact I have to RMA it already. That said, the promise this wheel has, I'll be giving them another shot (and buying an extended warranty...) in the hopes that my issues are just a fluke.

author: Brady Arnold
title: Very great entry wheel/pedals setup
content: Very solid wheel for the price range, it uses a conical gear and motor setup instead of sprockets that are driven by belts like most other wheels, it has a very solid range of motion (900 degrees) and the soft lock can be adjusted in the logitech software, it has decently strong motors for force feedback and will require some minor adjustments in a few sims to get it feel and respond the way it should, with that being said though once you tune your force feedback settings a bit to your preferences there are almost no problems whatsoever, after using the wheel pedals and shifter for several weeks very heavily several hours a day. My only problem is that the force feedback can feel kind of wobbly or jittery at very high speeds until you adjust the FFB settings per game usually.

author: Dave Brown
title: I like the updated button layout
content:
My G25 finally broke. Stepping up to this is a SIGNIFICANT improvement.

I like the updated button layout, as I no longer need another controller handy. I also like the layout better. But most of all - it's SO much quieter while operating. It also feels smoother while turning. The center point is still a little "No left feedback past this point, no right feedback past that point", but it's forgivable, as it's also about 1/3 the price of the systems that might do more.

One cautionary word: there really is no repair service for these - they are very much "buy and use until it breaks", but with Logitech standing behind it if it breaks under warrantee. Once the warrantee is over, you can try to repair it yourself (which did not work on the G25) or just pick up a new one. It's sufficiently complex in there that an extended warrantee really would be justified.

I have registered the warranty and currently have a claim with Logitech for this. Aside for this one problem this wheel is a lot of fun.

author: JB
title: Perhaps the best wheel out for the XBox One, but sub-par support
content:
The Logitech G920 Driving Force Race Wheel is a solid product, and overall a great wheel for the XBox One.  I say this as an owner of the previous Logitech G27 Racing Wheel for over five years. From all indications the G920 is built to the same standards as the G27 (and the current G29 for the PS4) and I would expect the lifespan and reliability to be similar.

Since the G920 can also be used on a PC, I'll point out a few differences this new generation of wheel and the previous generation G27:
- The G920 costs more than the G27 and does not come with a shifter like the G27 does, instead it is a separate purchase.  I will say this isn't a big issue for me as I use the paddle shifters on the wheel almost exclusively.
- Though this can be used on both the XBox One and a PC, the button layout obviously lend itself to XBox One use.
- The brake pedal has been updated to more closely resemble how an actual car brake feels - the pedal moves much less and encounters increasing resistance as the pedal is pushed down. I like how the G920 succeeds in making the pedal feel a bit closer to a car's brake, but my son who races more than I do is not as impressed and prefers the G27 brake. In all, this is a case of "different" but not necessarily "better".

So I would call this a 5-star product for XBox One and a 4-star product for PC users - except I have to dock the G920 (along with Logitech's other wheels) for poor after-warranty support. Many parts on the G920, G29, and G27 are made of plastic and can break, and other parts (the potentiometers or "pots" in the pedal system in particular) will wear out over time. Logitech currently has *no* spare parts available for any of their gaming wheels including the G920.  If the wheel is still in warranty Logitech will apparently replace the entire wheel, but if you are out of warranty you will get no help whatsoever from Logitech. In my case I asked about a lost screw that attaches the G27 shifter to a table and about worn out pedal pots - in each case Logitech said there was nothing they could do. That might be tolerable for a cheap controller or mouse, but I do not consider a $400 racing wheel a throwaway product and I find this level of support unacceptable.

So overall a solid product and arguably the best wheel for the XBox One. I will enjoy this wheel as long as it remains trouble-free, but I know that after the warranty expires any support from Logitech is likely to be non-existent. Also note that the new generation of wheels (G920 and G29) has reduced the warranty from three years to two.

author: Dr D
title: Great great gaming wheel for the price
content: Another great product from Logitech as per usual. Lot's of great features and feedback system is fairly decent. My only complaints would be their gaming software will not detect the wheel no matter how many times I re-install the drivers and software (sigh) or any other number of troubleshooting steps I can find online. However the wheel works flawlessly in game so not a deal breaker. The other would be more of a personal preference and honestly applies to every wheel system out there. The peddles are too close together and the break peddle should be a horizontal pad like what we have in most vehicles. The experienced drivers instinct has the break and gas hard mapped in our subconscious so moving to the break from gas on gaming peddles easily results in hitting the gas and break both. With all the effort that has gone into making these systems come as close as possible to real driving; why not make the peddle layout/spacing more realistic or at least adjustable so we can decide for our selves? I guess it's more of a nice to have then a must have but damn it would be nice to not have to re-program my breaking reflexes :).

author: Author at Home
title: Outstanding Wheel at a Great Price
content:
First a frame of reference. I use this for Gran Turismo Sport on the PS4. I previously had a Driving Force Pro from Logitec as well. I’ve played each iteration of Gran Turismo since the original Gran Turismo (it was not called GT1) and have used a wheel on that game starting w/ Gran Turismo 3 (a-spec) and have logged . . . about a billion miles.

I love this wheel dearly. I’ll talk about the pedals separately.

The operation is very smooth and it’s much quieter than my old DFP. Metal paddle shifters are wonderful; I’ll add a shifter once it’s supported in a GT game. There is a blue metal band on the top of the wheel making it easy to find center (for those of us who care about that) so it’s not a line of tape that will come loose or fade over time. For me it’s precise as all get out. After using a controller for the first few months I was ecstatic about how I could place my car around the track. But it won’t make anyone a championship driver . . . you’ll just have more precision.

There is a full complement of buttons on the wheel including (bottom to top)  a PS button, Options button and Share button below the center of the wheel. It may take some time to get used to; I’ve hit the share button while trying to pause the game during a practice session. That’s my only quibble. The rotary dial can be used  to select the level while the +/- button changes what setting you’re manipulating during a race; you can remap the wheels buttons in the options menu.

Getting my PS4 to recognize my wheel off the bat was easy . . . once I figured out just what to do. I leave my wheel plugged in, turn on the PS4 from the unit itself, then – once the blue screen comes up – press the PS button on the wheel. I mention this because initially I was using my controller to wake up the PS4 and it would take quite some time before the wheel could be used. I hope that helps anyone who’s run into the same issue.

NOW ABOUT THE PEDAL SETUP

I kept this separate because of all the reviews mentioning the pedals. The gas offers very little resistance in comparison to the brakes. The brakes may feel very stiff to others; I myself was somewhat prepared due to the reviews. Compared to my old DFP, the effort required to operate the brake pedal is gargantuan . . . but that’s not a problem. It feels much more like the brakes I’ve used in my (limited) time on the track. The brake has more resistance than the ones in my Buick, but I was able to get used to that. For me it has a much more sporting feel.

**UPDATE 7/29**
After some checking it appears the rubber inside the brake - which causes that resistance - is supposed to simulate a load cell. The brake has a certain amount of travel to a point, then you apply more pressure and modulate how much stopping power you get. It's a bit grabby to work with at first, but I REALLY REALLY love it now. Just took the better part of an afternoon to make it part of my routine. Trail braking is easier too. Back to the original review...
*******

In game I’ve noticed something. When using a controller, I have less braking power, but with the pedals – when I really stand on the brakes – the stopping ability is increased. I credit that to the game itself, recognizing what a driver can do with her/his feet vs. the amount of travel available w/ the triggers on the controller. It definitely took some getting used to but the amount of modulation I get from the gas AND the brakes has lowered my lap times tremendously.

Lastly, the price of this is awesome in comparison. A $700.00 wheel is not in my budget, and this is the one I’d decided to target. It came up on Prime Day and I snapped it up . . . but I’d planned on buying it eventually at the regular price. It’s smooth and quiet, precise and a great wheel. Worth every penny.

Now I just need a correct wheel stand! The X-Celerator(?) Big Boy stand I have worked for the DFP; the pedals on the G29 are way too big.

TL;DR:

Great wheel, Brake pedal takes effort to push but it’s worth it, HIGHLY recommended for price.

Hope this helps.

I'm not sure what the cause of this is, but a quick google search shows this as a trending complaint.
So far all buttons are working.
Now for the second issue. A month ago I started noticing that the faux leather was making noise. Apparently, whatever adhesive is being used to adhere the faux leather to the wheel rim has worn off. It's like it has a bit of play in it. I don't want to twist the leather on the rim to make it worse, but sometimes that is unavoidable when doing quick corrections when driving. I hope it does not get to the point where wheel rim slips under the leather. Good thing i don't have Force Feedback maxed out!! Only more time will tell....

author: Sam Bellemore
title: Incredible Quality: Usability Concerns / Things you should know
content:
I love this thing. It is built very well, feels great, looks great, easy to set up. I can feel the road under my car in Forza Horizon 4 like never before. Pedals stay put on the floor, and they feel very... well, real. This is automobile quality gear. Hell, my 2013 Sonic has a cheaper feeling steering wheel than my computer desk.

My concerns, and what a possible buyer should know:

- It is hard as (insert profanity) to drive with this bad boy. I am not taking a star off for this. This is GOOD. However, it made me realize just how casual I am about my driving games. When the back end goes out (which it will due to what I mention below) the amount of maneuvering you have to do in the 900 degree steering range is crazy. Realistic, YES. Accessible to the casual / semi serious enthusiast? More than likely not. Be warned, your gameplay WILL suffer hard if you are coming to this from a controller. Will take some serious time investment.

- If you have a rolling chair with no carpeting underneath (and this is my personal problem with using this thing, again not docking for this) you WILL move backwards. There is real resistance to these pedals, mostly the brake. This is not a fault of the product, this is just reality. I think it is great that it is this way since it is a result of the product feeling VERY realistic.

- Brake pedal sensitivity (and I am docking a star for this one). No matter how much I tweak the settings in the Logitech companion software, I can NOT get to full brake lock without curling my toes around the pedal and JAMMING it to the stand. I am driving in Forza Horizon 4 with no ABS, and I simply CANNOT lock up the wheels. This is very frustrating for me, as it makes cornering more of a challenge than the new control scheme already is.

- No Vibration Feedback: I can understand in hindsight why a wheel clamped to a desk wouldn't have rumble. However, that is hindsight. I have serious trouble keeping the back end in control when I don't get the rumble feedback I am used to in my XBOX controller. The dual-motor force feedback usually isn't doing much until the car is in full-tilt oversteer. This makes driving rather tricky. This is lending itself to the lost star - but on it's own doesn't warrant that since Rumble was not an advertised feature. You know what happens when you assume!

OTHER GRIPES (these lend to the one lost star):

- ABXY (and PS equivalent) are a bit of a reach for my thumb, and I have large hands. I find myself frequently pressing B (or the "cancel" equivalent on PS) when reaching for the A (or "accept) equivalent on PS) button.

- The mounting clamps semi-frequently experience a sort of slight release under heavy steering input (at least when mounted to a standard desktop) and it makes an incredibly frightening POP noise, however continues to work normally with no damage. The mounting knobs just pop up out of their "locked" position when this happens.

- At a $400 USD price point, I would have hoped the paddle shifters were column-mounted. However they are not, they are wheel-mounted. This makes for some guesswork if changing gear mid-corner. This is big for me, as I am accustomed to changing gears when preparing to exit a corner.

TL:DR: Some minor frustrations, but many are a fault of my setup. A couple ergonomic issues, but for experienced players or those with a knack for reprogramming muscle-memory, not a huge issue. Would advise a demo at any sort of shop that stocks these if possible, before buying. If I had done this I likely wouldn't have purchased.

I might look into a club sport 1.5 shiftier as an alternative to Driving force unit in future. I did already fire up die cut machine and just had to make a decal for wheel.. lol

author: R. Ferguson
title: Evolution of the G27; brake pedal now very stiff.
content: Logitech's marketing for the G920 and the G29 (Playstation) suggests a thorough redesign of the company's earlier force feedback steering wheels, notably the popular G27. The G920 (MSRP 399.99) is best viewed as an evolution of the workhorse G27, and once past the addition of the D-pad/XYAB controls and compatibility with Xbox One, the units share many mechanical features. This is especially true in the pedal unit, which as best I can tell, is largely the G27 unit with a Nixim style mod, that is, a small block of rubber inserted into the spring coil to increase pedal resistance. For my taste, I think the brake is not sufficiently progressive; it goes hard very fast. I haven't opened up the spring mechanism yet, but I will revisit this review when I do and let you know whether there are any quick fixes. It is a certainty that there will be 3rd party mod kits for the pedals just as there were for the G27. So far, the outer pedal mechanism appears nearly identical to the G27. On the steering wheel there is the obvious addition of the controller functions. This is great for set-up, but in general I don't like a lot of stuff on my steering wheel (real or simulated) so I'm actually nostalgic for the spartan G27. The G920 loses the LED rev indicator that is present on the G29 and G27. The paddle shifters are similar to the G27. The leather stitched wheel feels good, and you have 900 degrees of turn and a race-car style flat bottom geometry. On the force feedback, Logitech says they've done loads of design and testing. I think the unit will feel familiar to G27 users. It is very smooth and quiet. I am disappointed by the removal of the shift unit from the package, but that's the way things are going generally. On the whole, think of this as an evolved G27 with a stiff brake pedal and Xbox One compatibility.

author: Chris

author: Amazon Customer
title: 5 stars if it weren't for my grudge.
content: I'll start by saying this product is perfect and as described. That said, I'm holding a grudge against Logitech for not coming up with a solution to the PS4 compatibility issue with the older Driving Force GT wheel. People have come up with complicated DIY hacks to make the old wheels function on PS4 (which is a little over my head) so it's obviously possible. So what I'm left with is two completely worthless Driving Force GT wheels. This new wheel is great, but offers nothing to me that the old one doesn't. I believe this to be a scam by Logitech to sell more units, and my only way to vent is to my fellow Amazoners.

I choose the G920 because research seemed to indicate that there were less compatibility issues with it then with other gaming wheels. So far there have been no issues with the product. It is a very high quality built unit. The games I have that are five years or less in age work fine with it on my Windows 10, 64 bit gaming rig.. Older games work with the wheel if I use a driver designed for an older wheel. They can be downloaded fro the Logitech WEB site.

author: 4thNobleTruth
title: The steering didnt work. There is an light that ...
content: Like it! Brakes too stiff.

author: NAAM
title: Does not work with PS4.
content:
Simply put, this did not work with my PS4. I spent several hours on Logitech's forums trying to fix it, with no luck. It seems that many other people have had the same exact issue, and for a while too. I went off a tech review, otherwise I would not have purchased this.

When plugged in, the buttons and pedals worked but the steering wheel did not. No amount of restarts, or attempts to calibrate it, worked. I made sure the software was up to date, for both the games and PS4. Neither made any difference.

author: Hobbyist
title: Not typical Logitech quality
content:
I bought this wheel and the shifter add-on with the intentions of using it for Xbox One (Forza 6 & F1 2016) and for PC (American Truck Simulator).  I had the wheel for maybe a week and sent it back for a refund.  The wheel is functional but not anywhere near the level I thought it would be.  The force feedback is awful and I set it on zero after awhile.  In Forza 6 with all assists off and steering set to simulation or normal, once your cars' rear wheel lose traction, there is no way to correct without overcorrecting.  You also cannot quickly whip your car around with throttle steer, the cars just understeer and go straight.  Plug your controller back in and you can drift and throttle steer no problem.  And believe me, I went through and manipulated every setting configuration possible.

On PC for American Truck Simulator, things were a little better but after the first two days on my brand new gaming PC, the system wouldn't even recognize that the wheel was connected.  I deleted and reinstalled drivers and software but no luck.  And when it intermittently connected, the force feedback, although set to zero, was so stiff, you couldn't even budge the wheel from center.

I WAS VERY DISAPPOINTED WITH THE QUALITY OF THIS PRODUCT.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Fun
content: Son likes it.

author: Gonzalo Torres
title: Awesome
content: Takes a while to get used to but works perfectly. I have it set up to my desk and it holds on a lot stronger than I though it would. It hasnt come off or even loosened since, and its been weeks. Set up was easy.

author: KrystalO
title: Not compatible with a lot of games
content: Bought this for my husband because he has a ton of racing games, but it only works for 1 of them. It came with a list of games it’s compatible with, and there was only 10 games listed. We had to go out and buy another $60 game just so he could have more than one game he could use this with. He said the wheel is very jerky when he uses it.

author: Alex
title: Easy to setup
content: can be used on all different desks and tables, would be best to get a stand or even the whole chair and stand setup for it.

author: Deitra King
title: Logitech wheel and shifter
content: The product has already stopped working and the return window is closed.  Waste of money.

author: Ravex24
title: I'm sure it's great, when fully functional. Hopefully I will find out.
content:
So far, not happy. Has not worked since it arrived. Device manager refuses to see it, even after a complete format of my HD. All troubleshooting from Logitech and internet research has failed. So how did it get 2 stars? Well, it's still semi-recognized by the system. I just can't adjust the settings outside of games, or use the profiler, which is a big problem with this wheel if you are a sim racer. So, I have had driving experience with it, just without full features or capabilities. I've been sim racing since the old Indy 500 Papyrus put out. For the last 8 years, I've had the Logitech DFGT. This G29 is so much smoother and you can feel quite a bit more. The real prize here is the pedals, however. One pedal, to be exact. The brake pedal compared to the one that comes with the DFGT isn't even close. The throw could be a bit better but the feel is vastly improved, giving much better control. It was so different that it took a bit to adjust my driving and get it right. My lap times immediately improved, setting personal records right off the bat. So, while I do think this would probably get 4 or 5 stars, it's yet to be fully functional for me, so as it stands, it's a 2. Will update after working with seller to resolve this problem.

Edit: Update--- Still does not work properly even with a replacement. Logitech keeps trying to close my case even though they have resolved nothing. I have a replacement wheel and they want to go through this entire process again. It seems that they have no answer. Do NOT buy this. May work properly. May not. But customer service has been crap. Once again, I got this in July. It's now late October. I still have no solutions to my problems. I will not work with this company again, and I stress, it has been work. My pain through dealing with this wheel's issues has been much more hassle than it is worth. Do not buy a Logitech device. Ever! I never will again.

author: Haley
title: Good Wheel/ OK Pedals (Unboxing and Gameplay Video Link  Included)
content: I received this wheel from Amazon about a week ago.  The wheel is great, but as other's have said the brake is quite stiff when you hit the foam piece Logitech put in the brake spring.  To solve that issue, I reduced the top deadzone of the brake to around 60% travel so I never have to worry about hitting the foam.  I will most likely remove the foam piece in the future.  The following video shows my unboxing and some Forza 6 game play!  Hope this helps.  [...]

author: all american

author: TJG
title: so good. Replaced an old Driving Force GT that was ...
content: So far, so good.  Replaced an old Driving Force GT that was not compatible with a PS4.  I've used it for F1 2016 only, but plan on using it for iRacing in the future.  MUCH quieter than the DFGT.  There is a dead spot in the middle that is larger than it should be, so that's not ideal.  The blue buttons are also a bit far to reach with your thumbs if you have small hands, making hitting them a bit tough while steering (I have mine set for DRS - requires me to move my hand off of the wheel).

author: Andrew
title: Good manual steering wheel
content:
I've always wanted a steering wheel with a 3rd clutch pedal and manual shifter. I've had the cheap console ones before with the shifter that only goes up and down, and those have not been cutting it for me.

Managed to get this wheel bundled with the shifter during one of the sales, and so far, I've been pretty satisfied with this wheel. One thing I noticed with my cheaper wheels was that I always had issues with oversteer and spinning out. This wheel wasn't much different in that regard. When I first jumped on Forza with my 600hp S14 Silvia, I kept spinning out, and couldn't drift like I could with a controller. I do think that this might just be something to get acquainted to as when I went to a slower car, I didn't spin out nearly as much and eventually got better at it.

In terms of the quality of the materials, they don't seem too bad. I will say though that my wheel already had a tiny bit of peeled color on the middle blue strip on top of the wheel. Not a big deal to me, but for someone more anal about aesthetics, this is something to note. Maybe it's just a defect on mine, but it makes me question the durability of the middle strip. The outer part of the wheel seems durable so far. At first I thought the stitching was slightly frayed, but it turns out that they just left the ends sticking out a bit. So far, it seems like this wheel should last a while. But it isn't a big deal if it doesn't as you can easily swap the wheel with real car wheels using adapters that you can find online.

The pedals I have no complaints about at all. I'm completely satisfied with the pedals.

The shifter I felt was a bit light. I was able to swap shift knobs easily by getting an adapter/taping the shaft so a normal shift knob would fit. With my heavier metal shift knob, I like how it feels more. For me, getting into reverse is a bit finicky as I sometimes don't push down enough and the game doesn't register it as reverse.

But overall, I'm pretty happy with this bundle. If you're able to get the bundle when its on sale, it is definitely a great value and I'd recommend it if you want to get into sim racing or just want a wheel with a full manual setup.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Five Stars

author: jason schleicher

title: This is quite a nice wheel. It is Plug-in-Play with Xbox One out ...
content: This is quite a nice wheel.  It is Plug-in-Play with Xbox One out of the box.  Brake pedal gets very stiff suddenly half way down, thanks to a rubber stopper.  It's a little too sudden and stiff, would be better with a progressive spring rate, that is my biggest issue with the product.  From what I have read the rubber cylinder can be taken out, but requires some disassembly of the pedals. The quality is very nice and leather wheel feels nice, shift paddles are solid. The LED power light is blinding, I just covered it with a piece of electric tape.

author: Daniel
title: after opening this package, i took everything out of ...
content: after opening this package, i took everything out of it's plastic and went to mount it to my desk, when i unscrewed the clamps, the left side got stuck wide open and will not under any circumstances tighten, no amount of force i've been able to put into turning the screw has gotten it to tighten, my desk is large so i've managed to wedge cardboard between the clamp and my desk to get it to stay mounted stable, but it's really unfortunate that i won't be able to move it from my desk to anywhere else unless i buy a  sim racing cockpit

author: JR
title: Pedals are mapped wrong and cannot be fixed in the software
content:
Pedals are mapped wrong (accelerator=brake, clutch=accelerator, brake=clutch) and no way to remap through Logitech software. Made the whole unit worthless, over software, that Logitech won't fix! With the new update they removed the ability to remap the pedals or this wouldn't have been a problem.

Avoid the Logitech wheels completely, I've heard that this problem effects many of the older wheels now too, since a software update. Better to play it safe and go with Thrustmaster is what I've heard.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Feels like I'm at the track.
content: All I can say is wow!! There are times I have to look around the room to see if I'm still there and not sitting in a race car on the track. The sensitivity is amazing that when I am racing and my car starts to fishtail, I almost feel like I'm moving sideways myself. You feel every bump imaginable. I did a lot of research before ordering the Logitech and compared this to the Thrustmaster racing wheel. My brother has the Thrustmaster and I was impressed the moment I tried it but I decided to go with the Logitech because of the price difference. Well, that is the only difference I can see, the Logitech is as responsive and maybe even more so. You won't be disappointed.

author: Trevor Robson
title: On PC, plug and play right into project cars
content:
Mod the brake petal, seriously, mod the brake petal...in case I wasn't clear...mod the brake petal.
-1 Star because I had to mod the brake petal.
Otherwise it's solid.
Good feedback, quite accurate, and solid feel.
But that stupid piece of rubber in the brake petal. I could only get 57% travel on the brake petal without standing on it. Even without the rubber, the brake is tight.
Anyway, if you have an xbox get this wheel, if you have a ps4 get the other one. If won't get a console, just pick one...but this wheel is quite solid.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Excellent controller.
content:
I'm not some e-sports celebrity racer or anything, so you can be sure I don't know what I'm talking about, but this wheel kicks ass.

Many folks comment about the brake pedal mod, and, honestly, yes, you need to do this, but its simple and there are many videos on YouTube.  The brake pedal damper is way to heavy.  Cut down the rubber stopper to your liking and you're good to go.

Forces in the wheel are generally lag free and realistic (depending on the game, and your preferences).  Control is crisp and accurate in all axis'.  Build quality is surprisingly good, easily the sturdiest controller I've owned in 30 years of buying this stuff.

I love the carpet spikes, the pedals never move no matter how hard I jam on them.

In short, its a really good set.

Also with the squeaking sound when turning left I looked for troubleshooting options on Youtube and its quite a frequent problem amongst the owners of the wheel hopefully it just goes in time.

author: ShibaDog
title: Great Value |  Some Limitations | Would  buy it again.
content:
This a nice driving wheel and pedal set. I'm using it with an Xbox One and exclusively for Forza 6. I would consider myself a Beginner to Intermediate user of the Xbox One and Forza. I purchased the G920 because the pedals specifically got good reviews for quality, so I wouldn't need to purchase an upgraded set of pedals. The reviews were accurate. The pedals are not excellent, but good enough for intermediate drivers, I think.

Remember, this is a USB-connect wheel and pedal set, so don't assume you'll be able to connect it to your Xbox wirelessly. But the upside is that you can use it with other USB connect platforms.

Pros:
1. Responsive wheel and realistic force feedback.
2. Good production quality.
3. Mounts to my Playseat well, and is very stable.
4. The tightening knobs for the mount push down out of the way after tightening to the Playseat deck or your desk/table.
5. Very reliable, and it has not given me any problems after months of almost-daily use. I leave the wheel settings in their default positions and tune car performance in Forza's "Tune" menu. Maybe not the right way to do it, but works for me.

Cons:
1. The adjustment range of the clamps that secure the wheel to your desk/table is not sufficient to accommodate a thicker table top. It needs another inch or so of travel.
2. The thumb toggle on the left of the control pad section sometimes refuses to move to the right without carefully pressing it just the right way. It works but is finicky.
3, there is no headset hookup on the wheel, so you need to attach a headset to your console. You can connect a handheld controller and the G920 simultaneously and connect the headset to the controller, for online chat; but it's a little bit of pain in the a$$ to do it that way and it will "time out" and cut sound, so you need to keep it "alive" by touching it frequently.

All in all, from the view of a "non-expert" user, this seems to be a competent and reliable wheel & pedal set at an affordable price point, and performs as advertised. I wish it had a headset hookup.

author: Timbo
title: Brake is Way too Hard to Press
content: I was so excited to get this and the stand for it. When it came in, I used it for about 10 minutes and it's been in the closet with the winter coats and boots since. The only reason that I hate using it is the brake. You almost have to stand up out of your chair and STAND ON IT to get it to work. The brake tension is set about 5x higher than it should be. Until they fix that, this is a complete waste of money, unless of course, you play Nascar games, where you just step on the gas and turn left for five hours.

title: Okay but not sure it's worth over $300
content:
I've owned the Xbox 360 Microsoft wheel and wanted one for my Xbox One to play Forza 6 and Horizon 2. Also just ordered F1 2016.
In any case, I was disappointed that the shifter was a separate clamp on mechanism from the wheel as it took too much space for my set up. And the paddles seemed cheap being made of stainless steel in my opinion. Also, the USB cable that connects to the console was too short for me although an extender cable worked well.

On carpet, the foot pedals didn't slide as the flip anti-skid worked well. The instructions were so-so and had to look online for more info.

author: Old Truck Guy

author: YoyoBear
title: Several replacements, all of them had unique issues. Refunded.
content:
I went through 3 replacements. One went missing in shipping. Each one had a unique problem. First (original) one would get misaligned during gameplay. Second (1st replacement) had a loud screeching noise when turning. Third went missing. Fourth was perfect then it started to misalign, have a loud screeching noise, then flat out malfunctioned thus becoming not usable in any shape or form. The gear system feels like old tech but the feel of the texture and look of the wheel is great.

I can't imagine this wheel being usable for long term. The pedals a good thoough.

author: heavy-haul
title: got second one same problem very bad product so now sending back for

author: GP Russell

author: SF
title: it's not perfect or anything like steering a real car
content: Bought this wheel to play Dirt 4 and Gran Turismo Sport on PS4 and it does work very well, it's not perfect or anything like steering a real car, but it sure is far superior to using a ps4 controller. Dirt 4 is now actually fun to play, game was clearly not designed for a controller. If you have few hundred $$$ burning a hole in your pocket and are a car enthusiast, you cant go wrong with this wheel. Like I said, it's not perfect: there are some dead zones, feedback is artificial, but it does simulate steering a race car well. and if a game is designed for this controller, then you can customize feedback and sensitivity to your liking and driving style.

author: MB
title: Great Wheel

author: Kyle

content: Works great better than what I expected for a starter wheel I just started using it tonight I will update if I have any issues with either the wheel or peddles the break is like every one says though, really tight, i would recommend a nice stand for it I don’t see anything but nice stand or a sturdy desk working very well with the force feedback at 100 percent, deff not the strongest on the market force feedback wise but deff a lot better than I thought it would be it will make your Arms soar after about an hour on real racing 2 with force feedback all the way up, Ohhh and I drive for 4-10 hours a day so I’m use to having my arms up, point is it does really really well for an entry level wheel and really recommend it like i said I will up date if I have any issues with it

The force feedback it's pretty good and the paddles are good too. The price when it is not on sale is a bit too high so wait until it gets marked off atleast 40%.

author: Amazon Customer

It is a very commonly reported problem. While the wheel was working correctly, it worked very well. I’m giving four stars, because if my wheel wasn’t malfunctioning, it would’ve been great. Customer service was also easy.

author: Glenn A. Miller Jr.

author: dion cross
