content: Great wheel for beginners, lots of plastic so not professional grade. But hours of fun and great start to pc / console fun in most sim racers and driving games

author: Manuel Acosta Palmer
title: Like the g25 did for me years ago
content:
This is the second logitech wheel Ive used (the previous being a g25 I used with Gran Turismo on the ps3. Like the g25 did for me years ago, this wheel transforms Forza into a whole new experience. It feels like a brand new game.

The force feedback is strong and accurate. I actually ended up building a solid platform to properly use the wheel, as anything not solidly built would simply move too much. The inputs from the wheel are immediate, and make you feel like youre in the car. The only downside (and its a matter of taste) lies in the pedals. Specifically, the brake pedal. If feels way too stiff, but with time you get used to it. So im not deducting a star because of this.

Overall Im really happy with my purchase.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Design flaw in wiring harness will render this wheel useless in no time - See link in my post to proof on Logitech forum.
content:
After about 3 hours of use, I'm getting "phantom" button presses of the "Share" button and "Options" button while racing. That can kill a great race in hurry as it pauses the race in Project Cars (great game by the way) at the most annoying moments. After a quick Google search, I found loads of people in the Logitech forums having the same issue caused by a design flaw in the wiring harness that connects all the buttons in the wheel to the base.

Please read the posts in the following link to the logitech forum before making this purchase: [...]. This is page 3 of the thread in which someone actually took the wheel apart to discover the problem.

My next step is to contact Amazon for a return, but not an exchange unless they can assure me that Logitech has implemented a design change that will rectify the issue. If no change has been made, it's Thrustmaster for me. I will say though, for the 3 hours it worked, I have no complaints. Great feel, great pedals and I love the external stick shift (separate purchase). I also have a PS3 force feedback wheel by Logitech that's worked great through years of abuse.

author: Mohamed Refae
title: Sounded like something gotten loose in there
content: Had the wheel for less than 3 days. I barely even used it and it started squeaking when I turned it left. Sounded like something gotten loose in there. Had to return it

author: Robert Weston
title: Was amazing until it stopped working. Logitech customer support is a joke.
content: My 11 year old son got this for his birthday and I’ll admit even the adults love it. You really need the (additional, expensive) racing chair to use it well as it needs to mount to something to be stable. Sadly, the wheel stopped working and while online I can find others experiencing the same problem, Logitech is just giving me the runaround. It’s been a month of trying to get help from logitech, sadly I still have nothing but a broken wheel. Had a replacement been easy to get I would still be very happy but certainly not worth the price if it won’t hold up.

author: Austin S.
title: Too much Flex, no cable management.
content: High priced for what is included. Flexes quite a bit still. Wheel post twists at times even when locked. No cable management. Unless you have the wheel reclined at steep angel toward your lap you still end up hitting knees. Also makes it a little awkward to swap drivers vs getting out of a traditional seating. I don't dislike the product enough to return. I don't enjoy it enough to recommend it.

author: Steve
title: I know there a better systems out there
content: I know there a better systems out there, but for the money you can't beat this. When setup and fine tuned this thing will give you a work out. I was a IMCA modified driver and it's hard to believe the amount of feedback this wheel gives you.

author: Zeph
title: Premium price tag, mediocre product
content:
I didn't expect much, and I was still disappointed.

Feels like a kids toy, the mounting clamps built in are a total joke. Wost of all the Force Feedback isn't an option and it's pretty strong, made infinitely worse by the atrocious mounting clamps. If you cannot get it mounted, it's completely unplayable.

author: Teri
title: Good wheel; but huge scam if you already own a g27
content: Quality is top notch and good sale price. Almost identical to the g27 that I already have. But shame on you Logitech for forcing me to buy a new wheel for my ps4 when I have a perfectly good g27 that I love and paid $300 for only 2-3 years ago. Huge scam, wish I could go to another manufacturer but Logitech has the market cornered with their fine product and they know it.

author: BoonDock Saint
title: Night and day
content: Coming from a $70 wheel and pedals this is night and day. I still have a PS3. this works seamlessly with F1 2014 and Driver san Francisco. It also works seamlessly with the original GRID. (Which Sony is selling for 10 bucks online!) Leather wrapped wheel, aluminum and steel construction. Fit and finish are excellent.  you NEED a wheel mount with this, it produces A LOT of torque.  I bought this on black Friday for 199. I personally wouldn't have paid full price for it. Not that it's not worth it, it's just a bridge too far.

author: al
title: If not bolting down it could be a little loose
content: I love this product, I was hesitant at first thinking it was gonna be difficult to get used to, the wheel is a little tedious to adjust and the clamps could be better but otherwise amazing

author: Scott K. Brigham
title: Best Wheel for the Price
content: Awesome mid range steering wheel combo. Chose Logitech over Thrustmaster after researching. Thrustmaster set comes with the cheap pedals...FOR SAME PRICE (roughly). Quality pedals are essential. I have several friends with a Logitech G920 and only 2 with the Thrustmaster (and 1 of them only bought it because G920 was not available at that time). Their feedback was priceless

author: JC
title: Son thinks it's okay
content: But it's too oversensitive sometimes.

author: Nate
title: I am giving up on all things Logitech after my experience with these wheels and their poor customer service.
content:
TL;DR: These wheels have notoriously poor reliability and worse customer support. But when the G29 works, it's great.

In late November, I purchased a G27, which came defective (the wheel would align itself to about 10 degrees off center). I attempted to replace it through amazon but they were out of stock, so I went to Logitech. Unfortunately, Logitech's customer support takes at least 2 business days to respond to any message, so the process of confirming that I needed a replacement took about a week. Following that, Logitech said they would send me a shipping label and then did not contact me for about 2 weeks. At that point, I called support and they told me they were waiting for supply of G27s (which they don't make anymore...) Eventually, they decided to replace my wheel with a G29 and sent me a shipping label. This whole process took about a month.

A couple weeks later (this is now mid-January), the G29 came in, and it was a blast for a about 2 weeks, at which point this wheel also broke. This time, the issue is a faulty connection in the wheel which can either cause it to get stuck calibrating when plugged in, or cause the buttons to be unresponsive (or all activated) at many positions on the wheel. This is a common issue you can find in other reviews and forum posts. I have just contacted Logitech again, but for 2 and a half months of wheel ownership I have had a functional one for less than 2 weeks, and I expect to not have a functional wheel again for another month.

*EDIT* The wheel is coming tomorrow so I was spot on with the 1 month replacement period. Hopefully I get what I paid for this time.

author: R.S.C
title: Five Stars
content: Great quality and works as described.

author: EunJong Kim
title: Five Stars
content: The condition of the delivered item was good and this gear is perfect for racing game.

author: Jesse
title: Great intro setup for the money.  Take the time to calibrate it and you'll be happy.
content:
Overall, solid racing setup.  It starts as a good setup that with some modifications and calibrations make it a great setup.  If you're not sure if racing is your thing, get this.  It's one of the cheapest full setups you'll find for the money and won't totally break the bank.  I for one will probably upgrade, but this bridges the gap nicely.

The Wheel - Very good quality materials, paddle shifters responsive and sturdy, decent force feedback.  Since I use this for Project Cars 2, I applied the almost mandatory Jack Spade profile, which made the FF excellent.  Others have stated this saved the game for them.

The pedals - Sturdy, somewhat heavy plastic base, good quality pedals with a good throw... except...the brake pedal.  At first I thought it was broken, but then did some research.  Logitech was trying to emulate a real brake pedal which has more resistance.  I just did a recalibrate on it and it does indeed feel more realistic.  I give light pressure for normal braking, and if I need to slam the brakes and lock up the wheels, I have to put some leg into it.  I like that.  People it's not hard, there is calibration and there are mods.  Luckily, I didn't need to mod it.

Shifter - Not too impressed, however I cannot beat Logitech up too bad, as this only cost 60 bones. It has an okay quality.  It is very loose between the grooves and I frequently miss gears because of this.  There is a relatively cheap mod to fix this as well.  It also does not have a sequential mode like other shifters.  There is a way to make this happen too, but it involves rubber bands and such.  I will most likely sell this and get a shifter with both modes with better materials.

author: Josh Oxendine
title: I don't know how I ever made it without it.
content: Went from running midpack racing online with a controller to winning. 66hrs with the wheel with no issues.

author: Justin Rose
title: Fun!!
content: Use it for pc and ps4. Tons of fun!!! Definitely recommend for race simulator fans!

author: C. Holmes
title: A big steaming pile of dump on WIndows 10
content: So it detected fine, but the clutch was mapped to the Y axis, so in games they thought the clutch was the accelerator. The actual accelerator was unable to be mapped. No amount of removing, reinstalling, or rebooting fixed this. Boxed it up and sent it back. Googled this issue and it's been a problem for years on Logitech's end. I normally love logitech, this is my first negative for them. Just beware this wheel is not up to par.

author: rafael
title: Five Stars
content: Good perfect

author: Bryan
title: I may have just gotten a bad one, but I'm extremely disappointed
content:
I may have just gotten a bad one, but I'm extremely disappointed. At first glance and use this seems like a great wheel and pedal set. In spite of the design being a little toy-like, the leather wrapped wheel feels high quality. Gameplay is good at first, but I ran into problems right away. Midway through a race, the centering will suddenly be off by 10-45 degrees or more causing the vehicle to become impossible to control. At times the steering would go all the way right or left and not allow me to drive at all. I've recalibrated and tried in Project Cars 2 and DriveClub VR with the same issue.

Does this product actually work for people? Logitech, please feel free to reach out. I'm returning this one and not happy, but willing to give this product another try and will update the review if I can try one that works.

author: Tamara Uhor
title: GEARHEAD MUST HAVE!
content: This wheel is very nice. I upgraded from the thrustmaster 458 spider wheel and there is a dramatic difference. I would have given 5 stars if the shifter was included because this wheel is a little pricey.

author: Kenzie
title: Ok product, great customer service.
content: Great product up until the steering wheel started making a noise. Company was able to swap it out for me immediately. Great customer service!

author: Auntie M
title: Five Stars
content: Works great, makes gaming more fun. Would highly recommend to anyone who asks.

author: Crossfeed
title: Four Stars
content: Good vehicle control and feedback.

author: Notyourfather
title: defective out the box, tech support useless.
content:
Defective out of the box. Usb disconnects every couple of minutes, seems to be a fairly common problem. I'll get one from a better manufacturer, personally I think logitech is garbage these days. Tech support was just going to send a new one but I don't feel like waiting weeks for them to get off their butts and do it.

Update
So I opted for a replacement wheel instead. I returned the broken one for a refund. This one works, so I'll bump it up to 3 stars. The problem with finding a decent wheel these days is they all seem to have issues. The thrustmaster ones feel great, but most fail in a year or two and have to be repaired. Logitech if you can find one that works seem to hold up longer from what I've read. We'll see.

author: Jeff Gray
title: Shifter
content: I purchased a g920 wheel and it was working great for a couple months then all of a sudden it did t work it was the shifter every time I tried to use the shifter the wheel just wouldn’t connect it works fine without the shifter other than that it works great

author: Jose Daniel Castro Hinojoza
title: Do the brake mod
content:
I got this 2 days ago, when I first connected it my game wouldn't recognize it even thought I saw the device connected and everything. I downloaded the logitech software for the product and it worked.

But after that like everyone is saying, the brake pedal is so hard to press, with all my force I was getting maybe 60% press but I wasn't going to play like that. After removing the piece of plastic inside the brake it works like a charm now.

author: Cory
title: Seemed great, then...
content:
Logitech's latest driver update did stop the constant blue screen crashes, however the Force/Vibrate functions often crash for no apparent reason during gaming. Reconnecting the USB does restore Force/Vibrate, but still irritating as often as it happens... With all that aside, this wheel is excellent for racing games. The feedback feels great, and doesn't seem to feel under or over powering. The built in clamps are disappointing, small jaw opening, loose and wobbly. The pleather wheel feels great, paddles are nicely stamped steel, high quality xbox controller buttons. The pedals are ok. Gas pedal is ok and not wildly sensitive, Clutch is a simple pedal with just a slight resistance, clutch engagement ranges can be adjusted allowing you to use personalize where you like the clutch throw. The break pedal is good, but make sure you have the pedals against a wall or something very heavy so you don't push them away. I disagree with the people who say the break pedal is too hard, and removing the rubber resistance as some are saying, is not a good idea, it feels good enough. However a hydraulic break pedal would have felt most accurate, and weigh the pedals down just right... So, that brings me to the price. It is very much over priced, I would rate it at 180-200usd maximum. For the price I payed, I was more expecting professional simulation hardware, more fabrics and metals, and higher quality parts,  but it is mostly a cool glorified xbox controller. Don't let my slightly negative review stop you from considering this, Its Awesome, and a Necessity if You Enjoy Driving games.
Edit: Month later, its getting quite irritating that there has not been one day where the wheel hasn't crashed my game. I wish I knew what it was like to exit my game instead of crash to desktop.... Logitech doesn't appear to even have the ambition to improve or fix this. I guess I payed $500 for fancy looking piece of s***.

author: Pariah Zero
title: Good value, but nowhere near the top of the line.
content: This is a decent Wheel for beginners. It’s the Toyota Corolla of wheels - a basic machine at a reasonable price. It’s not the wheel that many others are, but it also doesn’t have the accompanying price tag. There are upgrades for people willing to void the warranty; but it is decent out of the box.

author: bmal1
title: If you are going to race this wheel will help
content: Son loves it. He is on racing games a lot and says it much better than a keyboard or a controller

author: Raul G.
title: From DFGT to G29; Logitech Delivers a Fine Racing Wheel!
content:
I guess the first place to start my review is by saying that I do know about the controversy surrounding the G27 and as an owner of the Logitech DFGT, which I used for many years with GT5 & 6 and various other awesome PS3 racing games, I feel the twinge of anger. I do not and will not speculate about the "security chip" claim that Logitech has and continues to make. I am reviewing this wheel, to the best of my ability, as a standalone product.

--------------------
PRODUCT DESCRIPTION:
--------------------
Years ago when I wrote my original review for my DFGT I was beaming with happiness; GT5 Prologue had been released (the taste of car-crack that I had grown up with on PS1 and PS2) and my decision to buy the DFGT was validated the very first lap. I felt a lot of that same happiness when I fired up Driveclub (yes, Driveclub) and the G29. This is a beautiful, well-made piece of gaming goodness.

Since I do not own (but have used) the G27 I'm going to compare the G29 more to my DFGT. So to start...

►Build Quality:
From the moment I unboxed the G29 I loved the quality of the materials and how it came together. You're getting a real leather wrapped wheel, high-quality metal pedals and flappy-paddles shifters. Extensive use of plastics are found on the G29 no doubt but again the key is high-quality plastics.

►Force Feedback & Turn Radius:
I tinkered around with the force feedback setting in Driveclub until I found something that felt good. I'll say that out of the box the configuration is pretty good. However, going from using my DS4 to a full-on racing wheel was a huge gameplay shift so I spent quite a bit of time sliding around the track. The force feedback felt a bit too strong so I dialed it down. One of the things I distinctly remember loving about the FF is the connection it helps the player make with whatever racing game you're playing. That is still very much true with the G29; I immediately felt connected to the road as I drove my M3 and then later Pagani Zonda around Canada, India and various other in-game locations. You feel the road shift, bumps, rumble strips and run-out areas... it's pretty amazing and totally immersive.

The steering wheel also features a full 900° turning radius. It's important to note that because not all racing wheels do and you can sometimes find yourself running into the limitations of the hardware when playing a game.

►Pedals:
The pedals with the G29 are excellent. You're getting real metal pedals here not plastics like with my DFGT. Each pedal has a different amount of pressure required to press the pedal down. The brake distinctly feels like a brake and not like the clutch or accelerator. I will say that I haven't purchased the optional shifter (yes, optional) so my experience with the clutch was pretty limited. I do intend on buying the shifter I just haven't done so yet. So I'll update my review then.

--------------------
PRODUCT USE:
--------------------
I'll keep this a bit shorter since I mentioned using the G29 with Driveclub. I will say again that I really do love almost all of the G29. The steering is tight, force feedback is excellent and strong - so much so that I turned the setting down; the pedals are realistic and responsive. If you've never slurged and purchased a driving wheel you simply cannot go wrong with the G29. This is almost the complete package...

I will say I have two areas of disappointment with this wheel:

1) You have to purchase the shifter separately for the cost of a new PS4 game. Ouch.

2) The flappy paddle gearbox (to borrow a favorite term from Top Gear) is not good. Let me describe it this way - it's "squishy". Each paddle shifter has to be squeezed toward the driver and it feels like I'm squishing a stress ball inside the G29 assembly. My own car has paddle shifters and they're so much more better; crisp and responsive with a satisfying "click". Not so much here. Yes, this paddles will have to do if you don't intend on getting the shifter but they're not great.

--------------------
THE GOOD:
--------------------
(+) Materials. From a real leather wrapped steering wheel to metal pedals and paddle shifters Logitech did a nice job bringing the G29 together into a premium racing wheel.

(+) Force Feedback. I love the power behind the force feedback motor and even had to dial it down in Driveclub.

(+) Shift Indicator. Just like your favorite supercar or F1 this wheel features LED indicator lights right on the steering wheel. It's a little gimmicky but cool!

(+) Button Arrangement. I love that the L2/R2 and L3/R3 buttons are light blue and a good contrast to the rest of the wheel making them easier to find.

(+) PS4 Buttons. The 'Options' & 'Share' buttons are easy to find as is the 'PS' button. Great for quick in-game snaps.

(+) Quick Setting. The G29 retains some of the DFGTs button layout including the quick setting buttons and radial toggle.

--------------------
THE BAD:
--------------------
(+) Shifter. I have to mention it... the G29 is as much as the PS4 and you still have to buy the shifter separately! That stings!

(+) Paddle Shifters. Channeling Jeremy Clarkson here... the flappy paddles aren't great. It feels like I'm squeezing fruit when shifting. I really wish these were more satisfying to use.

--------------------
CLOSING:
--------------------
All in all I cannot wait to use the G29 on more games. I've avoided buying Project Cars up to this point because of mixed reviews but will probably jump over after I'm bored with Driveclub. For now the G29 and Driveclub is my gaming nirvana. Aside from a few downsides as mentioned this is a fantastic product and easily one I recommend!

author: A**88
title: It's junk
content: We bought this three months ago and it's sparking and locking up! I do not recommend!

author: Eric M Heenie
title: A Must for serious PS4/PS3/PC racers! GREAT PRODUCT
content: Wow...I've been waiting years for a driving wheel...glad I waited until the g29 came out, I've seen many g27 owners leave negative comments but I couldn't be happier! patience is a virtue and now I can play all my old ps3 and ps4 racing games with this awesome wheel. one day shipping for only $9.99 on top of it, gotta love amazon prime :-)

author: G. Brown
title: this is great. wish it came with the shifter
content: this is great. wish it came with the shifter, but i have the thrustmaster one and thats way better anyways.

author: Bigmcbr
title: best ever.
content: it is the best wheel and peddle set i have ever had.thank.s

author: Amazon Customer
title: IT's great because this wheel not only works with my ps4 ...
content: I havent had a wheel since the mad katz one for ps1. The driving wheel has come along way. I certainly wont be able to go back to racing with just a controller again. IT's great because this wheel not only works with my ps4 it also works with my ps3.

author: Chris M.
title: Works great on xbox
content: Works great on xbox. But I bought it mainly for my pc gaming. Won't even recognize on the computer and the software will not install. The break pedal is very hard to push.

author: Stanislao
title: I feel I got more than I've pay!
content:
For me this is the best steering wheel for beginners, this bring rpm led indicator what is awesome and there is not another wheel of this price with that feature, also the steering wheel is cover with leather that make it look nice,
Pedals: the brake pedals bring a load cell that help you to regulate the brake pressure and this pedals are really better than the thrustmaster 150 pro bring with it...
In my opinion this steering wheel could be more expensive than thrustmaster t150 pro and it is even cheaper!

author: bimota
title: Five Stars
content: Just enough performance for light users but worry about reliability since my old G27 didn't last a year.

author: NLS
title: Didn't cost $2000+
content: It was on sale when I bought it. It's not cheap, but it's definitely the most expensive thing out there.

author: K. Asche
title: Five Stars
content: Love this wheel. Works as expected.

author: Brandon
title: I imagined this feeling at least somewhat like i was actually driving
content: This does not have nearly the fluidity in turning/handling that the online gaming reviews would lead you to believe.  After reading many reviews, I imagined this feeling at least somewhat like i was actually driving. Not so much.... This felt like a $300 kid toy and full of regret.  I can drive just as well with my controller.

author: Getahinsh Productions
title: Check game compatibility before buying!
content: Sure the quality is amazing, the feedback is great. Bought mine when it was $200. Thought it would be just the best thing to add to my racing experience.... WRONG! It's only compatible with maybe 10 games on PS4 and about 18 games on PC but they aren't any of the newer games that have come out since 2015. God forbid trying to connect it to your PC. You have to download drivers and then you have to force your computer to think it's an Xbox controller to which half of the buttons don't work. Then trying to load a game hoping it recognizes your game/wheel. And should it notice the wheel it won't pick up the petals. I am very unhappy with this product.

author: Jeff
title: Great Steering Wheel for PC.
content: Excellent Wheel. Build quality is great. Setup was pretty easy to do on the PC with the Logitech G hub application I had to download and it was pretty much plug in and play. I was able to use it in all my games that supported a steering wheel and it worked flawlessly. The force feedback is realistic and an awesome feature and it felt like im in an actual car or truck while holding the wheel. Would recommend to anyone looking for a great and dependable wheel.

author: eNerGy
title: Great wheel, but so very very Notchy
content:
After much research I chose this wheel based on other reviews of this product and the price. Everything about this wheel, pedals and shifter are amazing except for the obvious notchy feeling with the force feedback and resistance. It is annoying and really detracts from the realistic feel its supposed to give. I gave it some time in the hopes that it would wear in or that I could manipulate the settings enough, but to no avail. It is so annoying that I will be taking the wheel apart to understand and hopefully find a remedy for it. If that does not work I will be selling it.
Other than that it is a solid wheel and really really good quality for the money.

author: Steven Stevens
title: Four Stars
content: It’s great I enjoy it

author: Gustavo Barbosa
title: Excellent Feedback Wheel with Pedals.
content: I got it in a promotion and price was very close to much simpler systems.  The Logitech G920 seems robust and works perfectly in my PC with Forza 7 and Need for Speed (after installing Logitech software).  Playing with this wheel and pedals is another world. I was playing using my keyboard only and I could not play these games for more than 10min... was very disappointing. Now with the G920 I can spend hours as it is so fun and realistic. I will buy a special chair or even those systems that includes the chair and wheel/pedal support.  The Logitech G920 is really a nice upgrade for your car gaming with very good overall quality.  I will test now in my Xbox One. I do recommend.

author: mitchell
title: Get it
content: It's dope

author: Amazon Customer
title: Great wheel and pedals and even better customer service
content:
I have my Logitech wheel and pedals for 18 months with TONS of use.  I love both.

Recently I encountered a problem and contacted them.  Their service was terrific.  After an initial on-line warranty form, they contacted me with some suggested solutions.  When these did not work I called them and always had a very helpful person to talk to.  They quickly OK'd my issue under warranty and shipped me a new wheel.  I could not have been happier.  Their service was 180 degrees from the "service" my friend received on his Thrustmaster pedals which he is still trying to solve.

Highly recommended.

author: Amazon Customer
title: This thing is fantastic! Solid feedback and resistance when you enter a ...
content:
suh---WEEEET! Had a driving wheel years ago for the PS2. Blew chunks. Horrid. Swore off the things. Buddy tells me they are huge improved, try them again. Read reviews, this one gets GLOWING commentary except for its price. I figure you get what you pay for, so I try it....YOU GET WHAT YOU PAY FOR! This thing is fantastic! Solid feedback and resistance when you enter a corner too hot and stress the front end. It actually wants to kick back at you and fight you as you force your ride to try and violate the laws of physics.
You want solid, honest performance and feedback? Buy this damn thing. You wont regret it.

author: Amazon Customer
title: returned
content: not worked comfortably

author: Tammielynn
title: Live it
content: Love the price! I love how its interchangeable between game system and computer.

author: Matt
title: New car smell
content:
The Logitech G29 is one impressive piece of gaming equipment.  I'm a huge fan of driving/racing games and I was stoked for the opportunity to review this product.  So let's get to it.  (I've also never used a G27, so I won't compare that iteration to this one.  Instead, I'll focus solely on the G29).

Firstly, this is a spectacular looking wheel.  It looks like it belongs in a real luxury car.  It's that good.  The presentation and build are both top notch.  Aside from the slightly smaller size, it passes as a legit wheel.  I absolutely love it and I'm completely enamored with it.  The pedals, too, feel like real peddles.  They have excellent spring.  The only change I would maybe consider would be to spread out the pedals a bit more, if it were possible.  But that's really a preference rather than a complaint.

Setting it up was relatively simply on PC.  I had to download the software from the Logitech website.  The software allows you to set up profiles for individual games, or use existing profiles for your games.  I found the set up is user-friendly and easy to navigate.

I was quite surprised that the shifter is sold separately.  If you want a shifter, plan on adding another $60 to cost, which at $400 is already quite hefty.  The wheel and shifter cost more than the cost of a new PS4.  Looking at it that way, it does seem overpriced;  but I don't know the costs of R&D and production.

It does rather feel like a luxury at this price point, but if you can afford it, go for it by all means (especially if you don't already own a G27).

author: Jesse D. Sightler
title: Durable, high-quality wheel
content:
At the time that I purchased this, it was significantly less expensive than the TX 458 Leather edition. I think that pricing fits perfectly. The leather wrapped wheel is of a high quality and the pedals are excellent as well. I find that the break pedal provides excellent feedback, and while it is heavy I think this adds to the game rather than detracting from it. A little calibration can make it marginally less heavy if desired as well and it is easy to get the level of braking force that you want.

The steering itself is excellent, and the driving motors are relatively quiet. The feel is slightly notchy due to the gearing and it does have a slight issue with poor on-center feel. In practice, I have found neither of these issues to be significant to me. Also, the wheel can produce quite a bit of force when turned up all of the way. I don't think a higher level of feedback is needed at all.

Overall, it is an excellent product. Everything about it feels well made and durable.

author: Amazon Customer
title: great feeling and precise control in braking and accelerating
content: awesome force feedback. great feeling and precise control in braking and accelerating.

author: Shenanigans335
title: Great wheel!
content: I love it. Knew I would. Great for a wheel using helical gears.

author: FH
title: I can see why it's struggling to get that fifth star. Tested for PC.
content: Only buy if you are expecting to have to download modifications for it to work completely for pc or have googled the games you play thoroughly in terms of compatibility to see the fine print of what works and doesn't work. For such an expensive wheel, the compatibility out the box is very poor. Some of the listed games on the logitech website work very well, such as Forza, but trying it with Grid or Dirt required far too much software mods to get it to work. Spending time on Google showed some people had different experiences. From my experience, the wheel turns off its force feedback as well depending on the game if it is incompatible, then you have to keep replugging it back in to get the feedback back on.  Some games if not most, the shifter is completely useless and will not work no matter what I try. Also the shift lights are compatible with almost no games without installing a third party program that also didn't seem to work for me, but at that point I was super impatient with all the downloading/googling I had to do. It's just the price point is too high to have this little support. Could buy something better and don't think this wheel is worth the high price. Ended up requesting a return.

author: Amazon Customer
title: sweet setup. very good wheel
content: sweet setup. very good wheel. best i've used. play with the settings in-game to get it right, the wheel isn't the issue.

author: R. Koenecke
title: Logitech G-920 Works Great with Xbox one
content:
Works great with my Xbox One, after a simple Logitech software update via the UBS cable.
Pedals and shiftier work great, together it creates a very realistic experience.

author: Alex
title: Logitech Wheels getting worse and worse
content: I want my G25 back! :( Don't plan on steering fast with this thing because itll likely lose center and you'll have to re calibrate it! pitiful.

author: DONGGEUN LEE
title: Five Stars
content: it's perfect.

author: Jordan
title: Do your research before you buy!
content:
This is a solid wheel.

I love holding the wheel.

I love the smell of the wheel.

I like the metallic paddle shifters.

It's not loud, but it's not quiet either.

While it has some special buttons, it does not have all of the buttons found on a PS4 controller.

IT DOES NOT HAVE A MIC INPUT.

Interested to see what the special GTSport wheel looks like.

author: Tom
title: The brake is very accurate feeling
content:
I'm a fan of track driving I'll get 20-30 days track time each year.

title: This wheel is awesome, and completely changes how immersive Forza 6 is ...
content: This wheel is awesome, and completely changes how immersive Forza 6 is compared to just using a controller. This was given to me as a gift and I couldn't be happier. The force feedback works well and the materials used on the wheel and pedals are of high quality. It took me only ten minutes to set up and get going on the Xbox One. author: Kindle Customer
title: Very Satisfied
content:
This is my first PC racing wheel and I'm very satisfied with it.  With that being said, I cannot compare this product to others.

PROS:
-Solid construction
-Good quality without the $600 price tag of their competitors
-Responsive wheel, turns easily and fluid
-Force Feedback is fantastic - can decrease and increase within most game settings.
-3-pedal system - brake, accelerator, clutch.
-Wheel is comfortable to grip - doesn't slip in hands.
-Easy to set-up (I'm using Windows 10 64-bit)
-Easy to add on the Logitech G Driving Force H-Shifter (just plug 'n play, then map the keys to the game)

CONS:
-Brake Pedal - way too hard to *fully* depress.  Even when placed against a wall, my chair wants to tip over to get to 100% braking.  The pedal gets to 80-90% easily without tipping me over in my chair (lol).  Regardless, it doesn't effect my games as my vehicles still come to a complete stop.
-Pedal base needs something for hardwood/vinyl flooring.  Rubber pads, even suction cups, would help.  As it is now, it's designed to be played on carpeted flooring.  Not a major issue though.
-Even though it's not as pricey as others, $300 remains to be a lot of money, but worth it if you enjoy driving/racing/trucking simulators.

Overall Verdict:  If you can afford it, get it!  I was thoroughly satisfied

author: Christopher Eagan
title: Good features for Pros Gamers, Good deal for Casual Gamers, Doesn't Excel at Anything.
content:
Logitech makes great products using quality materials and I see this wheel lasting a long time regardless of the user. All the other reviewers are absolutely correct regarding the brake pedal. This wheel is impossible to use with Forza 6 until you remove the rubber stop inside the brake pedal spring. This is not a difficult task. If you are comfortable using basic tools like a screw driver and have the patience to "mod" your brand new wheel, you can remove the rubber stop and the pedals then work brilliantly. Other commenters have said that the LED light on the wheel is very bright, which it is. Play in a lit room and that's not a big deal. Also, don't look at the wheel while driving. I personally think that the USB cable that connects the wheel to the Xbox is too short. I had to use a USB extension cable to reach my Xbox. I bought the shortest Amazon Basics one that would work to avoid introducing delays in the controller's response time in the game and it seems to work fine.

I also own the Mad Catz® Pro Racing™ Force Feedback Wheel and Pedals for Xbox One® which I love. In comparing the two, the MadCatz wheel is better for casual gamers who want a realistic experience. One of the mount options for the MadCatz wheel also you to use it right on your last without a stand. The Logitech wheel REQUIRES a stand. The Logitech wheel has a larger dead zone for the force feedback so the MadCatz wheel feels more responsive. The MadCatz wheel also comes with pedals that work correctly right out of the box and have adjustable springs so that you can create a brake pedal feel that works best for you. The Logitech pedals come with a clutch pedal, which is a big plus for pro drivers, but the minimal adjustability of the Logitech pedals makes them feel less pro than the MadCatz ones.

The perfect wheel for me would come with the adjustability of the MadCatz wheel and include the missing clutch pedal. I'd like the ability to adjust the dead zone for the force feedback to match my dead zone for the wheel input in-game. I don't think any wheel should require the purchase of a stand.

Logitech sent me a replacement. Within two weeks the pedals failed - pressing the throttle pedal was also actuating the brake.

Under warranty, Logitech sent me a third wheel, which after about six months developed the problem the first wheel had.
I would never buy a Logitech wheel again, regardless of price. What a joke

author: Jes Wiegel
title: Great Wheel but Horrible Break Pedal, BAD CHOICE for PC Gaming
content:
As my first gaming wheel, I did a lot of research on it before buying it. The wheel itself is great though I must say that Logitech really screws you over with this wheel regarding software functionality.

The wheel itself works great; has good force feedback and functionality. The brake pedal, however, is ridiculous; they put a black rubber piece inside of the pedal and it's horrible to deal with. I couldn't even push the pedal all the way down at full force; even people I know who have been wrenching and working on cars/trucks for years as mechanics had the same issue with the brake pedal. Removing it still leaves the brake pedal as the most difficult pedal to press but is much easier to use and not as frustrating. I honestly think putting the rubber piece in the brake pedal was a poor design choice.

My biggest complaint with the wheel though is the software made for it. Logitech ditched the Logitech Profiler for the Logitech Gaming Software for use with the G920/G29 and it's horrendous. You have no versatility with the software; getting it to work with games that aren't designed with the wheel in mind is a hit or miss and the only things you can change are the DOR and the center spring strength (not to mention combining pedals for certain games). The software is cheap and a horrible alternative to the Profiler, which they should've just updated and kept with the G920.

If you are looking for a PC Gaming wheel, this wheel is a massive disappointment and you should look to the G27 instead. The G27 has the same functionality but comes with the Logitech Profiler which is far superior to the crappy Gaming Software the G29/G920 has. All in all, great wheel functionality and design aside from the brake pedal, but extremely bad software support for PC Gaming.

title: One of the First Actual Owners - It's Great!
content:
Before Pre-ordering this wheel, the low reviews had me a bit concerned.  Then after reading, I saw that it was mostly people crying about the old wheel not being compatible with PS4.  Well that sucks, but it's no reflection on this wheel, and for the record it's Sony that didn't make the PS4 compatible.  The G27 may physically never be compatible and Logitech would never be able to anticipate what to expect in the PS4...Anyway, end soapbox.

I got the wheel last night, set it up, and tried it out with Project Cars.  What a difference right out of the box!  I haven't needed to change any settings (although the headlight and wiper buttons don't work...probably a minor setting change).  I recently tried a $75K simulator setup and the steering feel on this unit is just as good.  The pedal feel might even be better...  Good quality materials and a solid feel.  Mine is mounted to a Wheel Stand Pro.  Both products are well worth the money and are a great combo.  I guess my Porsche might be spending a little more time in the garage for a while, haha....

author: N.
title: Almost impossible to use the breaks without voiding warrenty
content:
Almost impossible to use the breaks without voiding warrenty by loosening them because of how stiff the breaks are.
The wheel feels like it's driving for you... You're just trying to hold the wheel and it literally yanks itself out of your hands unless you're holding it like a gun.(This must be what they mean by "feedback" driving..)
No one needs feed back from million dollar super cars; Do you have any idea how violent going from 0-60 in 1.5 - 2seconds is with feedback?
The simple act of going 0-60 in just a few seconds is enough for the feedback to literally spin you out, and when it feels like the game is fighting you like this it feels like you have no power steering BUT with a super car instead of your car irl. It just feels awful
And the idea that i'm doing something wrong when i'm perfectly capable of playing my second favorite genre along side fighting games with fighting sticks.. rediculous
I'm probably going to send everything back considering everything cost me half a grand of disappointment.

content:
It's to bad G27 not compatible with the PS4. It was better than this. The wheel is OK, don't get me wrong. But the buttons, what did I just hit. Oh, over and over again. I just want to pause the game but I end up at PS Menu or share, lol. The brake, if my car was like this I'd take it in and tell them its broke, lol. The tech these days has really went into the crapper. Who tests this stuff and says yeah, I like that. Have they even used a brake in a car? The other buttons seem farther away from the edge of the wheel than the G27. I need fingers that are about 2 inches longer so when I'm racing I can depress them. I'm tired of this crap. I should give it 3 stars cause that would be fair. But since I get screwed having to buy a shifter separately and I'm not as satisfied as their older version. screw that, it gets one. Extra 60 bucks deducts 2 stars, I think thats fair for a Fisher Price QA department. I'm tired of this cheap overpriced crap everybody keeps putting out. I must be getting old or something.
.

author: Regular Guy
title: You can't get any better for the price
content:
IMPORTANT: The software the wheel requires slams your CPU. My i7 7700k with watercooling heats up a ton after about an hour using this. Take this into consideration. Also the force feedback improves with the framerate so make sure VSYNC is off on all your games you use this with.

 Feels scarily realistic. The only thing I can recommend is buying an adapter and a full size steering wheel for true immersion since the wheel is 270mm and a real wheel is closer to 350mm. Brakes are stiff but are actually really good. See the pedal becomes very stiff after some travel and if you've ever tried to push the brakes ALL the way in your car you know the feeling. The first bit of travel is great if you are using a car with no ABS since it's about how hard you can press without locking up the brakes. Clutch is fairly light and throttle a little heavier but both are smooth and satisfying. If you have wide feet I recommend using this set with just socks. You'll have better throttle control anyway. Strongly recommend getting the shifter as well. If you don't know how to drive a manual you can learn/teach others with this set. Short of getting a simulation chamber with G-force emulation this is pretty good. Looks kinda goofy with all the buttons but they are a lifesaver in games with tons of bindings and the dial is good if you have a race car that has a turbo/supercharger you can adjust on the fly. If you love racing irl this is a great gift to yourself. I actually drive on the track even more quickly and safer now that I can practice all I want with this little rig for the cost of a hotter room. Recommend games like Assetto Corsa, Gran Turismo, Beamng, Euro Truck Sim. TONS of aftermarket upgrades too if you want to throw more money at your rig.

author: JDThird
title: First time race sim player, and this made all the difference for me
content:
Alright, I'll preface this by saying I'm not a racing sim person.  Never have been.  I'd gotten an earlier version of Forza for the Xbox 360 out of curiosity, and my son enjoyed it a bit, but neither of us really got into it, being into first person shooters instead on the consoles...

But in April I grabbed an Oculus Rift, and of course one of the things I ultimately had to try was a racing game, and it really turned it into a different experience. Enough that I decided I needed to try a wheel and pedals to control it, not just the Xbox controller.  So I did some digging, and this was the one that seemed to hit the right price point and was supported in the Project Cars game I have on the Oculus system.

Setting up couldn't be much easier - I was clamping it to my PC stand (https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B001BBKNI6/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1) and that actually worked quite well, but I did end up just ordering an actual racing wheel stand this evening to improve the experience.  The only thing I would've wanted them to change is to have some kind of plate or bar on the bottom to help hold all the cables in place as you're getting things set up.  There are small channels underneath this, where they run, so they're recessed and this sits flat on the surface you're clamping it to.  But I had issues with a short cable getting pulled out the first time I was setting things up.  Having something that slid over that to help keep them in place would've been nice.  But it's a minor annoyance, wasn't even worth dropping a star.

So once you get things plugged into this, you can connect it to power, but don't plug into the PC until you've installed the software, which will then prompt you to connect the USB cable.  I did this on Windows 10, and had no issues.

There was a firmware update right away, so I ran that as well.  Then it was time to play.

Project Cars in the Oculus had support for this, so that's what I tried first, and then realized that this is apparently a game that reverses the pedals by default, so I had to go into the options and remap all three pedals to get it to work.  But once I did that, I was quite blown away by the experience.

Having never used a racing wheel before, I didn't expect the force holding the wheel in place.  I expected force feedback as things happened, but I didn't realize how firmly this wheel was going to hold the center position.  But it's awesome since it really helps keep you stable.

Most of the video reviews and such talked about how it takes time to convert from a controller to a wheel, and that you can expect to "relearn" since it's a whole different experience.  I didn't have that issue, since my racing sim gaming was so minimal.  I took to it quite quickly, and inside of about three or four races, I had a good feel for it, and my performance soared compared to the hand held controller.

Many people complain about the bright light on the wheel above the Xbox button.  For me, not an issue since I have a headset on for the VR system, but I can see how that would be annoying if you're using monitors.  Nothing a bit of tape wouldn't solve, but I think the least they could have done is had an option in the software settings to turn the light off altogether.

Button placement is alright, I wish they had been a little closer to the wheel's edges to make it easier to hit, but they're not hard to get at as they are, just not quite as ergonomic as I would've hoped.

Unit is pretty quiet as well.

I see a lot of people complain about the brake pedal being stiff, and it certainly is, compared to the others, but for me it isn't an issue.  I may not know enough about these though to have the "right feel" for how it SHOULD be, and that may be why it doesn't bother me.  But as a total racing sim tyro, it's not causing me any issues at all.

For me, this really became a "Wow, I'm sure glad I got this!" kind of an item the first day I had it.  With the VR headset, this really completes the immersion.  And when it's on this desk I'm using right now, and I"m on the bench in front of the setup, my hands are EXACTLY where they show up in the Oculus, so the illusion is complete for me.

Feels great, love the resistance in turns since that really helps me keep on track and not spin out as much, and while the price seems steep to me, I didn't have many options considering I'm on a Windows 10 PC and may use it on the Xbox One as well at some point.  But while the price was steep, I'm looking at it as one of those, "You get what you pay for" things.  It completes the illusion of actually racing, and that made the price point less of an issue for me.

author: J. Cauthen
title: A serviceable and reliable wheel with a promising refinement path
content:
I picked up the Logitech G920, primarily for use with the XBox One and Forza 6, and Project CARS and iRacing on the PC.  So far it's doing a serviceable job with all three, but at the outset, it's not as refined as I would expect a next generation force-feedback steering wheel to be.  The force-feedback effects feel mostly one-dimensional to me, with the emphasis being on self-centering forces.  There's also a considerably significant force-feedback "deadzone" when the wheel is centered, even with Forza 6's inside dead zone set to "0", making the driving feel a bit sloppy.  I didn't expect optimum performance out of the box, as it's pretty clear that Turn 10 has as much of a hand in the way this wheel performs in Froza 6 as Logitech.  It will improve over time, hopefully to at least the level of performance I was seeing with my Fanatec GT2 on Forza 4, and the XBox 360.  Presently though, I can still turn in better times with the wheel than I can with the controller, while holding better lines in multiplayer racing, so that alone is worth the price of admission.

My biggest concern for this wheel was its helical gear drive.  I thought the potential for noisy gear operation might go beyond my tolerance level, after seeing and hearing some videos of the Mad Catz FF wheel in operation.  Much to my delight, I can't hear the helical gears in operation.  There is a "gritty" feel that I can associate to them, but it feels a lot like the steering in my Mazda Protege.  It's not an annoyance, but clearly not as smooth as the belt drive operation of my Fanatec GT2.

The process of pairing this wheel to my XBox One required more gyrations than Logitech's recommended process, which is quite busy on its own.  Once I got the two paired, it's not been a problem.  You can use another controller to enable chat via the headset plugged into it, but there's not miniplug on the wheel to accommodate the headset.

The G920 turns in equally pedestrian performances with iRacing and Project CARS on the PC, but at least both games are presently playable.  I have not yet plugged Jack Spade's latest force-feedback package into Project CARS, which reportedly will help with that. I'll report back and revise my review once I've had a chance to do so... installing that package is not an easy task though.

The pedals that come with the G920 are so-so.  The brake pedal has a built in damper that stiffens up too quickly, IMO.  The workaround is to shorten up the travel of the brake pedal in the tuning setup, but then you reduce the resolution and fine control of the brake pressure when doing so.  I wish there was a way to adjust the backpressure of the damper to your tastes, but alas, there is not.

The connecting cable for the pedals needs some strain relief.  It exits the pedal base without any sort of pigtail to reinforce it.  On a racing cockpit or stand that puts the pedal base at an angle, this cable is subjected to undue stress that could easily lead to a broken conductor, or two within.  I put a stress release loop in my cord and taped the cable to the base with electrical tape at an angle to keep the stress relief loop in place.

Overall, the G920 has a quality feel of construction.  The leather stitched wheel feels great there's no slop in the wheel operation.  It also seems to run cool.  The force-feedback force is probably less than what most belt driven force feedback wheels typically deliver.  I think it will feel better once more feedback forces are modeled by the games and the wheel's profiler.

author: Kyle D Smith
title: Awesome wheel!
content: Love the build and design of the wheel and pedals. The feel is great and the paddle shifters have a nice solid click every time. Only two complaints is that the feedback can be obnoxiously loud sometimes, like on gravel in Dirt Rally or running over some rough curbs. The sound is a rough clanking noise and if you're not bothered by sound, then it shouldn't deter you form getting it. The second is that the brake pedal can be a bit hard to press down completely. With a stand, I don't think it would be a problem but without a stand (which is my case) it can be a little annoying. That's all, great entry-level ffb wheel :)

author: B. Rowley
title: Questionable value for money; sub-par driving performance
content:
(Comparing to a Thrustmaster F430 Wheel, playing on Forza 6)

WHEEL
Compact base with hard-mounting holes. Desk-clamping system is much simpler than Thrustmaster's, but is entirely plastic. Seems strong, but may not last forever. The metal wheel body feels nice, with large metal paddles. Some of the buttons are tight, others are loose. Similar quality to the Thrustmaster. Wheel rim is stitched in leather, but I wouldn't consider this an upgrade. The stitching is thick and ugly, and some of the leather is not even tucked away properly, leaving rough edges. It is actually quite smooth, so I would definitely recommend wearing gloves if you take your driving seriously.

PEDALS
Love having a clutch pedal. The base is quite large, metal pedal faces feel good. The brake pedal is VERY stiff: you have to stand on it to depress all the way. All of the pedals experience a lot of play under compression: it seems like the hinges are left deliberately loose for some reason? Didn't affect feel or stability, but a bit concerning.

EXPERIENCE
The brake pedal takes a lot of getting used to. Most of the resistance seems to come from a rubber stop, which has the disadvantage of lacking feel. The harder you stand on the pedal, the harder it is to tell how much force you are applying. I dialed back the deadzone to create a shorter pedal, but now your pedal release is much more aggressive and upsets car balance. I feel bad complaining about this since a real racecar has a stiff pedal, but the execution here feels unsatisfying.

The wheel force is quite weak, even compared to the old Thrustmaster. Heavy impacts just don't feel heavy. Full-lock slides don't pull your arms back to center. The center-deadzone is much wider than the Thrustmaster's. Contrary to other reviews, I did not find any noise problems with the wheel: the sound of the accelerator pedal against the pedal base is louder. There seems to be some sort of calibration issue, too: the wheel controlled the Xbox, but Xbox would not show the device under Controller Settings.

OVERALL
Well, after about 6-10 hours of use, I returned the wheel. Switching back to a controller immediately feels lame, but my laptimes are consistently 2-3 seconds SLOWER with the wheel. Even at a sale price of $240, the poor force feedback and spongy brake pedal are poor issues. At full price, this seems like a rip-off.

author: OU812

author: Travis R.
title: G29 A great wheel,but Has Issues
content:
Ok, Dont get me wrong this thing is a great sim Wheel,  I tested on Project Cars, Nascar Heat, Driveclub, and Dirt Rally. The Wheel overall feels good, great sturdy build. The Force feedback is very strong and accurate Depending on the game your playing. Project Cars was in my experience the only time i noticed any Force feedback Dead zone about a Mm or 2 (very small), thats to be expected with a gear driven wheel tho. Also it can get loud, you will hear chatter and popping on higher FFB settings. If noise is a issue 4 you then you should look into a belt driven wheel. Can be pretty quite on lower settings also though. The pedals are Grade A Love them the brake mod feels perfect After it gets broke in. Only Problom is a Big one.  ALOT of These G29s are Defective They Stop working Randomly, and the wheel makes a bad ringing sound when turning, i had 2 get a replacement for Mine squeaking very badly. Amazon sent a new one and ive had it 4 days and it started squeaking even louder than the 1st one, for $400 this thing should be perfect and when working properly it is very awesome and fun. Its just a toss up on if you get a good unit with no issues. I am going 2 get another replacement, but untill then i cant recommend this at all. Unless u have prime and get a deal. //UPDATE// May 25 17 - after my third wheel and 200+ hours on it heres my conclusion,
/PROS/
-Great Force Feedback
-Little to no deadzone (on higher FFB settings )
-18 remapable buttons
-quality Build | Leather and Metal
-Can be Hard Mounted
-Compatable with Almost all Racing games on PS4
-pedals are heavy duty and can handle punishment
//CONS//
-Shifter sold separate 60$
-Shifter has a Very Short Throw (about 2in from 3rd to 4th) and feels kinda toy like
-Can get pretty Loud on higher FFB settings (Alot of Rattle )
-Gear Driven motors (reskin of G27)
-Brake Mod Requires breaking in, Very Stiff at first
- Had to get 3 Replacements Due to loud Ringing in Wheel

author: Jeff Kimble
title: So good it should come with its own racing seat
content:
This wheel took me a little getting used to but I am absolutely smitten with it now.  I have been using it on a PS4 and Project:CARS.

First, let's talk feedback.  This thing is SPOT. ON.  If you're serious about next-level racing sim, buy this wheel, buy a projector, and get ready to trick your brain.  Seriously.  Five minutes in and you'll have sweaty palms.  You'll find yourself talking to yourself and the car.  You'll palm the wheel in controlled drifts and bite the corner of your lip.  It's intense.  The feedback is just absolutely balanced and incredible.  Little nuances in the track get accurately translated to your hands.  The rumble strips feel perfect.  Dip the tire off track or spin out and the car behaves exactly as you'd expect.  It's honestly surreal.

When you grab the wheel, prepare for battle.  The motors are powerful and at speed, you WILL have to fight this thing just like a real car.  The lock-to-lock rotation is spot on as well.  You'll spin it around fast when you enter a hairpin a little too hot and you'll battle it through when you ultimately spin out.  Because this thing means war, you really need to be sure to mount it to something secure.  My "traditional" setup has been one of those coffee tables that you can pull the top open and toward you.  That's not enough for this guy and it will shake the table top.  Plus, those little nuances I mentioned before?  They'll get lost in translation without a durable stand.  I'd STRONGLY recommend getting a specific wheel stand or racing chair.  A bit to that end, we haven't discussed the pedals yet!

The brakes have great progressive resistance and I was absolutely amazed how far these things have come.  The pressure is manageable and you can really manipulate the pedals to keep them where you need them to accurately control the car.  The same goes with the throttle.  It's a TAD on the light side compared to an actual gas pedal, but it doesn't feel wrong or fake.  Finally, to help keep these grounded, Logitech has built in a spike strip you can deploy that bites into the carpet.  Because these pedals are a bit "stiff", I still managed to move them around on carpet, but they stay reasonably in place.

Finally, this is all wrapped up in a high-quality package.  The leather-wrapped wheel feels outstanding and the face and paddle shifters gladly show off their metal build.  The pedals are high-quality metal with rubber grips so this thing's here to stay.  That said, Logitech made some other interesting build choices in my opinion.

Given the power of these force feedback motors, I was a bit disappointed to see that the clamps are both small and plastic.  I DID figure out that they come with pads you can slip off -- so pay attention there -- but it feels like these may break at some point given the force they constantly endure.  Outside of the plastic clamps, there are some additional curiosities to consider.

First, the wheel is still not 'actual size'.  Given, it seems like actual-sized wheels are now a thing of the past but it's the size of all other gaming wheels.  Call me a purist I guess but I don't understand why.  So much attention to detail went into this thing and the second you grab it, you know it just doesn't feel like a car.  This, truly, was my biggest disappointment.  Secondly, this comes with a clutch pedal and no shifter.  To get the shifter, you need to throw down ANOTHER $150 (!!!).  I personally am a fan of paddle shifters anyway, but why not include the pedal with the shifter to get it out of the way?  Finally, the shift light.  I was genuinely excited about this feature but the wheel is so tiny and the LEDs are mounted so low (on the hub, not the wheel itself), that you don't ever really notice them.

In all, this wheel's high performance absolutely eclipses its flaws.  The only negatives are more annoyances than compromises and anyone serious about racing games needs this in your life.  Expensive?  Yes.  But it's money very well spent in my opinion.

UPDATE 1: I have become so obsessed with using this wheel that I have built it a full-on racing seat setup. In doing so, I noticed that both the pedals and wheel have bolt holes so you can legitimately get this thing mounted. Do this and thank me later.

author: Allan L.
title: Logitech G29 Issues. Must read before purchasing.
content:
Beware potential buyers of the Logitech G29. The wheel has an inherent defect. Myself along with other owners have suffered with my wheel malfunctioning after 3 months. What happens is that the wheel stats the Calibrating process, but never stops. Mine malfunctioned in November after purchasing it just in August.
 I strongly recommend purchasing a 1-2 year warranty in case you fall prey to a similar issue. As I said earlier, others have had the exact same issue.

author: Kevin Nicholls
title: The set for more serious sim drivers.
content:
I've been through several racing wheels going back to the Per4mer Turbo Wheel over 20 years ago. Sidewinder Precision? Check. Multiple Thrustmaster wheels? Check. The list goes on, but the point here, is that the G920 is probably the most "real" steering wheel and pedal combo I've felt outside of an arcade.

The wheel and shift paddles are arguably higher quality than what came with some cars I've owned in the past, though I wouldn't have minded if Logitech had gone all out and made the wheel a bit larger. It still has the small "this is a game" geometry to it, and while the metal paddles feel right, the loud clickers are additional reminders if you're looking for a really immersive sim experience.

I was really impressed by how smooth and relatively quiet the force feedback is. It gives some decent fight when you're cornering hard, but at times, I felt like it offered a bit too much travel. Not so much that it was distracting, but I felt like there was too much similarity between the feel across different cars in Forza.

The pedals are especially nice. The travel and resistance is excellent, and the weight keeps them from slipping around very much -- though I'd strongly recommend a stand to keep everything secure. Again, though, they're just small enough and just tight enough together to keep them from being perfect.

At first, I was mildly disappointed that the shifter is a buy-up, but when I really started using this and felt the quality of the components, it really does justify the higher price, relative to other wheel and pedal combos.

It's not perfect, but it's awfully good.

author: mlh758
title: Great wheel for the price
content:
A lot of negative reviews mention the rubber stopper on the brake pedal making it nearly useless without a modification. If you are on a PC this is completely unnecessary, go into the calibration settings and adjust the axis to something that is comfortable for you.

Once that is out of the way, the rest of the setup is pretty fantastic given the price point. The force feedback is decent and the wheel and pedals feel precise. I wish the shifter had a little more feel but considering what it costs I'm not going to complain about that much. I have a lot more fun playing racing games with this than a controller.

author: Judd
title: Far exceeded my expectations
content:
My first gaming wheel. I had no idea the difference it would make. I hoped it would improve the experience of my driving simulators, but couldn’t imagine that it would transform them the way it has.

Within a couple minutes of driving American Truck Simulator, a friend said, “Obviously this is a special kind of chair, too.”  It was just a regular office chair, but the force feedback of this wheel is so well done that my brain is fooled into thinking I’m moving. In my setup the wheel is placed directly in from of a 40 inch screen, which adds to the illusion that I’m looking out a windshield. Still, I never got motion sickness playing with a gamepad even when playing directly in front of the screen.  After about 25 hours with the g920, I’m still often slightly disoriented when I brake, and my inner ear disagrees with my mind’s assertion that I’m decelerating.

It’s hard to overstate how much more control you have with the g920 instead of a controller. Not only is it more precise, but it gives you realistic feedback that helps you learn and make decisions. In Assetto Corsa I feel myself skidding or fishtailing before I see it, and even when spinning out of control, the tugging of the wheel helps me understand the forces on the tires, and how best to right myself.

I should add that the shifter is absolutely worth the extra money. With it, the third pedal functions just like a real clutch.  Driving a stick shift is fun, and also gives the driver more tactile information about the speed and handling of the vehicle. Like the wheel and pedals, the shifter inceases immersion and makes it easier to stay in control.

If like me you have them on a hard floor, you’ll need the pedals braced against something - for me the wall. The clamps on the wheel and gear shift work very well. Construction is solid and attractive. I would like a hat switch, thumb stick, or mouse within reach of my fingers for looking around in game, but it’s well worth occasionally having to take my right hand off the wheel to look with my mouse, in order to experience everything else this device offers.

The shifter is clearly "controller like", but very effective and feels pretty darn good. Love being able to race a stick shift again! The wheel itself, omg, is great. Leather wrapped, smells good, and feels even better when racing. Coming from a Driving Force GT, this thing is the bomb!
